('98', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 1
('98', 0, 1, 2, 45) 1. GIVE AND TAKE1
('98', 0, 2, 3, 63) A Sindhi sufferer writes:
('98', 0, 3, 4, 89) At this critical time when thousands of our countrymen are leaving their ancestral homes and are pouring in from Sind, the Punjab and the N. W. F. P., I find that there is, in some sections of the Hindus, a provincial spirit.
('98', 0, 3, 5, 315) Those who are coming here suffered terribly and deserve all the warmth that the Hindus of the Indian Union can reasonably give.
('98', 0, 3, 6, 443) You have rightly called them dukhi, 2 though they are commonly called sharanarthis.
('98', 0, 4, 7, 527) problem is so great that no government can cope with it unless the people back the efforts with all their might.
('98', 0, 4, 8, 640) I am sorry to confess that some of the landlords have increased the rents of houses enormously and some are demanding pagri.
('98', 0, 4, 9, 765) May I request you to raise your voice against the provincial spirit and the pagri system specially at this time of terrible suffering?
('98', 0, 4, 10, 900) Though I sympathize with the writer, I cannot endorse his analysis.
('98', 0, 4, 11, 968) Nevertheless I am able to testify that there are rapacious landlords who are not ashamed to fatten themselves at the expense of the sufferers.
('98', 0, 4, 12, 1111) But I know personally that there are others who, though they may not be able or willing to go as far as the writer or I may wish, do put themselves to inconvenience in order to lessen the suffering of the victims.
('98', 0, 4, 13, 1325) The best way to lighten the burden is for the sufferers to learn how to profit by this unexpected blow.
('98', 0, 4, 14, 1429) They should learn the art of humility which demands a rigorous self searching rather than a search of others and consequent criticism, often harsh, oftener undeserved and only sometimes deserved.
('98', 0, 4, 15, 1625) Searching of self ennobles, searching of others debases.
('98', 0, 4, 16, 1682) The sufferers should learn the art and virtue of corporate life, in which the circumstance of co operation is ever widening till at last it encircles the whole human race.
('98', 0, 4, 17, 1854) If they do this no sufferer will live in isolation.
('98', 0, 4, 18, 1906) All of them, no matter to which province they belong, will hold together and would be considering not the welfare of self but that of all.
('98', 0, 4, 19, 2045) This does not mean that all of them will live or insist on living at one place, an impossible feat at any time, more so today, when lakhs upon lakhs of people have been torn from their homes, not knowing where to lay their heads upon.
('98', 0, 4, 20, 2280) But this humble spirit of co operation does mean that wherever
('98', 0, 5, 21, 2343) 1 The Gujarati version of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 14 12 1947.
('98', 0, 6, 22, 2413) 2 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 25 11 1947.
('98', 1, 0, 1, 2460) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 1, 1, 2, 2500) they are placed, they will feel one with all the sufferers, no matter from what strata of society they are drawn or to which province they belong.
('98', 1, 1, 3, 2647) Insistence on being accommodated in a particular place of one’s choice there will be none.
('98', 1, 1, 4, 2738) The sufferers will never grumble.
('98', 1, 1, 5, 2772) They will disdain to occupy houses belonging to Muslim owners or tenants, whether these places are physically occupied or evacuated.
('98', 1, 1, 6, 2905) It is for the Government to decide what they will do with property evacuated under abnormal conditions that are prevalent in India today.
('98', 1, 1, 7, 3043) The sufferers’ one and only care would be to hold together and act as one man.
('98', 1, 1, 8, 3122) It would be seen that if the idea thus presented takes shape and spreads, the problem of accommodating sufferers, otherwise styled refugees, will become incredibly simple and they will cease to be a menace.
('98', 1, 1, 9, 3329) Moreover, every sufferer who is not a cripple will do his or her full share of work against bread, clothing and shelter in a becoming manner.
('98', 1, 1, 10, 3471) Thus they will realize the dignity of labour and feel dependent upon no one.
('98', 1, 1, 11, 3548) All will be equal to one another irrespective of sex.
('98', 1, 1, 12, 3602) Some labour will be shared by all, e.g., sanitary work including latrine cleaning and scavenging.
('98', 1, 1, 13, 3700) No labour will be considered too low or too high.
('98', 1, 1, 14, 3750) In this society there will be no room for drones, idlers or loafers.
('98', 1, 1, 15, 3819) This camp life is any day superior to the city life of dirt and squalor side by side with palaces—difficult to decide which is a greater eyesore between the two.
('98', 1, 2, 16, 3981) NEW DELHI, December 6, 1947
('98', 1, 3, 17, 4009) Harijan, 14 12 1947

('98', 1, 6, 23, 4291) Alternatively, you may get the article typed or write it in a still clearer hand.
('98', 1, 6, 24, 4373) I would not be able to translate this article into Gujarati.
('98', 1, 6, 25, 4434) I myself did not follow all the English words fully.
('98', 1, 6, 26, 4487) You had

('98', 2, 5, 10, 5017) 3. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 2, 6, 11, 5045) NEW DELHI, December 6, 1947
('98', 2, 7, 12, 5073) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('98', 2, 8, 13, 5095) You heard the bhajan and the Ramdhun sung by Subbula kshmi 1. She is new to Delhi.
('98', 2, 8, 14, 5178) Usually she gives music recitals.
('98', 2, 8, 15, 5212) One ought to lose oneself while singing bhajans and Ramdhun.
('98', 2, 8, 16, 5273) Today you must have realized why people are so keen to hear her.
('98', 2, 8, 17, 5338) She has a melodious voice.
('98', 2, 8, 18, 5365) I welcomed her message offering to come and sing here.
('98', 2, 8, 19, 5420) Today I do not wish to take more than 15 minutes.
('98', 2, 8, 20, 5470) Yesterday I took 25 minutes which was too long.
('98', 2, 8, 21, 5518) I am ashamed of it.
('98', 2, 8, 22, 5538) I must train myself to finish within 15 minutes.
('98', 2, 8, 23, 5587) Today I intend to take only 15 minutes and leave out what cannot be covered within that time.
('98', 2, 8, 24, 5681) I had a letter from a friend yesterday.
('98', 2, 8, 25, 5721) I have only been able to read a part of it.
('98', 2, 8, 26, 5765) I have another letter today which I have not been able to go through.
('98', 2, 8, 27, 5835) I must ask to be excused.
('98', 2, 8, 28, 5861) The letter which I have read in part says that I am too simple a man, that I do not know how the world’s affairs are run and am apt to be deceived.
('98', 2, 8, 29, 6009) The correspondent also explains the nature of the deception and cautions me to be careful.
('98', 2, 8, 30, 6100) He asks me to see what is happening in Pakistan and suggests that we should do the same here.
('98', 2, 8, 31, 6194) That we should take revenge I do not agree.
('98', 2, 8, 32, 6238) We cannot burn the houses of the Muslims.
('98', 2, 8, 33, 6280) However humble those houses may be they are as dear to their owners as the palaces of millionaires may be to them.
('98', 2, 8, 34, 6395) It is in these houses that they live.
('98', 2, 9, 35, 6433) 1 M. S. Subbulakshmi, eminent exponent of Carnatak music
('98', 3, 0, 1, 6490) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 3, 1, 2, 6530) a Muslim has to go to Pakistan he suffers.
('98', 3, 1, 3, 6573) The correspondent asks when the displaced Hindus and Sikhs can go back to their homes.
('98', 3, 1, 4, 6660) I may inform him that so long as they do not go back I shall not rest.
('98', 3, 1, 5, 6731) It is a different thing if they die before that happens.
('98', 3, 1, 6, 6788) So long as there is a single Hindu or Sikh left who does not get his house back, I shall not rest.
('98', 3, 1, 7, 6887) Yes, one may not ask that the house that has been burnt should be restored to its former state.
('98', 3, 1, 8, 6983) No government can do that, not even the Government of India.
('98', 3, 1, 9, 7044) I shall say that the Hindus and Sikhs should go to Model Town and stay there.
('98', 3, 1, 10, 7122) The Lahore Hindus and Sikhs can ask the Pakistan Government to return them their houses and their land just as they are.
('98', 3, 1, 11, 7243) All that they should ask is that the Muslims who have occupied their properties should be made to vacate them.
('98', 3, 1, 12, 7354) We cannot ask them to raise houses on the land.
('98', 3, 1, 13, 7402) They should merely return the land.
('98', 3, 1, 14, 7438) Those who are now in the Indian Union should become truthful and decent.
('98', 3, 1, 15, 7511) We must not imitate Pakistan.
('98', 3, 1, 16, 7541) If they cut off their noses we can’t do the same.
('98', 3, 1, 17, 7591) I shall further say to the correspondent that if we have made a mistake we must rectify it.
('98', 3, 1, 18, 7683) Everyone makes mistakes.
('98', 3, 1, 19, 7708) Only, one must not repeat them.
('98', 3, 1, 20, 7740) Man is liable to err, even as he has the potentiality to do good.
('98', 3, 1, 21, 7806) Once he rectifies his mistakes, he can only do good.
('98', 3, 1, 22, 7859) If we stick to our dharma it is not necessary to advertise it to the world.
('98', 3, 1, 23, 7935) I have had to write on what happened to Kathiawar Muslims.
('98', 3, 1, 24, 7994) I did the right thing.
('98', 3, 1, 25, 8017) It is good to tell the Hindus there about it.
('98', 3, 1, 26, 8063) It is good to tell the Government.
('98', 3, 1, 27, 8098) It is our right.
('98', 3, 1, 28, 8115) When we agreed to the formation of Pakistan we had not bargained for the houses of Hindus and Sikhs being burnt in Pakistan and their being driven out of the country.
('98', 3, 1, 29, 8282) If mistakes have been made they must be rectified.
('98', 3, 1, 30, 8333) Of course they can say that we should also rectify our own mistakes.
('98', 3, 1, 31, 8402) They may say that the Muslims who had gone to Pakistan were driven out of India and that they should be taken back.
('98', 3, 1, 32, 8518) If that is done the displaced Hindus and Sikhs could go back to Pakistan and the displaced Muslims in Pakistan could come back to India.
('98', 3, 1, 33, 8655) This will be good both for India and Pakistan.
('98', 3, 1, 34, 8702) If not, then both the countries will fall in the eyes of the world.
('98', 3, 1, 35, 8770) We have always conducted ourselves honourably.
('98', 3, 1, 36, 8817) We won our freedom honourably.
('98', 3, 1, 37, 8848) It is not I who say it.
('98', 3, 1, 38, 8872) It is not Hindus and Muslims who say it.
('98', 3, 1, 39, 8913) It is the whole world that says that we have attained our freedom by honourable means.
('98', 3, 1, 40, 9000) We should preserve it by honourable means and not by resorting to rowdyism.
('98', 3, 1, 41, 9076) Rowdyism could be the way to lose our freedom.
('98', 3, 1, 42, 9123) If we keep our conduct and our
('98', 4, 0, 1, 9154) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 5
('98', 4, 1, 2, 9199) behaviour clean the world will see that we have made amends for our former mistakes.
('98', 4, 1, 3, 9284) What is the world going to do about Pakistan —you may ask.
('98', 4, 1, 4, 9343) I shall say that the world does not have to do anything or say anything.
('98', 4, 1, 5, 9416) Pakistan has to cleanse itself.
('98', 4, 1, 6, 9448) I am reminded that the Resolution 1 passed by the A. I. C. C. had my support and that I am responsible for its being passed.
('98', 4, 1, 7, 9573) I am however told that people do not want it.
('98', 4, 1, 8, 9619) Displaced Hindus and Sikhs do not want to go back to Pakistan.
('98', 4, 1, 9, 9682) I do not say that they should go back as beggars.
('98', 4, 1, 10, 9732) True, they have come away from Pakistan because they were helpless.
('98', 4, 1, 11, 9800) But they must go back with dignity.
('98', 4, 1, 12, 9836) The Pakistan Muslims should tell them that they have changed for the better and now invite them to go back.
('98', 4, 1, 13, 9944) Similarly we should tell the Muslims who have gone away that their houses and their land are as they had left behind and that they should come and occupy them.
('98', 4, 1, 14, 10104) If we get over our madness and behave as gentlemen, things will be all right.
('98', 4, 1, 15, 10182) Where is the deception here?
('98', 4, 1, 16, 10211) I do not deceive anyone.
('98', 4, 1, 17, 10236) The world should not look for deception here.
('98', 4, 1, 18, 10282) The A. I. C. C. has passed the Resolution that the displaced Hindus and Sikhs should all go back to their homes and land in Lyallpur and they should be invited to do so with love.
('98', 4, 1, 19, 10462) Our Sikh brethren used to be farmers there.
('98', 4, 1, 20, 10506) They have to go there in any case.
('98', 4, 1, 21, 10541) This is my dream.
('98', 4, 1, 22, 10559) I wish to live to see this dream realized.
('98', 4, 1, 23, 10602) If it is not the will of God that this dream be realized, He will take me away.
('98', 4, 1, 24, 10682) That is why I am staying on in Delhi.
('98', 4, 1, 25, 10720) If I cannot do this here, where else can I do anything?
('98', 4, 1, 26, 10776) If only Pakistan would mend its ways, confess its errors and assure us that it would behave decently, all would be well and we could live as good neighbours.
('98', 4, 1, 27, 10934) There is no reason why we should remain enemies of each other.
('98', 4, 1, 28, 10997) Enmity cannot be our dharma.
('98', 4, 1, 29, 11026) I have concluded within ten minutes today.

('98', 5, 0, 1, 11241) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 5, 1, 2, 11281) 4. DISCUSSION AT KASTURBA GANDHI NATIONAL MEMORIAL TRUST MEETING
('98', 5, 2, 3, 11346) NEW DELHI, December 7, 1947
('98', 5, 3, 4, 11374) QUESTION: Should the sevikas 1 of the Kasturba Trust be given instruction in
('98', 5, 4, 5, 11451) first aid and home remedies or should this be a different department?
('98', 5, 4, 6, 11521) For instance, should the women engaged in Nayee Talim and khadi work receive such training too?
('98', 5, 5, 7, 11617) GANDHIJI: I do hold that any woman who wants to be an all round village worker must have a basic training in nursing.
('98', 5, 5, 8, 11735) That is to say she must know how to deal with and treat common diseases such as boils, malaria, scabies, vomiting, diarrhoea and so on.
('98', 5, 5, 9, 11871) I of course believe only in nature cure.
('98', 5, 5, 10, 11912) But these women must know what the disease is, what diet is to be given and how sponging, enema, etc., have to be given.
('98', 5, 5, 11, 12033) All this is of course covered under Nayee Talim.
('98', 5, 6, 12, 12082) Q. Now that we have our own Government, should we accept assistance from the Government?
('98', 5, 6, 13, 12171) For instance scholarships?
('98', 5, 7, 14, 12198) G. This, as in the case of the previous question, is a matter of individual discretion.
('98', 5, 7, 15, 12286) But I hold the view that we should not alter the policy we have adopted so far.
('98', 5, 7, 16, 12366) People everywhere seem to have become unconcerned and imagine that since now we have our own Government there is no harm in accepting grants.
('98', 5, 7, 17, 12508) But our Government has been there for barely five months, and in this brief period it has had to carry enormous burdens.
('98', 5, 7, 18, 12629) The financial plight of the Government today is far from easy and we must not make it more difficult by burdening it further, nor should the Government involve itself in the question.
('98', 5, 7, 19, 12813) This much relief can certainly be expected with our own Government in power, viz., that workers, both men and women, working in the Kasturba Trust and other national institutions, will not have to face the difficulties they did under the British rule.
('98', 5, 8, 20, 13065) Q. If the sevikas who have received training start working for the
('98', 5, 9, 21, 13132) Communist Party, what should one do?
('98', 5, 9, 22, 13169) Should one ask them to refund the expenses incurred on their training?
('98', 5, 9, 23, 13240) Again, if women from the Communist Party or the Socialist Party request for training being given to them, should they be given the training?
('98', 5, 9, 24, 13381) And should we take in trainees recommended by the Government?
('98', 5, 10, 25, 13443) 1 Women workers
('98', 6, 0, 1, 13459) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 7
('98', 6, 1, 2, 13504) G. It cannot of course be a happy situation if we train workers and are then denied the benefit of their services.
('98', 6, 1, 3, 13619) But we must not be disappointed.
('98', 6, 1, 4, 13652) If the Government sends us trainees and pays their expenses we must give them the training.
('98', 6, 1, 5, 13744) And we must emphatically tell the trainees that courtesy demands that they observe the conditions that go with the training.
('98', 6, 1, 6, 13869) We must not worry which is a trainee follows, or which party she comes from.
('98', 6, 1, 7, 13946) We must be satisfied if she signs the pledge and follows the rules.
('98', 6, 1, 8, 14014) This is not a sectarian organization or a party organization.
('98', 6, 1, 9, 14076) It is an institution of service.
('98', 6, 1, 10, 14109) We should not seek Government grants.
('98', 6, 1, 11, 14147) We have to train women village workers for the revival of the villages.
('98', 6, 2, 12, 14219) Q. Should we have prayers in the training institutions?
('98', 6, 2, 13, 14275) G. Certainly, prayers we must have.
('98', 6, 2, 14, 14311) In fact I hold that prayers must become a part of life.
('98', 6, 2, 15, 14367) It is so with me.
('98', 6, 2, 16, 14385) Prayer is the food of the soul.
('98', 6, 2, 17, 14417) It is the broom to sweep away all the dirt from the mind.
('98', 6, 2, 18, 14475) And the women getting instructions in the camp should as a matter of etiquette present themselves for prayers at the appointed time.
('98', 6, 2, 19, 14608) Whether they are believers or non believers, whether they have faith in prayers or not, they must attend the prayers.
('98', 6, 2, 20, 14726) It cannot be without its effects.
('98', 6, 3, 21, 14760) [From Gujarati]
('98', 6, 4, 22, 14776) Dilhiman Gandhiji—II, pp.
('98', 6, 5, 23, 14802) 5. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 6, 6, 24, 14830) NEW DELHI, December 7, 1947
('98', 6, 7, 25, 14858) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Today I wish to talk to you about a very complicated matter, which is also rather sensitive.
('98', 6, 7, 26, 14973) It has appeared in the newspapers.
('98', 6, 7, 27, 15008) You will have seen that yesterday some Hindu women workers went to Lahore and met some Muslim women there.
('98', 6, 7, 28, 15115) 1 They discussed the
('98', 6, 8, 29, 15136) 1 An Inter Dominion Conference was held in Lahore on December 6, to consider ways and means for the restoration of abducted women.
('98', 6, 8, 30, 15267) A joint appeal to the people of Pakistan and India to restore all abducted women was made by the representatives at the Conference.
('98', 6, 8, 31, 15399) Prominent among the signatories to the appeal were: Ghazanfar Ali, Iftikhar Hussain Khan of Mamdot, Begum Liaquat Ali Khan, Begum Shah Nawaz, Begum Bashir Ahmed, Iftikhar ud din, K. C. Neogy, Swaran Singh, Rameshwari Nehru, Mridula Sarabhai and Kamaladevi Chattopadyaya.
('98', 7, 0, 1, 15670) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 7, 1, 2, 15710) question of what ought to be done about the Hindu women abducted by Muslims in Pakistan and the Muslim women abducted by Hindus and Sikhs in East Punjab.
('98', 7, 1, 3, 15864) A very large number of Muslims have already left India and it is possible some more may yet leave.
('98', 7, 1, 4, 15963) We should now resolve that not a single Muslim will be compelled to leave.
('98', 7, 1, 5, 16038) If they voluntarily opt for Pakistan that is a different matter.
('98', 7, 1, 6, 16103) But the fact is that no one wants voluntarily to leave India.
('98', 7, 1, 7, 16165) Why should anyone want to give up one’s house and property?
('98', 7, 1, 8, 16225) It is not as if they had houses and properties waiting for them in Pakistan.
('98', 7, 1, 9, 16302) Those voluntarily opting for Pakistan or going for the sake of jobs are very few, which is natural because there are not enough jobs for them in Pakistan.
('98', 7, 1, 10, 16457) And if their established businesses in India are not affected, there is no reason for them to go.
('98', 7, 1, 11, 16555) But what of the women?
('98', 7, 1, 12, 16578) This is a complicated question.
('98', 7, 1, 13, 16610) Some say that about 12,000 women had been abducted by Hindus and Sikhs and twice that number had been abducted by Muslims in Pakistan.
('98', 7, 1, 14, 16745) Some others say that this estimate is too low.
('98', 7, 1, 15, 16792) I would say 12,000 is not a small number.
('98', 7, 1, 16, 16834) Why, a thousand, or even one, is not a small number.
('98', 7, 1, 17, 16887) Why should even a single woman be abducted?
('98', 7, 1, 18, 16931) It is barbaric for a Hindu woman to be abducted by a Muslim or a Muslim woman to be abducted by a Hindu or a Sikh.
('98', 7, 1, 19, 17046) Some people believe that 12,000 represents a very conservative figure.
('98', 7, 1, 20, 17117) Let us say that 12.000 is women had been abducted by Muslims of Pakistan and another 12,000 women had been abducted by Hindus and Sikhs of East Punjab.
('98', 7, 1, 21, 17269) The problem is how to recover them.
('98', 7, 1, 22, 17305) The women workers had been to Pakistan to consider how to solve this problem.
('98', 7, 1, 23, 17383) The Hindu and Sikh women carried away by force should be restored to their families.
('98', 7, 1, 24, 17468) Similarly the Muslim women taken away should be restored to theirs.
('98', 7, 1, 25, 17536) This task should not be left to the families of the women.
('98', 7, 1, 26, 17595) It should be our charge.
('98', 7, 1, 27, 17620) They also met Ghazanfar Ali 1 and a police officer whose name I forget.
('98', 7, 1, 28, 17692) Mridulabehn 2 and Rameshwaribehn 3, who had been to Lahore, both gave me separate reports and told me that they discussed
('98', 7, 2, 29, 17814) 1 Minister in charge of Relief and Rehabilitation in Pakistan; he had suggested at the Conference that a joint organization of the Dominions of India and Pakistan should be formed for the restoration of kidnapped women and children to their families.
('98', 7, 2, 30, 18065) 2 Daughter of Ambalal Sarabhai; one of the trustees of the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Trust 3 Rameshwari Nehru; Vice President, Central Board of Harijan Sevak Sangh; President of the women’s section set up by the Ministry of Relief and Rehabilitation
('98', 8, 0, 1, 18323) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 9
('98', 8, 1, 2, 18368) the question of how abducted women should be recovered.
('98', 8, 1, 3, 18424) Obviously it will not do to send police parties or armed units as an escort for these women.
('98', 8, 1, 4, 18517) Of course some Hindu and Sikh women workers could go to Pakistan accompanied by police officers from East Punjab to bring back the abducted women.
('98', 8, 1, 5, 18664) But this is not being done.
('98', 8, 1, 6, 18692) It is said that the women concerned do not now want to return, but still they have to be brought back.
('98', 8, 1, 7, 18795) Muslim women similarly have to be taken back to Pakistan.
('98', 8, 1, 8, 18853) It is also said that the Sikh and Hindu women concerned have embraced Islam and married their Muslim abductors.
('98', 8, 1, 9, 18965) It could be true.
('98', 8, 1, 10, 18983) Bat I do not admit that they are not willing to return.
('98', 8, 1, 11, 19039) Similar is the case of Muslim women in India.
('98', 8, 1, 12, 19085) We have become barbarous in our behaviour.
('98', 8, 1, 13, 19128) It is true of East Punjab as well as of West Purjab.
('98', 8, 1, 14, 19181) It is meaningless to ask which of them is more barbaric.
('98', 8, 1, 15, 19238) Barbarity has no degrees.
('98', 8, 1, 16, 19264) Raja Gazanfar Ali says that both parties have indulged in atrocious behaviour.
('98', 8, 1, 17, 19343) It is not necessary to ask who has been more guilty.
('98', 8, 1, 18, 19396) Atrocities have taken place on a mass scale and it is irrelevant who took the first step.

('98', 9, 4, 23, 22338) 6. A NOTE
('98', 9, 5, 24, 22348) Decemebr 8, 1947
('98', 9, 6, 25, 22365) It would of course be best if a woman could remain unmarried her whole life.
('98', 9, 6, 26, 22442) But only one in a million would be able to do so.
('98', 9, 6, 27, 22492) Desire for marriage is a natural thing.
('98', 9, 6, 28, 22532) There is nothing to be ashamed of in it.
('98', 9, 6, 29, 22573) To believe marriage to be a fall has an adverse effect on the mind and causes harm in many other ways.
('98', 9, 6, 30, 22676) The best way is to treat marriage as a religious duty and to exercise the utmost self restraint in the married state.
('98', 9, 6, 31, 22794) The householder’s state is one of the four states of Varnashrama.
('98', 9, 6, 32, 22860) The other three states depend on it.
('98', 9, 6, 33, 22897) But these days marriage has become a means of indulgence and that has led to terrible consequences.
('98', 9, 6, 34, 22997) Women should regard the duties of the householder’s state as
('98', 10, 0, 1, 23058) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 11
('98', 10, 1, 2, 23104) religious duties and live accordingly.
('98', 10, 1, 3, 23143) Personally I believe the if we give thought to it and live the householder's life with the same strict discipline which a sannyasi follows, we would find that a householder's path is much harder to follow than becoming a sannyasi, that it is a path full of thorns.
('98', 10, 1, 4, 23408) But a rosebush is full of thorns and yet when the roses bloom in the midst of those thorns, the whole bush looks grand.
('98', 10, 1, 5, 23528) We should strive to reach the condition of the rosebush.
('98', 10, 1, 6, 23585) 1 Hence we should marry not with the motive of physical pleasure but to cultivate self control and bring lustre to the householder's dharma.
('98', 10, 1, 7, 23726) That will immensely increase our capacity for service.
('98', 10, 1, 8, 23781) If a woman filled with such a spirit of service chooses as partner a man with similar feelings, the united power of service of the two could benefit the country many more times than the service of either of them singly.
('98', 10, 1, 9, 24001) Similarly, if the householder's life, as I have said, is a religious duty, motherhood automatically becomes one.
('98', 10, 1, 10, 24114) That duty is much more arduous.
('98', 10, 1, 11, 24146) In order to fulfil it, the couple should practise self control and bring forth progeny with a due sense of religious and moral responsibility.
('98', 10, 1, 12, 24289) For that, women should know the rules of physical, mental and spiritual hygiene.
('98', 10, 1, 13, 24370) The woman who presents the country with healthy, vigorous and well brought up children also serves the country.
('98', 10, 1, 14, 24482) If the couple have the spirit of service in them, their children are bound to be influenced by it and will themselves take up work of service when they grow up.
('98', 10, 1, 15, 24643) The point I wish to make is that those who are inspired by a total spirit of service will serve under all conditions.
('98', 10, 1, 16, 24761) If the couple do not live their life in the spirit of service, they will be nothing but imposters.
('98', 10, 1, 17, 24860) Their having been married will then have no meaning.
('98', 10, 1, 18, 24913) The argument that after marriage no work of service is possible has no substance.
('98', 10, 1, 19, 24995) It depends entirely on the marrying couple.
('98', 10, 1, 20, 25039) As my explanation shows, marriage puts the partners to a severe test but also helps them to render service.

('98', 11, 1, 2, 25462) 7. A NOTE
('98', 11, 2, 3, 25472) December 8, 1947 To live, man primarily requires two things food and clothing.
('98', 11, 2, 4, 25551) And the means of solving the problem are simple.
('98', 11, 2, 5, 25600) One way is to accept gifts.
('98', 11, 2, 6, 25628) But begging never helps the poor to solve their problem.
('98', 11, 2, 7, 25685) On the contrary, they lose their spirit and become weak and indolent.
('98', 11, 2, 8, 25755) Another way is to take up a job.
('98', 11, 2, 9, 25788) But service, too, does not make one self reliant.
('98', 11, 2, 10, 25838) The third way is to produce the things one needs.
('98', 11, 2, 11, 25888) There are two means of doing that the charkha and the mill.
('98', 11, 2, 12, 25948) Through mills we can produce cloth on a large scale and become self sufficient as a community but not as individuals.
('98', 11, 2, 13, 26066) There is talk about a third world war.
('98', 11, 2, 14, 26105) If a third world war breaks out, it is doubtful whether we shall not be dragged into it.
('98', 11, 2, 15, 26194) But I leave that question aside, though I can say with confidence that if India only makes up her mind, not only can she keep herself away from war but she has the strength to prove to the world the futility of war.
('98', 11, 2, 16, 26410) But today while brother is cutting brother’s throat in our own country, with what face can I promise that?
('98', 11, 2, 17, 26517) I therefore leave that question aside for the present.
('98', 11, 2, 18, 26572) But if unfortunately for the country it is attacked by bombs, the first targets will be the mills and not the homes where the charkha is plied.
('98', 11, 2, 19, 26716) If, when the mills are razed to the ground as a result of the bombing, the charkha and the takli are plying, we shall not feel helpless and the world will see that though India’s mills had been reduced to ashes, she was still standing on her feet.

('98', 12, 1, 2, 27515) 9. NO LIMITATIONS1
('98', 12, 2, 3, 27534) A correspondent says in substance:
('98', 12, 3, 4, 27569) Individual ahimsa I can understand.
('98', 12, 3, 5, 27605) Corporate ahimsa between friends is also intelligible.
('98', 12, 3, 6, 27660) But you talk of ahimsa towards avowed enemies.
('98', 12, 3, 7, 27707) This is like a mirage.
('98', 12, 3, 8, 27730) It will be a mercy if you give up this obstinacy of yours.
('98', 12, 3, 9, 27789) If you do not, you will forfeit the esteem you enjoy.
('98', 12, 3, 10, 27843) What is worse, you, being considered a Mahatma, mislead many credulous persons to their own and
('98', 12, 4, 11, 27939) society’s harm.
('98', 12, 4, 12, 27955) That non violence which only an individual can use is not of much use in terms of society.
('98', 12, 4, 13, 28046) Man is a social being.
('98', 12, 4, 14, 28069) His accomplishments to be of use must be such as any person with sufficient diligence can attain.
('98', 12, 4, 15, 28167) That which can be exercised only among friends is of value only as a spark of non violence.
('98', 12, 4, 16, 28259) It cannot merit the appellation of ahimsa.
('98', 12, 4, 17, 28302) “Enmity vanishes before ahimsa”, is a great aphorism.
('98', 12, 4, 18, 28356) It means that the greatest enmity requires an equal measure of ahimsa for its abatement.
('98', 12, 4, 19, 28445) Cultivation of this virtue may need long practice, even extending to several births.
('98', 12, 4, 20, 28530) It does not become useless on that account.
('98', 12, 4, 21, 28574) Travelling along the route, the pilgrim will meet richer experiences from day to day so that he may have a glimpse of the beauty he is destined to see at the top.
('98', 12, 4, 22, 28737) This will add to his zest.
('98', 12, 4, 23, 28764) No one is entitled to infer from this that the path will be a continuous carpet of roses without thorns.
('98', 12, 4, 24, 28869) A poet 2 has sung that the way to reach God accrues only to the very brave, never to the fainthearted.
('98', 12, 4, 25, 28972) The atmosphere today is so much saturated with poison that one refuses to recollect the wisdom of the ancients and to perceive the varied little experiences of ahimsa in action.
('98', 12, 4, 26, 29150) “A bad turn is neutralized by a good”, is a wise saying of daily experience in practice.
('98', 12, 4, 27, 29239) Why can we not see that if the sum total of the world’s activities was destructive, it would have come to an end long ago?
('98', 12, 4, 28, 29362) Love, otherwise ahimsa, sustains this planet of ours.
('98', 12, 4, 29, 29416) This much must be admitted.
('98', 12, 4, 30, 29444) The precious grace of life has to be strenuously cultivated, naturally so because it is uplifting.
('98', 12, 4, 31, 29543) Descent is easy, not so ascent.
('98', 12, 4, 32, 29575) A large majority of us being undisciplined, our daily experience is that of fighting or swearing at one another on the slightest pretext.

('98', 13, 5, 6, 30040) A Muslim organization has cautioned me against taking at face value anything said to me whether by a Hindu or a Muslim and making it the basis of an argument.

('98', 16, 5, 7, 36240) 13. LETTER TO A MAULANA
('98', 16, 6, 8, 36264) BIRLA HOUSE, NEW DELHI, December 9, 1947
('98', 16, 7, 9, 36305) MAULANA SAHEB, I had a talk with Sardar Patel about the Muslims from outside who want to settle in Delhi.
('98', 16, 7, 10, 36411) He says that he has no objection to nationalist Muslims settling in Hazarat Nizamuddin if they wish, whatever their number.
('98', 16, 7, 11, 36535) But he is against bringing Muslims from outside, to be rehabilitated in the interior of Delhi in houses now evacuated.
('98', 16, 7, 12, 36654) For, if the Muslims now evacuating these houses return, where will they be accommodated?
('98', 16, 7, 13, 36743) Secondly, if Muslims from outside are rehabilitated in these houses the Hindu and Sikh refugees who cannot find accommodation are bound to object and argue that while they have not been rehabilitated outsiders are brought in for settling.
('98', 16, 7, 14, 36982) The Sardar’s view seems quite right to me.
('98', 16, 7, 15, 37025) Therefore you may bring the nationalist Muslims and help them settle in Hazarat Nizamuddin.
('98', 16, 7, 16, 37117) These outsiders should not be accommodated in the city’s interior.

('98', 16, 9, 19, 37246) 14. TALK WITH WORKERS OF KASTURBA TRUST
('98', 16, 10, 20, 37286) December 9, 1947 Only a woman should be appointed an Agent of the Kasturba Trust.
('98', 16, 10, 21, 37368) For instance, in Assam and Utkal, no women workers are available.
('98', 16, 10, 22, 37434) We should therefore do without Agents there.
('98', 16, 10, 23, 37479) But having regard to the aims of the Trust, men should not be employed as Agents.
('98', 16, 10, 24, 37561) If today we employ them as Agents, tomorrow we shall be tempted to employ them in other capacities too.
('98', 16, 10, 25, 37665) The Turst’s object is to find ways and means to uplift the women and children of villages.
('98', 16, 10, 26, 37756) I do not want the Trust merely to run hospitals.
('98', 16, 10, 27, 37805) We must explain
('98', 17, 0, 1, 37821) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 17, 1, 2, 37862) the meaning of freedom to the women in the seven lakh villages of India.
('98', 17, 1, 3, 37935) We should explain to them the duties and not the rights of a woman as mother, sister and daughter in a free country.
('98', 17, 1, 4, 38052) If we talk about rights, that will increase mutual distrust and strife.
('98', 17, 1, 5, 38124) If they understand their duties, they will automatically understand their rights.
('98', 17, 1, 6, 38206) For instance, if a girl is born, the parents ask what need there is to educate her, and sell her off when she grows up.
('98', 17, 1, 7, 38326) We should try to eradicate such wrong ideas and evil practices.
('98', 17, 1, 8, 38390) If a girl of 20 is sold or married off to an old man of 60 or 70, what is the duty of the girl as a wife?
('98', 17, 1, 9, 38496) A girl of 20 cannot be said to be a mere child.
('98', 17, 1, 10, 38544) If such a girl has been educated by the Trust, she can very humbly and respectfully tell her husband that she looked upon him as her father and she serves him as such.

('98', 20, 4, 22, 46881) 16. QUESTION BOX
('98', 20, 5, 23, 46898) Q. Why does Gandhiji resort to a fast when he faces extreme difficulties?
('98', 20, 5, 24, 46972) What is the effect of this action on the life of the public of India?
('98', 20, 6, 25, 47042) A. Such a question has been put to me before but never, perhaps, precisely in the same terms.
('98', 20, 6, 26, 47136) The answer, however, is easy.
('98', 20, 6, 27, 47166) It is the last weapon in the armoury of the votary of ahimsa.
('98', 20, 6, 28, 47228) When human ingenuity fails, the votary fasts.
('98', 20, 6, 29, 47274) This fasting quickens the spirit of prayer, that is to say, the fasting is a spiritual act and, therefore, addressed to God.
('98', 20, 6, 30, 47399) The effect of such action on the life of the people is that when the person fasting is at all known to them their sleeping conscience is awakened.
('98', 20, 6, 31, 47546) But there is the danger that the people through mistaken sympathy may act against their will in order to save
('98', 21, 0, 1, 47656) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 21, 1, 2, 47697) the life of the loved one.
('98', 21, 1, 3, 47724) This danger has got to be faced.
('98', 21, 1, 4, 47757) One ought not to be deterred from right action when one is sure of the rightness.
('98', 21, 1, 5, 47839) It can but promote circumspection.
('98', 21, 1, 6, 47874) Such a fast is undertaken in obedience to the dictates of the inner voice and, therefore, prevents haste.

('98', 21, 4, 9, 48029) 17. ITS DEEP ROOTS 1
('98', 21, 5, 10, 48050) A correspondent writes to the effect that: Even after independence, the hold of the English language on the city people does not seem to have relaxed to any appreciable extent.
('98', 21, 5, 11, 48227) In proof of his statement he cites the Industrial and Agricultural Exhibition held in Bombay, at which the opener’s speech was in English, the signboards were painted in English and the corres pondence for the most part was conducted in English.
('98', 21, 5, 12, 48473) The ration cards are in English, much to the annoyance of the general public, who cannot read English.
('98', 21, 5, 13, 48576) Our leaders feel that their important pronouncements must be made in English without the slightest regard for the poor public.
('98', 21, 5, 14, 48703) This is a just complaint, demanding peremptory redress.
('98', 21, 5, 15, 48759) The unfortunate inertia has to be thrown out before a visible change for the better takes place in this important matter.

('98', 24, 6, 14, 54995) First, the cotton has to be ginned, carded, made into slivers, and then spun and woven.
('98', 24, 6, 15, 55083) If the hundreds of millions of people in India take to this work—it is easy, we can even teach it to children—all the expenditure on cloth can be saved.
('98', 24, 6, 16, 55236) If cloth is thus manufactured in villages it becomes almost free.
('98', 24, 6, 17, 55302) And if cotton is grown in the villages the saving would be twice as much, for we would have to spend nothing on cloth and we could also benefit from the craft and prosper.
('98', 24, 6, 18, 55474) I therefore feel that if we do not behave foolishly there should be no dearth of cloth in our country.

('98', 26, 4, 19, 60331) 21. WHO SHOULD BE PROVINCIAL GOVERNORS?
('98', 26, 5, 20, 60371) The following is a free translation of Principal Shriman Narayan Agrawal’s letter in Hindustani from Wardha:
('98', 26, 6, 21, 60480) In the Constitution that is being framed by the Constituent Assembly, there is to be provision for the election of provincial Governors by the majority of voters under the adult franchise system.
('98', 26, 6, 22, 60676) From this one is entitled to infer that, as a rule, the nominees of the Congress Parliamentary Board will be elected.
('98', 26, 6, 23, 60794) The Chief Minister of the province will also be of the Congress party.
('98', 26, 6, 24, 60865) Common sense dictates that the provincial Governor must be above party politics of the province concerned, or above being unduly influenced by the Chief Minister or above friction between himself and his Chief Minister.
('98', 26, 7, 25, 61085) In my opinion there is no necessity for a Governor.
('98', 26, 7, 26, 61137) The Chief Minister should be able to take his place and people’s money to the tune of Rs. 5,500 per month for the sinecure of the Governor will be saved.
('98', 26, 7, 27, 61291) Nevertheless, no provincial Governor should belong to his own province.
('98', 26, 8, 28, 61363) Moreover, in this way the expense and worry of an election by the majority of the adult population will be saved.
('98', 26, 8, 29, 61477) Will it not be proper and better
('98', 26, 9, 30, 61510) 1 : 2 A Hindi version of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 21 12 1947.
('98', 27, 0, 1, 61579) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 27, 1, 2, 61620) for the President of the Union to select Governors satisfying the reasonable test above suggested?
('98', 27, 1, 3, 61719) Such Governors will surely raise the tone of the public life of the provinces governed by them.
('98', 27, 1, 4, 61815) It is worthy of note that the present Governors have been appointed by the Central Cabinet of the Union on the above basis and, therefore, their influence on their provinces has been wholesome.
('98', 27, 1, 5, 62009) I fear that if the Governors are elected as threatened under the forthcoming Constitution, their influence is likely to be unwholesome.
('98', 27, 2, 6, 62145) Further, the Constitution as foreshadowed makes no mention of the village panchayat being the foundation of the progressive decentralization in the place of the old hunger for centralization.
('98', 27, 2, 7, 62337) There are other such defects which one can profitably point out, but I have no right or desire to enter into an elaborate criticism of our seasoned leaders.
('98', 27, 2, 8, 62494) I have but ventured to draw your attention to the defects which have appeared to me and demand your guidance.
('98', 27, 2, 9, 62604) There is much to be said in favour of the argument advanced by Principal Agrawal about the appointment of provincial Governors.
('98', 27, 2, 10, 62732) I must confess that I have not been able to follow the proceedings of the Constituent Assembly.

('98', 29, 5, 10, 66301) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('98', 29, 6, 11, 66323) A friend desires that the verses from the Koran we recite here should be explained.
('98', 29, 6, 12, 66407) These verses are ancient.
('98', 29, 6, 13, 66433) The Koran was composed by Mohammed Saheb—it was spoken by him, thirteen centuries ago.
('98', 29, 6, 14, 66520) The extracts from it that we recite are considered sublime like our mantras.
('98', 29, 6, 15, 66597) The very reading of it bestows merit on the reader.
('98', 29, 6, 16, 66649) It is good to know the meaning, of course, but even without knowing it a correct recitation itself is of great value.
('98', 29, 6, 17, 66767) I can now explain the substance of it.
('98', 29, 6, 18, 66806) I do not know Arabic or Persian.
('98', 29, 6, 19, 66839) I do possess a translation, but it is not here now.
('98', 29, 6, 20, 66891) Tomorrow I can provide a literal translation.
('98', 29, 6, 21, 66937) In substance, it is a prayer to God.
('98', 29, 6, 22, 66974) God is one and the same, by whatever name we may call Him.
('98', 29, 6, 23, 67033) Allah is one of His names.
('98', 29, 6, 24, 67060) Then His attributes are described.
('98', 29, 6, 25, 67095) He is called Rahim and Rehman but He is one God.

('98', 29, 6, 27, 67199) Satan drags us down and makes us do evil deeds only God can save us from that fate.
('98', 29, 6, 28, 67283) Man admits that he on his own does not do noble deeds but God prompts him to do so.
('98', 29, 6, 29, 67367) Man is like a drop of water in a sea.
('98', 29, 6, 30, 67405) If God does not save man Satan will devour him.
('98', 29, 6, 31, 67453) God is great.God is All there is.
('98', 29, 6, 32, 67487) His mercy alone can save us.
('98', 29, 6, 33, 67516) I should say that however much we may recite this prayer, ponder over it and follow its import it is not enough.
('98', 29, 6, 34, 67629) You may ask why in that case Muslims indulge in such barbarous behaviour.

('98', 29, 6, 36, 67810) Where are the Christians that live according to the Bible?
('98', 29, 6, 37, 67869) Where are the Hindus who conduct themselves according to the Gayatri?
('98', 29, 6, 38, 67939) We recite from Ishopanishad, “All things are pervaded by the Lord”, meaning that God is in everything.

('98', 33, 1, 2, 74226) 27. DISCUSSION AT CONSTRUCTIVE WORKS COMMITTEE MEETING 1
('98', 33, 2, 3, 74283) NEW DELHI, December 11/12, 1947
('98', 33, 3, 4, 74315) J. B. KRIPALANI: This meeting has been convened by the Constructive Works Committee of the Congress.
('98', 33, 3, 5, 74416) The question has been raised what the constructive workers should do.
('98', 33, 4, 6, 74486) GANDHIJI: The first thing we have to do is to improve our national character.
('98', 33, 4, 7, 74564) No revolution is possible till we build our character.
('98', 33, 4, 8, 74619) The pity is that though swaraj is so recent an achievement, there is already a slackness in constructive efforts.
('98', 33, 4, 9, 74733) I know there are a few difficulties.
('98', 33, 4, 10, 74770) Government help also may not be forthcoming at places.
('98', 33, 4, 11, 74825) But the Congress has always been in our hands.
('98', 33, 4, 12, 74872) And if you will only make an effort the Government too will remain in our hands.
('98', 33, 5, 13, 74953) QUESTION: Should constructive workers take part in politics?
('98', 33, 6, 14, 75014) GANDHIJI: I have answered this question many times before.
('98', 33, 6, 15, 75073) I repeat my answer: leave politics to Rajendra Babu, Jawaharlal and Vallabhbhai.
('98', 33, 6, 16, 75154) You confine yourselves to constructive work.
('98', 33, 6, 17, 75199) It is difficult to answer the question why constructive work is making so little headway, though the Congress has sworn adherence to it for years and men like Jawaharlal, Rajendra Babu and Vallabhbhai are at the helm of affairs.
('98', 33, 6, 18, 75428) All the Sanghs, except the Harijan Sevak Sangh, were brought into being by the Congress.
('98', 33, 6, 19, 75517) Why is it then that the workers of these Sanghs lack the power to make the Government go the whole hog with them?
('98', 33, 6, 20, 75631) No doubt, the fault lies with us, the constructive workers.
('98', 33, 6, 21, 75691) We had faith in constructive work, but our faith was not deep or enlightened enough to illumine our intellect and so our growth has been lop sided.
('98', 33, 6, 22, 75839) The criticism levelled against the constructive workers is that they are generally lacking in imagination and intellect.
('98', 33, 6, 23, 75960) Our intelligentsia are not lacking in sympathy.
('98', 33, 6, 24, 76008) Reason, as a rule, follows in the footsteps of feeling.
('98', 33, 7, 25, 76064) 1 The versions available in Mahatma and Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase have been collated with the Hindi version in Dilhiman Gandhiji.
('98', 33, 7, 26, 76198) Congress workers, including Shankarrao Deo and R. R. Diwakar, had posed the question whether it would not be better in view of the halting policy pursued by the Government, to form themselves into a separate body and go into the Government for the furtherance of the constructive programme.

('98', 46, 7, 25, 106495) Merger, as used here, has no legal significance.
('98', 46, 7, 26, 106544) People of some States in the Deccan Union 3 are reported to have expressed an intense desire for extinction of their Princely houses and their absorption in their provinces.
('98', 46, 7, 27, 106718) This has been described as merging in British India (as it was called during British rule), as distinguished from Princely
('98', 46, 8, 28, 106841) 1 A Gujarati version of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 21 12 1947. 2 A Hindi version of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 21 12 1947. 3 The Deccan States’ Union consisted of the States of Aundh, Bhor, Miraj Junior, Sangli, Ramdurg, Phaltan, Kurundwar Senior and Kurundwar Junior.

('98', 47, 1, 2, 107161) India or States.
('98', 47, 1, 3, 107178) In a society based on non violence, there should be no impatient destruction compassed by [one] man of another, for, every evil doer, unless he mends his ways, is bound to destroy himself.
('98', 47, 1, 4, 107367) Evil can never be self existent.
('98', 47, 1, 5, 107400) Therefore, the Congress policy has always been to mend Princely rule, not to end it, and to induce the Princes to become trustees and servants in reality of their people.
('98', 47, 1, 6, 107571) In pursuance of that policy the Congress Government has tried and in the main succeeded in inducing the States to accede to the Union instead of planning the destruction of Princely rule and absorption of their States as an integral part of the Union provinces concerned.
('98', 47, 1, 7, 107843) Therefore, merger can take place only under two conditions, viz., if the misrule of a particular Prince is self evident and is irremediable, the people will have the right, as it will be their duty, to seek absorption or merger in their province.
('98', 47, 1, 8, 108090) The second condition would be when a Prince and the people of his State both desire merger.
('98', 47, 1, 9, 108182) It is suggested that any one State or its people, whether powerful or insignificant, should not seek merger unless all the States or the majority desire it.
('98', 47, 1, 10, 108339) I do not think so.
('98', 47, 1, 11, 108358) Misrule cannot wait to be ended before there is equal misrule in other States.
('98', 47, 1, 12, 108437) Nor can a Prince who does not wish for any Princely power be expected or be made to wait till the other Princes are ready.
('98', 47, 1, 13, 108560) Each case will have to be decided on its merits by the Central Government.

('98', 47, 3, 16, 108684) 34. SPNING STILL!
('98', 47, 4, 17, 108702) A correspondent writes:
('98', 47, 5, 18, 108726) I and the members of my family have been regular spinners and weavers of khadi.
('98', 47, 5, 19, 108806) Now that we have got our freedom, do you still contend that we should spin and wear khadi?
('98', 47, 5, 20, 108897) This is a strange question.
('98', 47, 5, 21, 108925) Nevertheless, it represents the condition of many people.
('98', 47, 5, 22, 108983) Such persons evidently took to the spinning wheel and khadi merely mechanically and as one of the means of attaining freedom.
('98', 47, 5, 23, 109109) These friends forget that freedom was not mere removal of the foreign yoke, though it was the first essential.
('98', 47, 5, 24, 109220) Khadi represents and represented a way of life based on non violence.
('98', 47, 6, 25, 109290) 1 A Gujarati version of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 21 12 1947.
('98', 48, 0, 1, 109358) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 49
('98', 48, 1, 2, 109404) Rightly or wrongly, it is my opinion that practical disappearance of khadi and non violence shows that the main implication of khadi was not grasped by us during all these years.
('98', 48, 1, 3, 109583) Hence, the tragedy we witness of fratricidal strife and the lawlessness on many sides.
('98', 48, 1, 4, 109670) I have no doubt that spinning and weaving of khadi are more important than ever if we are to have freedom that is to be instinctively felt by the masses of the villagers of India.
('98', 48, 1, 5, 109850) That is the Kingdom of God on earth.
('98', 48, 1, 6, 109887) Through khadi we were struggling to establish supremacy of man in the place of the supremacy of power driven machine over him.
('98', 48, 1, 7, 110014) Through khadi we were striving for equality of all men and women in the place of the gross inequality to be witnessed today.
('98', 48, 1, 8, 110139) We were striving to attain subservience of capital under labour in the place of the insolent triumph of capital over labour.
('98', 48, 1, 9, 110264) Unless, therefore, all the effort made during the past thirty years in India was a retrograde step, hand spinning and all it implies must be prosecuted with much greater vigour and far greater intelligence than hitherto.

('98', 49, 8, 32, 112637) I am speaking of the Gujarat which is near Bombay.
('98', 49, 8, 33, 112688) Vijapur is a town in the Gaekwar State.
('98', 49, 8, 34, 112728) There was a woman worker there who used to
('98', 49, 9, 35, 112771) 1 Addressee’s wife 2 Addressee’s daughter

('98', 50, 1, 2, 112859) travel a good deal.
('98', 50, 1, 3, 112879) Her name was Gangabehn.

('98', 50, 1, 5, 112949) She too went to Vijapur.
('98', 50, 1, 6, 112974) In Gujarat women, who lived in purdah and included both Muslims and Rajputs, used to spin.

('98', 50, 1, 14, 113477) In this way lakhs of homes could get some money earned by the women.
('98', 50, 1, 15, 113546) The charkha thus became very popular there and through this work of khadi the women were able to earn enough money for their food.
('98', 50, 1, 16, 113677) Their demands were small.
('98', 50, 1, 17, 113703) They did not ask for a daily wage of two rupees, or three rupees.
('98', 50, 1, 18, 113769) They got two pice and they were content.
('98', 50, 1, 19, 113810) When they got three or four they were more than satisfied.
('98', 50, 1, 20, 113869) Still later the progress was much more.
('98', 50, 1, 21, 113909) Afterwards when I thought over it I realized that the charkha had tremendous potentiality.
('98', 50, 1, 22, 114000) What is this power?
('98', 50, 1, 23, 114020) What can the charkha achieve?
('98', 50, 1, 24, 114050) The charkha represents the power of non violence.
('98', 50, 1, 25, 114100) If on the one side there is the armed might of the whole world and on the other the charkha plied by the chaste hands— not unworthy hands—of our women, the power of the charkha is greater.
('98', 50, 1, 26, 114289) You have all had a glimpse of that power.
('98', 50, 1, 27, 114331) I have had a little more of it.
('98', 50, 1, 28, 114363) But no one amongst us has known the whole of it.
('98', 50, 1, 29, 114412) People merely thought that the charkha was only for poor women.
('98', 50, 1, 30, 114476) That it certainly is.
('98', 50, 1, 31, 114498) But it is also a symbol of non violence.
('98', 50, 1, 32, 114539) If people knew this they would not burn the charkha.
('98', 50, 1, 33, 114592) Time was when the whole of India plied the charkha and it enjoyed pride of place.
('98', 50, 1, 34, 114674) There were no mills then either in India or anywhere else in the world.
('98', 50, 1, 35, 114746) Cotton textiles were sent to the outside world from India and there was a time when Dacca muslin known as shabnam 1 was very popular.
('98', 50, 1, 36, 114880) It was greatly valued by people outside India.
('98', 50, 1, 37, 114927) They appreciated its beauty.
('98', 50, 1, 38, 114956) I do not wish to go into all that history, though it is quite interesting.
('98', 50, 1, 39, 115031) Nevertheless at that time the charkha was a symbol of slavery, for women were then forced to give a certain quantity of yarn and this was done by order of the government.
('98', 50, 1, 40, 115202) And the Government was not a Muslim government but a Hindu government.
('98', 50, 1, 41, 115273) It is all described in the books written at the behest of the Hindu Government.
('98', 50, 1, 42, 115353) Later on Bengal passed into Muslim
('98', 50, 2, 43, 115388) 1 Literally “dew”

('98', 51, 1, 2, 115447) hands, but this system goes back to much earlier times.
('98', 51, 1, 3, 115503) The charkha then truly stood for slavery.
('98', 51, 1, 4, 115545) Women were forced to spin; they had to supply fixed quantities of yarn and they could not even ask to be paid for it.

('98', 53, 4, 6, 120668) 39. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 53, 5, 7, 120697) NEW DELHI, December 14, 1947
('98', 53, 6, 8, 120726) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, As I was coming to the prayer, I received a note saying that a Muslim friend of the writer had been forced to go away to Pakistan.
('98', 53, 6, 9, 120879) The friend had left with the writer of the note some gold and silver bought with the earnings of his own labour.
('98', 53, 6, 10, 120992) He wants to know how it is to be sent to its owner in Pakistan, who however has not given his name and address in Pakistan.
('98', 53, 6, 11, 121116) If he furnishes the particulars I shall pass on the gold and silver to the Government to be sent to the person concerned.
('98', 53, 6, 12, 121238) Till he is traced the property can remain with the Government.
('98', 53, 6, 13, 121301) It is gratifying to know that notwithstanding all that has happened there are still among us Hindus and Muslims between whom fraternal feelings continue to exist and who do not covet what belongs to their friends of the other community.
('98', 53, 6, 14, 121538) If everyone was like this the misfortune that has befallen us would soon be overcome.
('98', 53, 6, 15, 121624) I told you I would be reporting to you briefly whatever took place at the meetings of various Sanghs being held in the Harijan Colony.
('98', 53, 6, 16, 121759) Yesterday I told you about the Charkha Sangh and its activities of spinning and weaving.
('98', 53, 6, 17, 121848) I have to tell you now about village industries and Nayee Talim.
('98', 53, 6, 18, 121913) I shall deal with Nayee Talim today.
('98', 53, 6, 19, 121950) Nayee Talim is not a thing with which everyone is acquainted, though the work has been going on now for seven or eight years.
('98', 53, 7, 20, 122076) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('98', 53, 7, 21, 122113) The correspondent had rejected the explanation suggested by Richard B. Gregg, for the recent violence in India.
('98', 53, 7, 22, 122225) Vide “A Psychological Explanation”, 11 11 1947.
('98', 54, 0, 1, 122273) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 55
('98', 54, 1, 2, 122319) Nayee Talim consists in imparting all instructions through some handicrafts.
('98', 54, 1, 3, 122396) The idea in a way has much deeper roots.
('98', 54, 1, 4, 122437) The argument is that no education is true education unless it is founded in truth and non violence.
('98', 54, 1, 5, 122537) A man may have acquired all the learning, understood the essence of all the scriptures, may have studied Sanskrit, Arabic and Persian, but, as the Sanskrit saying 1 goes, unless he has acquired true wisdom all his education has been in vain.
('98', 54, 1, 6, 122779) By true wisdom is meant that which leads us to mukti.
('98', 54, 1, 7, 122833) There are of course various kinds of mukti.
('98', 54, 1, 8, 122877) There is release from the bondage of action, release from the clutches of a tyrant, release of a girl from the hands of a maniac, and liberation of the country from foreign yoke.
('98', 54, 1, 9, 123056) The makti meant here is the liberation from all the ills of the world.
('98', 54, 1, 10, 123127) Education that is not rooted in truth and non violence is no education in the proper sense of the word.
('98', 54, 1, 11, 123231) There are so many instances of people who were highly learned and yet were satanic in their pursuits.
('98', 54, 1, 12, 123333) One famous instance is that of Ravana.
('98', 54, 1, 13, 123372) Ravana possessed great learning and his penance too was great.
('98', 54, 1, 14, 123435) And yet because his pursuits were demoniac he perished, whereas Rama lives even today.
('98', 54, 1, 15, 123522) We regard Rama as a manifestation of the Supreme Lord.
('98', 54, 1, 16, 123577) So in order to acquire true wealth of learning we must cultivate truth and non violence.
('98', 54, 1, 17, 123666) The discussion at the meeting centred round the question of the method of giving such education.
('98', 54, 1, 18, 123763) It could not obviously be imparted through books.
('98', 54, 1, 19, 123813) Then what should be done?
('98', 54, 1, 20, 123839) Millions of people in the country pursue some handicraft.
('98', 54, 1, 21, 123897) They cannot all be rich.
('98', 54, 1, 22, 123922) Even in America everyone is not rich.
('98', 54, 1, 23, 123960) True, the poverty there is of a different order but the hardships attendant on poverty are similar.
('98', 54, 1, 24, 124060) In the same way various other ills widespread in India also exist there.
('98', 54, 1, 25, 124133) With all their wealth and all their learning they have not been able to overcome these.
('98', 54, 1, 26, 124221) I thought that if the millions were to be given education it could be done only through handicraft.
('98', 54, 1, 27, 124321) If among a population of hundreds of millions a lakh or two have secured what now passes for education, what good can it do?
('98', 54, 1, 28, 124446) And if everyone tried to have that education we would go bankrupt.
('98', 54, 1, 29, 124513) The real system of education is one where the children of rich and poor, of king and subject, receive education through crafts.
('98', 54, 1, 30, 124641) And this cannot be done unless we adhere to truth and non violence.
('98', 54, 1, 31, 124709) It becomes a question of religion here—not religion in a sectarian sense but religion in a universal sense.
('98', 54, 1, 32, 124817) Such religion is eternal.
('98', 54, 1, 33, 124843) It cannot change.
('98', 54, 1, 34, 124861) It is for all, as much for Hindus as for Muslims.
('98', 54, 1, 35, 124911) One cannot
('98', 55, 0, 1, 124922) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 55, 1, 2, 124963) say that Hindus should speak the truth and Muslims should tell lies.
('98', 55, 1, 3, 125032) It is in the interest of all to speak the truth.
('98', 55, 1, 4, 125081) It is no one’s religious duty to commit violence.
('98', 55, 1, 5, 125131) If someone asks me whether Sikhs and Muslims may not receive Nayee Talim I shall say that if Sikhs and Muslims both declare that they are votaries of violence then certainly Nayee Talim would not be for them.
('98', 55, 1, 6, 125340) Nayee Talim is not the special province of any one sect.
('98', 55, 1, 7, 125397) I have studied all religions and assimilated their essence.
('98', 55, 1, 8, 125457) Muslims and Sikhs both come and sit beside me.
('98', 55, 1, 9, 125504) They advocate violence only where all other methods fail.
('98', 55, 1, 10, 125562) But when we initiate a child into education we should begin by teaching him how to die rather than kill.

('98', 55, 1, 12, 125752) Those carrying it on must stand by truth and non violence.

('98', 55, 1, 23, 126196) But I have never known him to be guilty of falsehood or violence.
('98', 55, 1, 24, 126262) He is associated with me only because he does not believe in violence.
('98', 55, 1, 25, 126333) The Secretaries of the Hindustani Talimi Sangh are Aryanayakum and his wife.
('98', 55, 1, 26, 126410) They too are votaries of truth and non violence.
('98', 55, 1, 27, 126459) I am busy otherwise and they have to run the scheme.

('98', 55, 1, 29, 126559) It is not even Zakir Saheb.
('98', 55, 1, 30, 126587) He is only the President.

('98', 58, 6, 9, 132415) 5. He will live permanently in Lahore.
('98', 58, 7, 10, 132454) No conditions are laid down for the Muslims.
('98', 58, 7, 11, 132499) Then why these conditions for the Hindus?
('98', 58, 7, 12, 132541) The Hindus say they cannot abide by the conditions.
('98', 58, 7, 13, 132593) So they go back disappointed.
('98', 58, 7, 14, 132623) I have already spoken of the possibility of disappointment and even if the report is accurate it does not necessarily follow that what the Muslim friends told me is false.
('98', 58, 7, 15, 132795) The persons concerned have not only to think of their own position but they have to think of India, whose representatives they are, and of Pakistan which has given them the assurances.
('98', 58, 7, 16, 132980) I may say that the Muslim friends concerned keep in touch with me.
('98', 58, 7, 17, 133047) They came to see me today too.
('98', 58, 7, 18, 133078) But I was observing silence and writing my prayer message and so could not see them.
('98', 58, 7, 19, 133163) They sent me word that they were not sitting idle but working for their mission.
('98', 58, 7, 20, 133244) My advice to the correspondent is not to be so full of distrust and so sensitive.
('98', 58, 7, 21, 133326) He will lose nothing by trusting.
('98', 58, 7, 22, 133360) Distrust eats up a man.
('98', 58, 7, 23, 133384) He should behave with discretion.
('98', 58, 7, 24, 133418) For myself I can only say that I do not regret what I have done.
('98', 58, 7, 25, 133483) All my life I have trusted in people with my eyes open.
('98', 58, 7, 26, 133539) I shall continue to trust the Muslim friends till it is proved that they cannot be trusted.
('98', 58, 7, 27, 133631) Trust begets trust.
('98', 58, 7, 28, 133651) It gives one the strength to face treachery.
('98', 58, 7, 29, 133696) If refugees from both sides are to go back to their homes the way for it is the way I have adopted and am following.
('98', 58, 7, 30, 133813) The correspondent’s suspicion that it is a trick to create a split between the Hindus and the Sikhs is wrong.
('98', 58, 7, 31, 133923) I had even mentioned to the Muslim friends the possibility of their assurance being given such prejudicial construction.
('98', 58, 7, 32, 134044) They denied vehemently that there was any trickery in it.
('98', 58, 7, 33, 134102) I see nothing wrong in a path being paved for those wishing to return.
('98', 58, 7, 34, 134173) It cannot be denied that there is more poison in Pakistan for Sikhs than for Hindus but the Hindus and
('98', 59, 0, 1, 134276) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 59, 1, 2, 134317) Sikhs have to swim or, sink together.
('98', 59, 1, 3, 134355) They should harbour no malice.
('98', 59, 1, 4, 134386) Intriguers cannot have sincere amity among themselves.
('98', 59, 1, 5, 134441) A correspondent from East Pakistan says:
('98', 59, 2, 6, 134482) Now that India has been partitioned how can you call yourself a citizen of united India?
('98', 59, 2, 7, 134571) Now what belongs to one Dominion cannot belong to the other.
('98', 59, 2, 8, 134632) Whatever the legal pundits may say they cannot rule the hearts of men.
('98', 59, 2, 9, 134703) Who can prevent the correspondent from saying that he is a citizen of the world?
('98', 59, 2, 10, 134784) Legally that is not the case and some countries have laws that would prevent him from entering those countries.
('98', 59, 2, 11, 134896) But if one has not been reduced to an automation, as some of us have not been, what does it matter to one what one’s legal status is?
('98', 59, 2, 12, 135030) So long as we are morally on the right path we do not have to worry.
('98', 59, 2, 13, 135099) What we have to take care of is that we do not nurse enmity towards anyone or any country.
('98', 59, 2, 14, 135190) For instance no one who harbours enmity towards Muslims or Pakistan can claim to be a citizen of both Pakistan and India.
('98', 59, 2, 15, 135312) If such feeling of enmity spreads it will end up in a war breaking out between the two countries.
('98', 59, 2, 16, 135410) Every country will treat as traitors those of its citizens who harbour malice towards it and help a foreign country.
('98', 59, 2, 17, 135527) Loyalty is indivisible.

('98', 61, 1, 2, 137588) 45. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 61, 2, 3, 137617) NEW DELHI, December 16, 1947
('98', 61, 3, 4, 137646) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I am told— and to some extent it is true—that controls on certain articles of food and clothing have been removed and will be removed from more articles.
('98', 61, 3, 5, 137822) There is now no doubt that controls are on the way out and Brijkishan has told me of its very first consequence.
('98', 61, 3, 6, 137935) Gur, which used to be sold at Re.
('98', 61, 3, 7, 137969) 1 a seer is now available at 8 [annas] a seer.
('98', 61, 3, 8, 138016) This is some achievement.
('98', 61, 3, 9, 138042) Of course the price should be still lower.
('98', 61, 3, 10, 138085) When I was young no one could have dreamt that gur would ever become so dear.
('98', 61, 3, 11, 138163) A seer of it could be had for one anna or less.
('98', 61, 3, 12, 138211) We should therefore hope that the price of this commodity will further fall.
('98', 61, 3, 13, 138288) No doubt we cannot have it free of cost.
('98', 61, 3, 14, 138329) Similarly, sugar has come down from Rs. 32 to Rs. 20 a maund.
('98', 61, 3, 15, 138391) Moong 1, urad 2 and arhar 3 are now sold at 1_ seers for a rupee.
('98', 61, 3, 16, 138457) The same is true of gram.
('98', 61, 3, 17, 138483) Gram, in my opinion, is included in the pulses, but in this region it has various special uses and so it is kept separate.
('98', 61, 3, 18, 138606) It used to sell at Rs. 24 a maund.
('98', 61, 3, 19, 138641) Now the price is Rs. 18. The black market price of wheat used to be Rs. 34 a maund.
('98', 61, 3, 20, 138725) It is now Rs. 24. The same goes for other articles.
('98', 61, 3, 21, 138777) People used to frighten me that I did not know how markets were operated, how prices rose and fell, that I did not know economics, that I was saying what I did because I was a mahatma and did not have to suffer the consequences of decontrol; it was the poor who would have to suffer.
('98', 61, 3, 22, 139061) But from the first results of decontrol I see that the people will live rather than die through the measure.
('98', 61, 3, 23, 139170) I shall therefore say that control on maize, barley and millet should also be lifted.
('98', 61, 3, 24, 139256) Because those who are used to millet will continue to eat millet.
('98', 61, 3, 25, 139322) They will not be able to digest wheat.
('98', 61, 3, 26, 139361) Similarly there are many whose staple diet is maize.
('98', 61, 3, 27, 139414) I thus see no reason why control on these articles should continue.
('98', 61, 3, 28, 139482) Dr. Rajendra Prasad too had promised that gradually all controls would be lifted.
('98', 61, 3, 29, 139564) We have seen the desirable consequences of some controls being lifted.
('98', 61, 3, 30, 139635) Now take match boxes.
('98', 61, 3, 31, 139657) One has to pay an exorbitant price for a box of matches in the black market, which is really the open market.
('98', 61, 3, 32, 139767) There is no doubt that if it is decontrolled it will have a very good
('98', 61, 4, 33, 139837) 1 Varieties of pulses 2 ibid
('98', 62, 0, 1, 139866) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 63
('98', 62, 1, 2, 139912) effect.
('98', 62, 1, 3, 139920) Match boxes never used to be so costly.
('98', 62, 1, 4, 139960) In my time it cost almost nothing.
('98', 62, 1, 5, 139995) Today a box of matches is sold, maybe, for one anna.
('98', 62, 1, 6, 140048) Then one got a whole dozen for that price.
('98', 62, 1, 7, 140091) Things were never so costly as they are now.
('98', 62, 1, 8, 140136) I am happy when people’s incomes rise but the rise in prices always distresses me.
('98', 62, 1, 9, 140219) If the prices rise the excess should go to the toiler, but even then prices cannot rise so steeply.
('98', 62, 1, 10, 140319) This happens when traders turn wicked and greedy and want to pocket as much profit as they can.
('98', 62, 1, 11, 140415) We have got our independence and we have been through a great calamity also, but still we have not learnt purity of conduct.
('98', 62, 1, 12, 140540) If our traders content themselves with what is a just profit, I have not the least fear that decontrol will lead to a rise in prices.
('98', 62, 1, 13, 140674) Even those who have such a fear attribute it to the fact that we are wicked and dishonest.
('98', 62, 1, 14, 140765) Traders care only for their profits and the farmers and other producers too are only concerned with filling their own bellies and nobody bothers about the consumers.
('98', 62, 1, 15, 140931) If that is so, how can one say that there is democracy in India?
('98', 62, 1, 16, 140996) How can such things be permitted in a democracy?
('98', 62, 1, 17, 141045) In a democracy it is incumbent on the Government to trust the people.
('98', 62, 1, 18, 141115) It must clearly say that it will do as the people desire but that if what they desire brings them hardships it cannot be held responsible.
('98', 62, 1, 19, 141254) True, we have a Civil Service, but all of us who are here should consider ourselves soldiers and serve the people.
('98', 62, 1, 20, 141369) Today malpractices flourish.
('98', 62, 1, 21, 141398) I am continuously receiving telegrams, etc., from everywhere.
('98', 62, 1, 22, 141460) I understand there are some fishy practices going on in Bombay though I do not know exactly what.
('98', 62, 1, 23, 141558) This should stop.
('98', 62, 1, 24, 141576) But the people should congratulate the Government for the good work that has so far been done.
('98', 62, 1, 25, 141671) It also encourages it.
('98', 62, 1, 26, 141694) So much for the lifting of controls.
('98', 62, 1, 27, 141731) There is then the matter of the [Indian] Civil Service.
('98', 62, 1, 28, 141787) I am receiving letters every day complaining of the expenditure still being incurred on the Civil Service.
('98', 62, 1, 29, 141894) How can all I. C. S. men be removed all at once?
('98', 62, 1, 30, 141943) And if they were, how would the work go on?
('98', 62, 1, 31, 141987) Some have already gone and some others, who are soon to go, are having to do much hard work.
('98', 62, 1, 32, 142080) The I. C. S. is in the charge of the Sardar.
('98', 62, 1, 33, 142125) He praises that cadre very highly.
('98', 62, 1, 34, 142160) Although they are few in number the I. C. S. men deserve to be complimented for the work they do.
('98', 62, 1, 35, 142258) They no doubt receive high salaries.
('98', 62, 1, 36, 142295) Still, it is we who constitute the real Civil Service.
('98', 62, 1, 37, 142350) Let the Government accept us as the Civil Servants and, in order to enforce discipline, punish us as it does the Civil Servants.
('98', 62, 1, 38, 142479) Let it summon any one of us and say he has to do such and such work.
('98', 62, 1, 39, 142548) Is not there a law to punish those guilty of misconduct?
('98', 62, 1, 40, 142605) If there is none, I shall say they should frame one.
('98', 62, 1, 41, 142658) They should place on the whole
('98', 63, 0, 1, 142689) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 63, 1, 2, 142730) people the responsibility they have placed on the Civil Service.
('98', 63, 1, 3, 142795) It is after all a people’s government.
('98', 63, 1, 4, 142834) Why do I have to say this?
('98', 63, 1, 5, 142861) Because there has been a fresh development; the Congress has said that there should be a Parlia mentary Secretary attached to each Minister, and these Parliamentary Secretaries should be not from among the I. C. S. officers but from the ranks of the Congress or from among those supporting the Congress.
('98', 63, 1, 6, 143165) Of course they will not work gratis.
('98', 63, 1, 7, 143202) They will have to be paid salaries.
('98', 63, 1, 8, 143238) If today we did not control the Government with its immense financial resources, how could we have paid these salaries?
('98', 63, 1, 9, 143358) But since we control the Government we must pay one a salary of Rs. 1,500 or Rs. 2,000, give him a house and other benefits, and call him a Parliamentary Secretary.
('98', 63, 1, 10, 143523) I must say it pains me—be it a Parliamentary Secretary attached to the Prime Minister or to the Home Minister or any other Minister.
('98', 63, 1, 11, 143656) Even if the Parliament —or rather the Congress Party—insists on creating such a post, does one have to work only for a salary?
('98', 63, 1, 12, 143783) In that case India will become a worthless country.
('98', 63, 1, 13, 143835) Was our strength born only today?
('98', 63, 1, 14, 143869) Let us first produce some results.
('98', 63, 1, 15, 143904) Let us sit down and assess how much we have produced in excess of what was produced till August 14. Have we produced more grain, more cloth, more industrial goods?
('98', 63, 1, 16, 144068) When people become industrious, earn money and become prosperous so that they can be generous in giving, then we can say that lustre has been added to India’s name and its worth has gone up.
('98', 63, 1, 17, 144259) But today our per capita income is only Rs. 70. This is nothing.
('98', 63, 1, 18, 144324) When this has doubled or risen even further and the rural incomes have also risen you can then ask the Government to pay more.
('98', 63, 1, 19, 144451) But if our production does not increase and we go on increasing our expenditure, where shall we be?
('98', 63, 1, 20, 144551) Take for instance a shop—and India is only a large shop—whose proprietor seeks from the manager an account of the sales every evening.
('98', 63, 1, 21, 144686) If he is told the sale today has been worth Rs. 1,000 while yesterday it was worth only Rs. 500 he is pleased.
('98', 63, 1, 22, 144797) But when he is told that the expenditure has been of the order of Rs. 1,500, he will fly into a rage and start shouting at the manager.
('98', 63, 1, 23, 144933) Shouting and abusing is bad no doubt and so is getting angry, but his point is well taken.
('98', 63, 1, 24, 145024) If the income is Rs. 1,000 and the expenditure Rs. 1,500, where is he to find the Rs. 500 to balance the books?
('98', 63, 1, 25, 145136) Today we have the money, so we go on a spree.
('98', 63, 1, 26, 145182) Tomorrow it will be gone.
('98', 63, 1, 27, 145208) It therefore pains me when we throw money away so recklessly.
('98', 63, 1, 28, 145270) This will do for today.

('98', 67, 1, 2, 149114) 52. MESSAGE TO U. P. STUDENTS
('98', 67, 2, 3, 149144) December 17, 1947
('98', 67, 3, 4, 149162) I have your letter and invitation.
('98', 67, 3, 5, 149197) I love being among students because I consider myself a student.
('98', 67, 3, 6, 149262) But at present I am trapped here.
('98', 67, 3, 7, 149296) Still, this too is a big school.

('98', 72, 7, 16, 161529) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, A correspondent writes to ask why I object to English being used, but not to Urdu.
('98', 72, 7, 17, 161634) The Muslims and the English are the same to us since we are friends of all.
('98', 72, 7, 18, 161710) The correspondent’s complaint arises out of ignorance.
('98', 72, 7, 19, 161765) Not only do I not object to Urdu being used, I am its advocate.

('98', 72, 7, 23, 162138) But all these 14 or 15 languages cannot be used in all the provinces.
('98', 72, 7, 24, 162208) The question also is what language should serve as a link language between the provinces.
