('98', 78, 6, 11, 172679) 64. ADDRESS TO MEOS
('98', 78, 7, 12, 172699) JESARAH, December 19. 1947
('98', 78, 8, 13, 172726) Addressing a gathering mainly of the Meos Gandhiji remarked that his voice was not so powerful as it once used to be.
('98', 78, 8, 14, 172844) There was a time when whatever he said was acted upon.
('98', 78, 8, 15, 172899) If it had the original power, not a single Muslim should have found it necessary to migrate to Pakistan from the Indian Union or a single Hindu or Sikh to leave his hearth and home in Pakistan and seek asylum in the Indian Union.
('98', 78, 8, 16, 173129) What had taken place—the orgy of murder, arson, loot, abductions, forcible conversions and worse that they had witnessed—was, in his opinion, unmitigated barbarism.
('98', 78, 8, 17, 173294) True, such things were not unknown before, but there was not that wholesale communal discrimination.
('98', 78, 8, 18, 173395) Tales of such happenings had filled him with grief and shame.
('98', 78, 8, 19, 173457) Even more shameful was the demolition and desecration of mosques, temples and gurdwaras.
('98', 78, 8, 20, 173546) Such madness, if it was not arrested, must spell ruin to both the communities.
('98', 78, 8, 21, 173625) They were far from freedom while this madness reigned.
('98', 78, 9, 22, 173680) What was the remedy, Gandhiji continued.
('98', 78, 9, 23, 173721) He had no faith in the force of bayonets.
('98', 78, 9, 24, 173763) He could only present to them the weapon of non violence, which provided an answer to every emergency and which was invulnerable.
('98', 78, 9, 25, 173893) It was common to all great religions—to Christianity no less than to Hinduism, etc., but it had today been reduced to a mere copy book maxim by the votaries of religions and in practice they all followed the law of the jungle.
('98', 78, 9, 26, 174120) His might be today a voice in the wilderness,
('98', 78, 10, 27, 174166) 1 Launched in 1917 against the Tinkathia system, under which peasants had to grow indigo on 3/20 of their holdings at the will of the landlords.
('98', 79, 0, 1, 174311) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 79, 1, 2, 174352) said Gandhiji, but he had no other message to give them except this message of non violence of meeting the challenge of brute force with the power of the spirit.
('98', 79, 2, 3, 174514) Gandhiji then referred to the representation which was read to him by a representative of the Meos in which had been catalogued their complaints for which they wanted redress.
('98', 79, 2, 4, 174690) He had placed that letter, Gandhiji told the audience, in the hands of Dr. Gopichand, their Chief Minister and the speaker would leave it to him (Dr. Gopichand) to tell them what he proposed to do in regard to the various points set forth in it.
('98', 79, 2, 5, 174936) All he could say was that if any Government officer had been guilty of misconduct, he was sure, the Government would not hesitate to take suitable action against him.
('98', 79, 2, 6, 175103) No individual could be allowed to usurp the function of the Government and expect a reshuffle of Government officers at his bidding.
('98', 79, 2, 7, 175236) He was clear too that no conversion or marriage of a woman to a member of the opposite community could be recognized as valid on the plea of consent or free will.
('98', 79, 2, 8, 175399) It was abuse of words to talk of free consent when terror reigned.
('98', 79, 3, 9, 175466) He would feel happy, continued Gandhiji, if his words could bring some consolation to them in their distress.
('98', 79, 3, 10, 175576) Referring to the Meo refugees who had been driven out of the Alwar and Bharatpur States, Gandhiji remarked that he looked forward to the day when all enmities would be forgotten and all hatred buried underground and all those who had been driven away from their hearths and homes would return to them and resume their avocations in perfect security and peace as before.
('98', 79, 3, 11, 175946) His heart would then dance with joy.
('98', 79, 3, 12, 175983) He would never give up that hope so long as he lived.
('98', 79, 3, 13, 176037) But he was free to confess that today conditions were not ripe for it.
('98', 79, 3, 14, 176108) He was sure that the Union Government would not be remiss in discharging its duty in that respect, and the States would have to listen to the advice of the Union Government.
('98', 79, 3, 15, 176282) The Instrument of Accession did not give to the Rulers of the States the freedom to oppress their subjects.
('98', 79, 3, 16, 176390) The Rulers had to be trustees and servants of their subjects if they wanted to retain their status.
('98', 79, 3, 17, 176490) Gandhiji concluded by giving a word of advice to the Meos.
('98', 79, 3, 18, 176549) He had been told, he remarked, that the Meos were almost like criminal tribes.
('98', 79, 3, 19, 176628) If the statement was correct, it called for an all out effort on their part to reform themselves.
('98', 79, 3, 20, 176726) It should not be left to others to do the work of reclamation.
('98', 79, 3, 21, 176789) He hoped that the Meos would not resent his advice, but take it in the spirit in which it was offered.
('98', 79, 3, 22, 176892) To the Government he would say that even if the allegation regarding the Meos was correct, that was no argument for sending them away to Pakistan.
('98', 79, 3, 23, 177039) The Meos were subjects of the Indian Union and it was its duty to help them to reclaim themselves by providing them with facilities of education and establishing settlements for them to settle in.
('98', 79, 4, 24, 177236) Harijan, 28 12 1947, and The Hindustan Times, 20 12 1947
('98', 79, 5, 25, 177293) 1 The audience was then addressed by Dr. Gopichand Bhargava.
('98', 79, 5, 26, 177354) On his way back to Delhi, Gandhiji visited an open air camp of the Meos and talked with the people there.
('98', 80, 0, 1, 177460) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 81
('98', 80, 1, 2, 177506) 65. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 80, 2, 3, 177535) NEW DELHI, December 19, 1947
('98', 80, 3, 4, 177564) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Today I had to go to Gurgaon to see the Meos.
('98', 80, 3, 5, 177632) The Meos there consist of refugees from Alwar and Bharatpur, besides those who are natives of the place.
('98', 80, 3, 6, 177737) The East Punjab Premier Dr. Gopichand Bhargava accompanied me.
('98', 80, 3, 7, 177800) He told the Meos that those of them who wanted to stay could stay on.
('98', 80, 3, 8, 177870) The Government would protect them.
('98', 80, 3, 9, 177905) That hundreds of thousands had to leave their houses and properties in Pakistan was something barbarous.
('98', 80, 3, 10, 178010) It was also a barbarous thing that people had to leave their houses and properties here.
('98', 80, 3, 11, 178099) One cannot go into who committed more barbarities because such a discussion cannot end the enmity that has been generated.
('98', 80, 3, 12, 178222) It should not be our fate to be eternal enemies of each other.
('98', 80, 3, 13, 178285) It will only end in our ruin.
('98', 80, 3, 14, 178315) I have said that I cannot tolerate this.
('98', 80, 3, 15, 178356) Those who have made up their minds to go will certainly go but no one will be forced to go.
('98', 80, 3, 16, 178448) There are men and women there in large numbers.
('98', 80, 3, 17, 178496) All of them are in distress.
('98', 80, 3, 18, 178525) Many of them have not even tents to shelter them and the days are so cold.
('98', 80, 3, 19, 178600) It is a tragic sight.
('98', 80, 3, 20, 178622) The Alwar State should admit its mistake and invite them back.
('98', 80, 3, 21, 178685) The Bharatpur State should do the same.
('98', 80, 3, 22, 178725) One cannot say that Meos are a criminal tribe.
('98', 80, 3, 23, 178772) Who can say who is criminal and who is not?
('98', 80, 3, 24, 178816) And will you exile those who are criminals?
('98', 80, 3, 25, 178860) Will you kill them?
('98', 80, 3, 26, 178880) This will never do.
('98', 80, 3, 27, 178900) You have to reform them and educate them and show them the ways of civilized behaviour.
('98', 80, 3, 28, 178988) My second topic today is sugar.
('98', 80, 3, 29, 179020) Sugar is not produced everywhere.
('98', 80, 3, 30, 179054) It has to be transported from the places where it is produced.
('98', 80, 3, 31, 179117) If we do not have sugar here we have to bring it from the U. P. or Coimbatore, but how to do it?
('98', 80, 3, 32, 179214) It can only be brought in railway wagons, but there are no wagons available.
('98', 80, 3, 33, 179291) Dr. John Matthai who is in charge of the Railways is helpless.
('98', 80, 3, 34, 179354) He says all the wagons are already in use and are being fully utilized.
('98', 80, 3, 35, 179426) Then there is a shortage of coal and iron and of staff.
('98', 80, 3, 36, 179482) Also the producers of sugar keep on raising prices and after all it cannot be carried on one’s head.
('98', 80, 3, 37, 179583) But though there is a shortage of railway wagons there is motor transport.
('98', 80, 3, 38, 179658) A motor truck runs as fast as a train and it does not require steel rails
('98', 81, 0, 1, 179732) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 81, 1, 2, 179773) on which to ply.
('98', 81, 1, 3, 179790) But motor transport requires petrol and petrol is still a controlled article.
('98', 81, 1, 4, 179868) If the control over petrol is lifted the trucks and lorries will start plying more easily and haul goods from one place to another.
('98', 81, 1, 5, 180000) The movement of salt can also become more smooth.
('98', 81, 1, 6, 180050) It is paradoxical that we produce so much salt and there is no tax on it any more, and yet it is so costly.
('98', 81, 1, 7, 180158) That is because supplies do not arrive.
('98', 81, 1, 8, 180198) In my view it has been a mistake to appoint contractors for producing and supplying salt.
('98', 81, 1, 9, 180288) If petrol is decontrolled trucks can be used for carrying salt and several other things.
('98', 81, 1, 10, 180377) It does not seem right to decontrol certain articles and continue control over others.
('98', 81, 1, 11, 180464) When we have adopted decontrol as a policy we must pursue it fully and see what happens.
('98', 81, 1, 12, 180553) You cannot say there is no petrol in the market.
('98', 81, 1, 13, 180602) Black market is flourishing in petrol and it will continue to flourish so long as the control over it is not lifted.
('98', 81, 1, 14, 180719) I am told that corruption has also increased, that it is necessary to grease the palm of the petroleum officer and it is not a question of a rupee or two but of hundreds of rupees.
('98', 81, 1, 15, 180900) Petrol is required only by those who run motor transport.
('98', 81, 1, 16, 180958) The Government should retain what petrol it needs for itself and release the rest to be sold in the open market.
('98', 81, 1, 17, 181071) Of course even if petrol should become virtually extinct and trains should become immobilized, the country’s affairs will not stop.
('98', 81, 1, 18, 181203) Only the mode of transport will be changed.
('98', 81, 1, 19, 181247) We will revert to old ways.
('98', 81, 1, 20, 181275) I have therefore no fears from the control over petrol being lifted.
('98', 81, 1, 21, 181344) We do not produce enough foodgrain for ourselves.
('98', 81, 1, 22, 181394) We may tell people to cultivate whatever land they have but for this one is told that fertilizers are required for the import of which we have to spend crores of rupees.
('98', 81, 1, 23, 181564) The fertilizers cause erosion of the soil.
('98', 81, 1, 24, 181607) This is not what I say.
('98', 81, 1, 25, 181631) It is what those who know the subject say.
('98', 81, 1, 26, 181674) Mirabehn has been doing this work.
('98', 81, 1, 27, 181709) She convened a conference of experts.
('98', 81, 1, 28, 181747) 1 Some very important people were with her in this.
('98', 81, 1, 29, 181799) There was Rajendra Babu and Sir Datar Singh and various others who know something about the subject.
('98', 81, 1, 30, 181900) The conclusions of the Conference are in the newspapers.
('98', 81, 1, 31, 181957) It recommended ways to make compost and what is called organic manure.
('98', 81, 1, 32, 182028) We have dung in plenty; then there is also human faeces which can make very good manure.
('98', 81, 1, 33, 182117) After it is converted into compost nobody can say how it was made.
('98', 81, 1, 34, 182184) If you take it in hand it has a pleasant smell, not an unpleasant one.
('98', 81, 1, 35, 182255) In making compost they also mix grass, leaves and other farmyard waste with the dung and in time
('98', 81, 2, 36, 182352) 1 The All India Compost Conference; vide “Compost Manure”, 21 12 1947.
('98', 82, 0, 1, 182423) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 83
('98', 82, 1, 2, 182469) it is converted into very good manure.
('98', 82, 1, 3, 182508) The Conference also passed many resolutions but the substance was that we should all work hard at agriculture and grow four maunds where only one maund grew before.
('98', 82, 1, 4, 182673) Mirabehn has left today.
('98', 82, 1, 5, 182698) She lives in Rishikesh near Hardwar.
('98', 82, 1, 6, 182735) She intends to carry on this work there.

('98', 83, 1, 2, 184189) 67. FRAGMENT OF A LETTER
('98', 83, 2, 3, 184214) December 20, 1947
('98', 83, 3, 4, 184232) I am now an old man; and maybe the country is experiencing, in your sense, the surge of freedom.
('98', 83, 3, 5, 184329) I do not see the joy of it on any face.
('98', 83, 3, 6, 184369) It may be that since I myself feel no joy my eyes cannot see any.
('98', 83, 3, 7, 184435) Does not a jaundiced person see only yellow?

('98', 85, 4, 13, 189429) 69. LAWS OF HEALTH
('98', 85, 5, 14, 189448) Shri Brijlal Nehru, himself a faddist like me, has written to the Press belauding the statement of the Minister of Health that “a very great deal of our ill health is due to our own fault” and saying that there is to his knowledge no governmental agency responsible for removing this fault.
('98', 85, 5, 15, 189739) He adds:
('98', 85, 6, 16, 189748) The attention of our Health Minister has so far been confined to the establishment of hospitals, sanatoria, clinics, dispensaries, etc., i.e., devices for the treatment of disease; no institutions have been founded for the prevention of disease by bringing home to the people the need of correct living and the methods of doing so.
('98', 85, 6, 17, 190080) He then goes on to suggest that a separate branch be established to attend to the promotion of health as distinguished from treatment of disease.
('98', 85, 6, 18, 190226) This agency may be given the assistance of an advisory body of both experts and laymen so that the experts may devise their schemes with the full knowledge of the requirements of the people and the limitations under which they have to live and work.
('98', 85, 6, 19, 190476) Why does this fellow faddist want a separate branch for this very necessary purpose?
('98', 85, 6, 20, 190561) This was the fashion under the old regime which went on piling expenditure on expenditure and deluded itself and the gullible public that the greater the expense the greater the utility.
('98', 85, 6, 21, 190748) I would have the Minister of Health require the doctors under her and the other staff understand that their first care must be the attainment
('98', 86, 0, 1, 190890) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 87
('98', 86, 1, 2, 190936) and preservation of the health of the public whom they are paid to serve.
('98', 86, 1, 3, 191010) As a preliminary step the writer
('98', 86, 2, 4, 191043) would have the production of a book on health laws and correct living in the conditions prevailing in India.
('98', 86, 2, 5, 191152) To carry weight with the public, the book must be brought out under the authority of the Health Ministry of the Government of India.
('98', 86, 2, 6, 191285) 1 The duty of writing such a book may be entrusted to the Indian Medical Association, who should be required to produce it within a stated time.
('98', 86, 2, 7, 191430) A transfer of emphasis from disease to health in the teaching given in our medical colleges would in itself be most desirable.
('98', 86, 2, 8, 191557) Indeed, the teaching of the laws of health should be obligatory in all schools and colleges.
('98', 86, 2, 9, 191650) If the treatise recommended by Shri Brijlal Nehru is brought out, I hope the authors would be instructed to avoid the introduction of disease under the guise of preserving health such as the craze for various inoculations.
('98', 86, 2, 10, 191873) NEW DELHI, December 21, 1947

('98', 86, 5, 13, 191943) An All India Compost Conference was held in New Delhi during the month to consider the question of compost development on the widest scale possible.
('98', 86, 5, 14, 192092) It was the conception of Shrimati Mirabehn and was presided over by Dr. Rajendra Prasad.
('98', 86, 5, 15, 192181) Sardar Datar Singh, Dr. Acharya and other eminent men in the line took part in it.
('98', 86, 5, 16, 192264) Several important resolutions were passed by it on schemes for towns and villages.
('98', 86, 5, 17, 192347) A subcommittee consisting of Shrimati Mirabehn, Shri Shivakumar Sharma, Dr. B. N. Lal and Dr. K. G. Joshi (with Dr. B. N. Lal as convener) was appointed to prepare a skeleton scheme for the provinces.
('98', 86, 5, 18, 192548) The resolutions emphasized the necessity of “the agricul tural utilization of town sewage, sullage and sludge, the utilization of the by products of the slaughter house and other trade wastes (for example, wool waste, mill waste, leather waste, etc.) and for the composting of other materials like waterhyacinth, cane trash, press mud, forest leaves, etc.” These resolutions are good and useful if they do not remain

('98', 87, 3, 12, 193849) 71. COMPOST MANURE
('98', 87, 4, 13, 193868) Manure may be described as of two kinds: chemical and organic.
('98', 87, 4, 14, 193931) One might ask how manure could be organic?
('98', 87, 4, 15, 193974) The word “organic” is from English.
('98', 87, 4, 16, 194010) Organic manure is made from human and animal excreta mixed or not mixed with grass, leaves and other such things.
('98', 87, 4, 17, 194124) We do not regard plants as lifeless but we do regard iron, etc., to be so.
('98', 87, 4, 18, 194199) Manure formed from such mixture is called “compost” in English.
('98', 87, 4, 19, 194263) I consider such manure as valuable as gold.
('98', 87, 4, 20, 194307) It keeps the soil ever fertile.
('98', 87, 4, 21, 194339) It does not erode the soil and make it barren.
('98', 87, 4, 22, 194386) It is said that chemical fertilizers destroy the humus of the soil as also bacteria and makes it necessary to keep the soil fallow after every few years of cultivation.
('98', 87, 4, 23, 194555) Moreover organic manure prevents the breeding of pests.
('98', 87, 4, 24, 194611) Under Mirabehn’s inspiration and through her efforts a Conference was called in Delhi this month to popularize such manure among the people.
('98', 87, 4, 25, 194752) It was presided over by Dr. Rajendra Prasad.
('98', 87, 4, 26, 194797) It was attended by Sardar Datar Singh, Dr. Acharya and others who are experts in this field.
('98', 87, 4, 27, 194890) After three days of deliberation they passed several important resolutions.
('98', 87, 4, 28, 194966) In these resolutions they have pointed out what should be done in cities and in the seven lakh villages.
('98', 87, 4, 29, 195071) The Conference has suggested the method of mixing human and animal excreta, garbage, rags and factory waste, in rural and urban areas.
('98', 87, 4, 30, 195206) For this purpose a small sub committee has been formed.
('98', 87, 4, 31, 195262) The face of India will change if the resolutions do not remain on paper and crores of people put them into actual practice.
('98', 87, 4, 32, 195386) We will
('98', 88, 0, 1, 195394) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 89
('98', 88, 1, 2, 195440) be then able to save golden manure worth crores of rupees which is being wasted because of our ignorance.
('98', 88, 1, 3, 195546) The soil will become fertile and we will get better crops than what we are getting.
('98', 88, 1, 4, 195630) As a result we will be rid of famines, crores of people will get enough to eat and the surplus can be exported.
('98', 88, 1, 5, 195742) Today our crops are in the same poor condition as our men and animals.
('98', 88, 1, 6, 195813) The fault is not of the soil but of the people.
('98', 88, 1, 7, 195861) The worms of lethargy and ignorance are eating into us.
('98', 88, 1, 8, 195917) The task undertaken by Mirabehn is of immense magnitude.
('98', 88, 1, 9, 195974) It will require thousands of Mirabehns.
('98', 88, 1, 10, 196014) People should take up the work with zest and Government departments should be awake.
('98', 88, 1, 11, 196099) Merely a few volunteers will not be able to do the work which requires crores of men.
('98', 88, 1, 12, 196185) We should have an army of volunteers.
('98', 88, 1, 13, 196223) Is India so fortunate?
('98', 88, 1, 14, 196246) Here India means both the parts.
('98', 88, 1, 15, 196279) If the southern part takes up the work one may be sure the northern part will also take it up.
('98', 88, 2, 16, 196374) NEW DELHI, December 21, 1947
('98', 88, 3, 17, 196403) [From Gujarati]

('98', 90, 4, 7, 199023) 75. NOTES
('98', 90, 5, 8, 199033) A WORTHY EXAMPLE
('98', 90, 6, 9, 199050) Shri Dilkhush Divanji of Karadi fame reports the glorious death at his post of one of his staunch workers.
('98', 90, 6, 10, 199157) The late Valjibhai was the nephew of Panchakaka, the famous farmer of Karadi, who took part in the no tax campaign of Bardoli 1. He never wavered.
('98', 90, 6, 11, 199304) He refuses even now to till his land or to pay the tax.
('98', 90, 6, 12, 199360) He rightly says that there is no swaraj of his dream so long as we need the police to guard our homes and the military to protect us from ourselves.
('98', 90, 6, 13, 199509) The deceased left a lucrative job and purely from a patriotic motive became a weaver.
('98', 90, 6, 14, 199595) He proved worthy of his uncle and died in harness.
('98', 90, 6, 15, 199646) No man can wish for a nobler death than Valjibhai’s.
('98', 90, 6, 16, 199699) It is to be wished that the weavers who were trained by him would multiply themselves.
('98', 90, 6, 17, 199786) If India is to come to her own, she needs thousands of weavers who will weave nothing but hand spun yarn and expects every man and woman and child above six years to spin good yarn daily for at least half an hour.
('98', 90, 6, 18, 200000) Such is Divanji’s’ dream and Valjibhai died for its realization.

('98', 90, 8, 23, 200516) I have always held that whatever may be said in favour of cash payment of taxes, its introduction injured the nation to the extent that the system of stocking grain in the villages was disturbed.
('98', 90, 8, 24, 200712) The conservation of’ grain in the villages is needed for the reason already mentioned.
('98', 90, 8, 25, 200799) The condition always must be that the growers and dealers

('98', 91, 1, 2, 200956) must not be greedy or unscrupulous.

('98', 91, 2, 5, 201267) THE GATES OF SOMNATH?

('98', 91, 3, 7, 201406) The curious must see the original.

('98', 91, 5, 13, 201869) 76. NEED FOR STORING GRAIN IN VILLAGES
('98', 91, 6, 14, 201908) Shri Vaikunthbhai writes:
('98', 91, 7, 15, 201934) Under the present trading system the grain produced in the villages is being sent out.
('98', 91, 7, 16, 202021) Therefore in many parts of the country the villages are left with no stocks of grain.
('98', 91, 7, 17, 202107) As a result the poor have to face hardships and there is a steep rise in prices during the monsoon.
('98', 91, 7, 18, 202207) To save the poor from such a plight, it is desirable that some grain should be stocked in villages under the care of the Panch, and only the surplus should be sent out.
('98', 91, 7, 19, 202376) With this end in view Shri Achyut Rao Patwardhan and I had prepared a scheme four years ago.
('98', 91, 7, 20, 202469) Shri Kumarappa has also acknowledged the need for such a scheme in his plan.
('98', 91, 8, 21, 202546) If the scheme meets with your approval, under the present changed circumstances you may kindly recommend it to the Provincial Governments and the villagers.
('98', 91, 8, 22, 202703) I think the suggestion has something in it.
('98', 91, 8, 23, 202747) Such stocks are necessary in the economic conditions of the country.
('98', 91, 8, 24, 202816) Ever since the system of collecting revenue in cash was introduced, the stocks of grain in the villages have diminished.
('98', 91, 8, 25, 202937) I shall not go into the merits or
('98', 91, 9, 26, 202971) 1 Which appeared in Harijan Sevak, 28 12 1947, under the title “Somnathka Mandir”
('98', 92, 0, 1, 203053) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 93
('98', 92, 1, 2, 203099) demerits of the cash revenue system; but I do believe the country could have been saved from the present difficult situation if we had continued to stock grain in the villages.
('98', 92, 1, 3, 203276) Now that the controls are being removed no one will suffer any hardship if the grain is stocked as suggested by Vaikunthbhai and if the villagers and the traders become honest.
('98', 92, 1, 4, 203453) If the farmers and the traders get a fair margin of profit there can be no high prices for the working class and other people in the cities.
('98', 92, 1, 5, 203594) What really matters is that necessaries of life should be within the reach of every one.
('98', 92, 1, 6, 203683) There can then be no question of high or low prices.

('98', 97, 6, 10, 211090) 88. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('98', 97, 7, 11, 211121) NEW DELHI, December 22, 1947
('98', 97, 8, 12, 211150) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Some eight or ten miles from here, at Mehrauli, there is a shrine of Qutubuddin Bakhtiyar Chisti.
('98', 97, 8, 13, 211270) Esteemed as second only to the shrine at Ajmer, it is visited every year not only by Muslims but by thousands of non Muslims too.
('98', 97, 8, 14, 211400) Last September this shrine was subjected to the wrath of Hindu mobs.
('98', 97, 8, 15, 211469) The Muslims living in the vicinity of the shrine for the last 800 years had to leave their homes.
('98', 97, 8, 16, 211567) I mention this sad episode to tell you that, though Muslims love the shrine, today no Muslim can be found anywhere near it.
('98', 97, 8, 17, 211691) It is the duty of the Hindus, Sikhs, the officials and the Government to open the shrine again and wash off this stain on us.
('98', 97, 8, 18, 211817) The same applies to other shrines and religious places of Muslims in and around Delhi.
('98', 97, 8, 19, 211904) The time has come when both India and Pakistan must unequivocally declare to the majorities in each country that they will not tolerate desecration of religious places, be they small or big.
('98', 97, 8, 20, 212095) They should also undertake to

('98', 98, 0, 1, 212196) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 99
('98', 98, 1, 2, 212242) repair the places damaged during riots.
('98', 98, 1, 3, 212282) Muslims have asked me whether, in view of the decision of the Muslim League in Karachi 1, members of the Muslim League should take part in the Conference called by Maulana Azad in Lucknow 2 and also whether Muslims might participate in the Conference of the Muslim League in Madras, and in any case what should be the course to be adopted by the members of the Muslim League in India.
('98', 98, 1, 4, 212667) I have not the least doubt that if they receive a personal or public invitation they should attend the Conferences in Lucknow and Madras.
('98', 98, 1, 5, 212805) They should fearlessly and openly declare their views at these meetings.
('98', 98, 1, 6, 212878) If they have learnt anything from the 30 years of non violent struggle they should not worry that they are in a minority in the Indian Union and that the majority in Pakistan can be of no help to them.
('98', 98, 1, 7, 213080) It does not need belief in non violence to see that a minority however small it may be has no reason to feel afraid for its honour and for the things it holds dear.
('98', 98, 1, 8, 213245) If man could but know his Maker and realize that he himself is a reflection of that Maker, no power on earth can take away his self respect.
('98', 98, 1, 9, 213386) No one can take away my self respect; I can only lose it.
('98', 98, 1, 10, 213444) During my struggle against the mighty Government of the Transvaal, a dear English friend of mine in Johannesburg used to tell me, “I always like to be with a minority, for a minority as a rule does not commit mistakes, and even if it does it can be rectified.
('98', 98, 1, 11, 213704) But a majority is drunk with power and it is difficult to reform it.” If by majority the friend also meant one sided armed might he was right.
('98', 98, 1, 12, 213847) We know from bitter experience how a handful of Englishmen had transformed themselves into a majority through force of arms and how they dominated the whole of India.
('98', 98, 1, 13, 214014) India lacked arms and, even if the arms had been there, we did not know how to use them.
('98', 98, 1, 14, 214103) It is a matter of regret that Hindus and Sikhs have not learnt a lesson from the British rule in our country.
('98', 98, 1, 15, 214213) The Muslims of the Union suffered from false pride in their majority in the East and the West.
('98', 98, 1, 16, 214308) Today they are rid of that burden.
('98', 98, 1, 17, 214343) If they now see the virtues of being a minority they will show the beauties of Islam in their own way.
('98', 98, 1, 18, 214446) They must
('98', 98, 2, 19, 214456) 1 The Council of the All India Muslim League had passed a resolution in Karachi on December 15, bifurcating the Muslim League into two bodies —one for Pakistan and the other for India.
('98', 98, 2, 20, 214641) 2 The Indian Union Muslims’ Conference was scheduled to be held in Lucknow on December 27 and 28 under the presidentship of Abul Kalam Azad.
('98', 98, 2, 21, 214782) Members of the Provincial Assemblies, the Constituent Assembly and various Muslim organizations had been invited to attend it.

('98', 99, 1, 2, 214951) remember that the best days of Islam were the days of the Prophet Mohammed’s minority in Mecca.
('98', 99, 1, 3, 215047) Christianity began to decline after the time of Constantine 1. I do not want to prolong the argument here.
('98', 99, 1, 4, 215154) My advice emanates from my faith and if Muslim friends do not have this faith they are free to reject it.
('98', 99, 1, 5, 215260) In my view they should all be prepared to join the Congress.
('98', 99, 1, 6, 215321) But they must not apply for entry into that body till they are sure of a hearty welcome and equality of treatment.
('98', 99, 1, 7, 215436) In principle there is no question of majority and minority so far as the Congress is concerned.
('98', 99, 1, 8, 215532) The Congress follows no religion unless it be a religion of humanity.
('98', 99, 1, 9, 215602) It treats men and women alike.
('98', 99, 1, 10, 215633) It is a purely political body in which Sikhs, Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Parsees and Jews are all equal.
('98', 99, 1, 11, 215740) The Congress has not always been able to practise what it preached.
('98', 99, 1, 12, 215808) This sometimes created an impression among the Muslims that it was a caste Hindu organization.
('98', 99, 1, 13, 215903) In any case as long as this kind of tug of war goes on Muslims should keep away with dignity.
('98', 99, 1, 14, 215997) When the Congress wants their services they should come into the Congress.
('98', 99, 1, 15, 216072) Till then they can be servants of the Congress as I am a servant of the Congress.
('98', 99, 1, 16, 216154) Although I am not a four anna member of the Congress I have a voice in that organization, and that is because ever since 1915 when I returned from South Africa I have been loyally serving the Congress.
('98', 99, 1, 17, 216356) If every Muslim similarly serves the Congress he will find that his services are similarly appreciated.
('98', 99, 1, 18, 216460) Today every Muslim is considered a supporter of the League and therefore an enemy of the Congress.
('98', 99, 1, 19, 216559) This has been the unfortunate result of the teachings of the League.
('98', 99, 1, 20, 216628) Today there is no cause left any more for enmity.
('98', 99, 1, 21, 216678) Four months are a very short time for getting rid of the poison of communalism.
('98', 99, 1, 22, 216758) It is the misfortune of India that Hindus and Sikhs took this poison to be nectar and made themselves the enemies of the Muslim League.
('98', 99, 1, 23, 216894) In returning brickbat for brickbat they brought a stain to their name and put themselves in the same category as Muslims.
('98', 99, 1, 24, 217016) I appeal to the Muslim minority to raise themselves above this poisonous atmosphere, to remove the suspicion that had been created concerning them and to show that they could live in India as her honourable citizens without any deceit and dissimulation.
('98', 99, 1, 25, 217270) One consequence of partition is that the League cannot continue
('98', 99, 2, 26, 217334) 1 Emperor of Rome (306 A. D. to 337 A. D.) who made Christianity the State religion

('98', 100, 1, 2, 217465) as a political organization.
('98', 100, 1, 3, 217494) The Hindu Mahasabha, the Sikh Sabha and the Parsee Sabha similarly cannot continue as political bodies.
('98', 100, 1, 4, 217598) They may well stay as religious bodies.
('98', 100, 1, 5, 217638) Their task then will be internal reform of society, to seareh for things of religious value and to act on them.
('98', 100, 1, 6, 217750) Then the atmosphere will become free of poison and these organizations will rival each other in doing good.
('98', 100, 1, 7, 217858) They will have amity for each other and they will help the Government.
('98', 100, 1, 8, 217929) Their political ambitions can be realized through the Congress alone whether they are in the Congress or not.
('98', 100, 1, 9, 218039) If the Congress thinks only of those who are in the Congress it will become very narrow in its sphere of service.
('98', 100, 1, 10, 218153) Even today there are very few people in the Congress.
('98', 100, 1, 11, 218207) If no other organization can rival the Congress it is because the Congress has been trying to represent the whole of India, because it has dedicated itself to the service of the poorest and the lowliest.

('98', 103, 1, 2, 222102) 94. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 103, 2, 3, 222131) NEW DELHI, December 23, 1947
('98', 103, 3, 4, 222160) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, A friend suggests that since it is getting cold we should begin our prayer half an hour earlier, that is, at 5 p.
('98', 103, 3, 5, 222296) I admit it is getting to be pretty cold.
('98', 103, 3, 6, 222337) Though the days will be getting longer minute by minute from now on, for today it is already the 23rd of December, still if all of you so wish we can begin the prayer at 5 p.m.
('98', 103, 3, 7, 222514) from tomorrow.
('98', 103, 3, 8, 222529) 1 Today I shall deal with three points.
('98', 103, 3, 9, 222569) Here is the first.
('98', 103, 3, 10, 222588) You saw that yesterday people 2 arrived here from Bahawalpur.
('98', 103, 3, 11, 222650) They are in great distress.
('98', 103, 3, 12, 222678) 3 They say that all the Hindus and Sikhs there should be brought here for their lives are in danger.
('98', 103, 3, 13, 222779) Today two friends from Bahawalpur came to see me.
('98', 103, 3, 14, 222829) They said that if no steps were taken in this respect they would go and fast in front of the Governor General’s house.
('98', 103, 3, 15, 222948) I told them that their fasting could neither bring here the Hindus and Sikhs left behind nor ensure their safety.
('98', 103, 3, 16, 223062) That besides the Governor General had no power except such as he derived from his Cabinet.
('98', 103, 3, 17, 223153) He merely affixed his signature.
('98', 103, 3, 18, 223186) If they thought that fasting before the residence of Pandit Nehru or the Sardar would do any good they were equally mistaken.
('98', 103, 3, 19, 223312) They saw the point and gave up the idea of fasting.
('98', 103, 3, 20, 223364) Yesterday I was observing silence and so could not say anything.
('98', 103, 3, 21, 223429) The Nawab of Bahawalpur should permit all the Hindus and Sikhs to go wherever they want to.
('98', 103, 3, 22, 223521) If he does not he will be failing in his duty.
('98', 103, 3, 23, 223568) I cannot relate to you the things that have happened there under the very nose of the Nawab.
('98', 103, 3, 24, 223661) A large number of Hindus and Sikhs were tortured and killed.
('98', 103, 3, 25, 223722) It is the Sikhs who built Bahawalpur.
('98', 103, 3, 26, 223760) They are a brave people.
('98', 103, 3, 27, 223785) They can fight and cultivate land.
('98', 103, 3, 28, 223820) They have been cultivating the land
('98', 103, 4, 29, 223856) 1 Gandhiji asked those who wanted the prayers to be held earlier to raise their hands.
('98', 103, 4, 30, 223943) A large number of them raised their hands.
('98', 103, 4, 31, 223986) It was, therefore, decided to hold the prayers at 5 p.
('98', 103, 4, 32, 224041) 2 Who carried placards reading “Save the 70,000 Hindus and Sikhs of Bahawalpur” 3 In the State of Bahawalpur, which had acceded to Pakistan on November 8, seventy thousand Hindus and Sikhs were awaiting evacuation.
('98', 103, 4, 33, 224256) It was reported that the Pakistan authorities were not agreeing to their evacuation through the Military Evacuation Organization.
('98', 103, 4, 34, 224386) The Hindus and Sikhs concentrated in camps were without adequate food or clothing.
('98', 104, 0, 1, 224469) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 105
('98', 104, 1, 2, 224516) there; so have the Hindus.
('98', 104, 1, 3, 224543) They have committed no crime.
('98', 104, 1, 4, 224573) Their only crime is that they are Hindus or Sikhs.
('98', 104, 1, 5, 224624) A large number of these innocent people were murdered and some ran away.
('98', 104, 1, 6, 224697) When Hindus and Sikhs cannot live there in peace, what is the worth of anything that the Nawab may say?
('98', 104, 1, 7, 224801) I appeal to the Nawab that he should do his duty.
('98', 104, 1, 8, 224851) If Hindus and Sikhs cannot live there in honour he should arrange for them to leave or he should declare that none of the Hindus and Sikhs still in Bahawalpur will be touched and that they can continue to live in Bahawalpur in peace.
('98', 104, 1, 9, 225085) If they are starving, food should be made available to them.
('98', 104, 1, 10, 225146) According to a report in today’s Statesman about the refugee camps in Lahore, the Muslims in the camps are living in insanitary conditions.
('98', 104, 1, 11, 225286) Epidemics like cholera and smallpox have broken out and even those who have escaped them are dying of cold and exposure.
('98', 104, 1, 12, 225407) How can people live under the open sky in this cold?
('98', 104, 1, 13, 225460) They need shelter and clothes and food.
('98', 104, 1, 14, 225500) If these three things are not available they must face death.
('98', 104, 1, 15, 225562) I do not know all that is happening there.
('98', 104, 1, 16, 225605) Yes, scavengers have been brought over from Sialkot who will clean the camps and remove nightsoil.
('98', 104, 1, 17, 225704) The officials say that they are not doing enough work.
('98', 104, 1, 18, 225759) It is clear that the people there are in distress.
('98', 104, 1, 19, 225810) What does it matter that they are in Pakistan?
('98', 104, 1, 20, 225857) Why should human beings be so degraded?
('98', 104, 1, 21, 225897) It pains me.
('98', 104, 1, 22, 225910) Those people who ran away from here to escape our excesses were deprived of their hearths and homes.
('98', 104, 1, 23, 226011) They are not familiar with the surroundings there and they have to suffer hardships.
('98', 104, 1, 24, 226096) But why can’t they keep themselves clean?
('98', 104, 1, 25, 226138) I should advise all the refugees, be they in India or in Pakistan, that they should not be dependent on others for everything.
('98', 104, 1, 26, 226265) They should not ask for help to cook for them or to remove their night soil.
('98', 104, 1, 27, 226342) People who were being uprooted from their homes are in no position to make such demands.
('98', 104, 1, 28, 226431) It’s a privilege of the rich.
('98', 104, 1, 29, 226461) They may employ ten when one is enough, but not we.
('98', 104, 1, 30, 226513) These are the symptoms of our degradation.
('98', 104, 1, 31, 226556) The refugees in the camps in Lahore should firmly and courageously declare that they will not have scavengers from Sialkot, that they will themselves do the cleaning of their camps.
('98', 104, 1, 32, 226738) The Pakistan Government and the officials concerned should also make it clear to the refugees that they will not have scavengers brought from Sialkot.
('98', 104, 1, 33, 226889) They should at least do what every human being can do.
('98', 104, 1, 34, 226944) And if even then there are deaths, that will be a different matter.
('98', 104, 1, 35, 227012) I have said it before, and I say it again, that the refugees should conduct themselves with decency.
('98', 104, 1, 36, 227113) They should do all that they can do and not become a burden on others.

('98', 105, 1, 15, 228195) The officials too co operated.

('98', 107, 1, 2, 230393) 98. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 107, 2, 3, 230422) NEW DELHI, December 24, 1947
('98', 107, 3, 4, 230451) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I often receive Sikh visitors.
('98', 107, 3, 5, 230504) I also read newspapers sometimes.
('98', 107, 3, 6, 230538) They say that I have proved an enemy of the Sikhs.
('98', 107, 3, 7, 230589) They would not have minded it much but for the fact that my word seemed to carry weight with the world outside India where it is believed that India has secured its freedom through non violent means.
('98', 107, 3, 8, 230789) This had never happened before anywhere in the world.
('98', 107, 3, 9, 230843) But a tree is known by its fruit, and by no other means.
('98', 107, 3, 10, 230900) For man is not God, man can know a thing from its results.
('98', 107, 3, 11, 230959) The fruit of independence has been that today Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs have become one another’s enemies.
('98', 107, 3, 12, 231066) As I have admitted earlier I had been under the delusion that our struggle was truly non violent.
('98', 107, 3, 13, 231164) God had rendered me blind and I was misled.
('98', 107, 3, 14, 231208) Because the lame, the crippled, the coward cannot be non violent.
('98', 107, 3, 15, 231274) Lame, crippled and dumb I do not mean literally, for God helps these and they are always non violent.
('98', 107, 3, 16, 231376) Even a child can stand before the world on the strength of non violence.
('98', 107, 3, 17, 231449) Prahlad was an instance.
('98', 107, 3, 18, 231474) We do not know whether Prahlad was a historical character.
('98', 107, 3, 19, 231533) To me he was more than a historical character, for I believe in the story.
('98', 107, 3, 20, 231608) Prahlad’s father 1 commanded him not to utter the name of God.
('98', 107, 3, 21, 231671) But Prahlad insisted that he would continue to utter the name of God.
('98', 107, 3, 22, 231741) The image of 12 year old Prahlad remains before my eyes.
('98', 107, 3, 23, 231798) Therefore I say that those who are lame and crippled at heart can never be truly non violent.
('98', 107, 3, 24, 231892) So long as the light does not shine in the heart no one can understand the beauty of non violence.
('98', 107, 3, 25, 231991) What we offered during the struggle was passive resistance which simply meant that we would not kill the British though in our hearts we wanted to kill them.
('98', 107, 3, 26, 232149) But we had not the power.
('98', 107, 3, 27, 232175) When the millions took up passive resistance it did bring about our freedom.
('98', 107, 3, 28, 232252) The freedom we have obtained is crippled freedom.
('98', 107, 3, 29, 232302) It is only partial.
('98', 107, 3, 30, 232322) I therefore laugh when I see our Sikh brethren getting angry.
('98', 107, 3, 31, 232384) In my eyes there is no difference between the Hindus and the Sikhs.
('98', 107, 3, 32, 232452) I have read the
('98', 107, 4, 33, 232468) 1 Hiranyakashipu, the Demon king
('98', 108, 0, 1, 232501) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 109
('98', 108, 1, 2, 232548) Granthsaheb.
('98', 108, 1, 3, 232561) A friend chides me for not knowing anything about the Granthsaheb.
('98', 108, 1, 4, 232628) He says I cannot understand the Sikhs and that if I did, I would not have written what I wrote about Guru Govind Singh.
('98', 108, 1, 5, 232748) That was many years ago and the mistake was not mine.
('98', 108, 1, 6, 232802) But he still says so because he is a friend.
('98', 108, 1, 7, 232847) If I say that the Sikhs are taking to drinking and gambling it does not mean that it applies to all or only to Sikhs.
('98', 108, 1, 8, 232965) Hindus too are a prey to these evils but Hindus do not have the strength that the Sikhs have.
('98', 108, 1, 9, 233059) The Sikhs should not use that strength indiscriminately.
('98', 108, 1, 10, 233116) They may wield the sword but only where they must.
('98', 108, 1, 11, 233167) Their sword should not fall where it ought not to fall.
('98', 108, 1, 12, 233223) I am a true friend of the Sikhs when I say that anyone who commits crimes or is guilty of bad conduct sins before God.
('98', 108, 1, 13, 233342) He degrades his religion.
('98', 108, 1, 14, 233368) Today is the 24th.
('98', 108, 1, 15, 233387) Tomorrow is Christmas.
('98', 108, 1, 16, 233410) Christmas is to Christians what Diwali is to us.
('98', 108, 1, 17, 233459) Really neither Diwali nor Christmas is an occasion when we should indulge in revelry and lose our heads.
('98', 108, 1, 18, 233564) I do not regard Christmas as an occasion for people to indulge in drunkenness.
('98', 108, 1, 19, 233643) Christmas reminds one of Jesus Christ.
('98', 108, 1, 20, 233682) I offer greetings to the Christians in India and abroad.
('98', 108, 1, 21, 233739) May the New Year bring them prosperity and happiness.
('98', 108, 1, 22, 233793) It has never been my wish that the freedom of India should mean the ruin of the Christians here or that they should become Hindus or Muslims or Sikhs.
('98', 108, 1, 23, 233944) For a Christian to become a Hindu or a Muslim is a fate worse than death.
('98', 108, 1, 24, 234018) According to my view a Christian should become a better Christian, a Muslim a better Muslim and a Sikh a better Sikh.
('98', 108, 1, 25, 234136) I want that all the Christians in and outside India should become free in the true sense.
('98', 108, 1, 26, 234226) Let them exercise self restraint and pursue the path of sacrifice and martyrdom shown by Jesus Christ.
('98', 108, 1, 27, 234329) Let them be free and increase the area of freedom in the world.
('98', 108, 1, 28, 234393) I see from the papers that the Government proposes to stop the grants made to them.
('98', 108, 1, 29, 234477) The money they receive from America and England will also stop coming.
('98', 108, 1, 30, 234548) It is feared that 75% of the churches in India will have to be closed down.
('98', 108, 1, 31, 234624) But a religion does not prosper with the help of money.
('98', 108, 1, 32, 234680) Most Christians in India are poor people.
('98', 108, 1, 33, 234722) What does it matter if the Government help should stop?
('98', 108, 1, 34, 234778) They should be glad that they will now be free of the curse of pecuniary assistance.
('98', 108, 1, 35, 234863) once a lot of money and presents came into the house of Hazarat Omar.
('98', 108, 1, 36, 234933) This worried Omar and he told his wife that with all that wealth he was no longer certain if he would be able to retain his self control and would not take to pleasure.
('98', 108, 1, 37, 235102) A church does not need a building.
('98', 108, 1, 38, 235137) The human body is the real church.
('98', 108, 1, 39, 235172) It is there that God dwells.
('98', 108, 1, 40, 235201) Then we have the sky for the roof and the
('98', 109, 0, 1, 235243) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 109, 1, 2, 235285) earth for the floor.

('98', 109, 1, 5, 235405) They do not really need assistance from the Government or anyone.
('98', 109, 1, 6, 235471) They should follow the teachings of their religion.
('98', 109, 1, 7, 235523) If they but persevere in the path of sacrifice shown by Christ, no one can take their religion away from them.

('98', 110, 4, 12, 237546) 101. FRAGMENT OF A LETTER
('98', 110, 5, 13, 237572) December 25, 1947
('98', 110, 6, 14, 237590) Slackness in khadi work will not do.
('98', 110, 6, 15, 237627) We should understand that the more we slacken the more we shall fall behind.
('98', 110, 6, 16, 237704) This fragile thread has had behind it sixty long years of work.
('98', 110, 6, 17, 237768) It still remains unbroken and thanks to it we have reached our present position.
('98', 110, 6, 18, 237849) Even now I am convinced that if only we had plied the wheel more vigourously, the thread would not have broken even as slightly as it has.
('98', 110, 6, 19, 237988) If we do not want to preserve what we have gained, then certainly we may let the thread snap.

('98', 110, 6, 22, 238312) Otherwise your fall will be quick, remember this.

('98', 120, 1, 2, 257343) 113. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 120, 2, 3, 257373) SAMBHAL, December 27, 1947
('98', 120, 3, 4, 257400) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, It gives me special pleasure to hold a prayer meeting in this village.
('98', 120, 3, 5, 257493) You should not thank me or give me an address of welcome or garland me.
('98', 120, 3, 6, 257565) Prayer is our dharma.
('98', 120, 3, 7, 257587) We pray when we get up in the morning.
('98', 120, 3, 8, 257626) We should pray regularly morning and evening.
('98', 120, 3, 9, 257672) In the evening at 5, or earlier in winter, we can have congregational prayer.
('98', 120, 3, 10, 257750) We must utter God’s name when we stand or sleep or eat.
('98', 120, 3, 11, 257806) We must also remember God when at work.
('98', 120, 3, 12, 257846) We should not give ourselves to selfish pursuits.
('98', 120, 3, 13, 257896) We must pursue the path of service.
('98', 120, 3, 14, 257932) I have too little time now to explain to you the whole significance of prayer.
('98', 120, 3, 15, 258011) Though, as I have told you, I want no addresses of welcome and garlands, still since you have given me these I thank you for the honour.
('98', 120, 3, 16, 258148) You speak in your address of the greatness of truth and non violence.
('98', 120, 3, 17, 258218) But if our conduct is not in conformity with truth and non violence, talking of them is hypocritical.
('98', 120, 3, 18, 258320) I do not like this.
('98', 120, 3, 19, 258340) Ever since I came to India from South Africa I had been travelling all over the country.
('98', 120, 3, 20, 258429) I have traversed India many times and seen thousands of villages.
('98', 120, 3, 21, 258495) People talk of truth and non violence but they do not act accordingly.
('98', 120, 3, 22, 258566) They think in one way, speak in another and act in yet another way.
('98', 120, 3, 23, 258634) It is a matter of shame for us that in India Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs should be slaughtering one another.
('98', 120, 3, 24, 258741) Mercifully there have been no riots here in and around your village because the number of Muslims here is small and they can do no harm.
('98', 120, 3, 25, 258878) If we want to behave as enemies of one another, let us at any rate stop talking of ahimsa.
('98', 120, 3, 26, 258969) Let us be truthful to this extent.
('98', 120, 3, 27, 259004) We have not become free in order to slaughter one another.
('98', 120, 3, 28, 259063) Freedom means that we should voluntarily do what is good.
('98', 120, 3, 29, 259121) We have become free to do good, not to do evil.
('98', 120, 3, 30, 259169) We never pray to God to let us utter falsehoods.
('98', 120, 3, 31, 259218) If we do that it would be surrender to Satan.
('98', 120, 3, 32, 259264) It is a good thing you have formed a panchayat.
('98', 120, 3, 33, 259312) But if it does not function properly and is a panchayat only in name, it will do no good.
('98', 120, 3, 34, 259402) In former times there used to be real panchayats in the villages of India.
('98', 120, 3, 35, 259477) Even I have not seen them.
('98', 120, 3, 36, 259504) But travellers from China and Greece have reported about them.
('98', 120, 3, 37, 259567) These travellers were not paid by
('98', 121, 0, 1, 259601) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 121, 1, 2, 259643) anyone.
('98', 121, 1, 3, 259651) They were not even invited.
('98', 121, 1, 4, 259679) They came on their own undergoing great hardships.
('98', 121, 1, 5, 259730) They came in order to gain knowledge.
('98', 121, 1, 6, 259768) They write that there were at the time no thefts anywhere in India; there were no locks on the doors.
('98', 121, 1, 7, 259870) All this was not what happened thousands of years ago.
('98', 121, 1, 8, 259925) Our history does not go back to thousands of years.
('98', 121, 1, 9, 259977) Formerly there were four varnas 1 Today these have grown into a large number.
('98', 121, 1, 10, 260055) It becomes meaningless to call them varnas.
('98', 121, 1, 11, 260099) It is a great responsibility you have assumed in forming a panchayat.
('98', 121, 1, 12, 260169) The cows yield so little milk that many people say that they should be slaughtered.
('98', 121, 1, 13, 260253) Muslims no doubt slaughter cows.
('98', 121, 1, 14, 260286) But no one in the world slaughters as many cows as the Hindus do.
('98', 121, 1, 15, 260352) Hindus do not treat the cows well.
('98', 121, 1, 16, 260387) They do not know how to look after them.
('98', 121, 1, 17, 260428) This amounts to slowly killing the cows.
('98', 121, 1, 18, 260469) It is much better to kill them all at once.
('98', 121, 1, 19, 260513) We worship cows and yet treat them most cruelly.
('98', 121, 1, 20, 260562) I shall say your panchayat has done something if at the end of the year the cows that today give three seers of milk give six.
('98', 121, 1, 21, 260689) Similarly you should produce twice the present amount of foodgrain.
('98', 121, 1, 22, 260757) You can do so by giving to the land the nourishment that it needs.
('98', 121, 1, 23, 260824) Mirabehn had called a conference which was attended by a large number of people.
('98', 121, 1, 24, 260905) They came to the conclusion that all the cow dung, human faeces and vegetable waste available in villages could be turned into rich manure.
('98', 121, 1, 25, 261045) It requires not expenditure but a little labour and it increases the fertility of the soil.
('98', 121, 1, 26, 261137) I do not know how clean you keep your village.
('98', 121, 1, 27, 261184) But it is your paramount duty to make yourselves strong.
('98', 121, 1, 28, 261241) You must keep yourselves clean externally and internally.
('98', 121, 1, 29, 261299) Your village should be free of dirt and dung in every way.
('98', 121, 1, 30, 261358) And it should be free from foul smells.
('98', 121, 1, 31, 261398) You should follow the rules of sanitation.
('98', 121, 1, 32, 261441) Why do you need a cinema here?
('98', 121, 1, 33, 261472) Instead of this, you can perform the various plays and stage dramas known to us.
('98', 121, 1, 34, 261553) The cinema will only make you spend money.
('98', 121, 1, 35, 261596) Then you will also learn to gamble and fall into other evil habits.
('98', 121, 1, 36, 261664) Those addicted to alcohol, ganja 2 and bhang 3 should give up these addictions.
('98', 121, 1, 37, 261744) Then I shall feel that your Panchayat has done some good work.
('98', 121, 1, 38, 261807) Then people will come from Delhi to see your village.
('98', 121, 1, 39, 261861) You must forget untouchability.
('98', 121, 1, 40, 261893) If you will
('98', 121, 2, 41, 261905) 1 Viz., Brahmin, Kshatriya, Vaishya and Shudra 2 Hemp 3 Hemp flowers
('98', 122, 0, 1, 261974) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 123
('98', 122, 1, 2, 262021) realize that Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs and Parsis are all brothers you will show what free India means.
('98', 122, 1, 3, 262122) May God give you the strength to accomplish all this.
('98', 122, 1, 4, 262176) Please do not clap your hands.
('98', 122, 1, 5, 262207) What I have said is a part of the prayer.
('98', 122, 1, 6, 262249) I want your blessings and if you do all that I have told you, you will have given me all I need.

('98', 124, 1, 4, 265406) When ours is a free country, why should we have controls?

('98', 125, 6, 27, 269556) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('98', 125, 7, 28, 269578) Today I was at a meeting of cloth merchants 1, where they told me that cloth too should be decontrolled as so many other things had been.
('98', 125, 7, 29, 269716) I have no doubt that control on cloth should be lifted.
('98', 125, 7, 30, 269772) You will see from the papers what happened at the meeting.

('98', 125, 8, 32, 269919) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('98', 126, 0, 1, 269946) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 127
('98', 126, 1, 2, 269993) the prices of cloth had begun to decline.
('98', 126, 1, 3, 270035) The reason, they say, is that now my voice is raised for decontrol and the Government listens to me, and hence it is expected that cloth will soon be decontrolled.
('98', 126, 1, 4, 270199) This has led to the hoarded cloth being brought out into the open market and so the prices have registered a decline.
('98', 126, 1, 5, 270317) The same was the case with sugar.
('98', 126, 1, 6, 270351) People tell me that wherever one goes one sees large stocks of sugar.
('98', 126, 1, 7, 270421) It is being sold at one rupee a seer.
('98', 126, 1, 8, 270459) I am told that people are even able to bargain and buy it for 15 as.
('98', 126, 1, 9, 270528) or even 14 as.
('98', 126, 1, 10, 270543) I am receiving telegrams from all quarters reporting much relief among people as a consequence of decontrol.
('98', 126, 1, 11, 270652) Blessings are showered on me for having brought about decontrol.

('98', 126, 1, 37, 272122) But laying more railway lines involves expenditure running into crores.
('98', 126, 1, 38, 272194) We must make the best use of what we have.
('98', 126, 1, 39, 272237) We have for the present all the railways we need.

('98', 127, 4, 23, 273899) 119. MATTER WELL PLACED
('98', 127, 5, 24, 273923) Compost is matter well placed, whereas rubbish and excreta, solid and liquid, are matter misplaced when they are allowed to lie anyhow to the discomfort of the public and detriment to their health.
('98', 127, 5, 25, 274121) It is a criminal waste depriving mother earth of her precious food.
('98', 127, 5, 26, 274189) Thus says Shrimati Mirabehn in her leaflet reproduced in full 1 in the Harijan, 23 11 ’47, pp.
('98', 127, 6, 27, 274284) We do not treat our Mother Earth properly.
('98', 127, 6, 28, 274327) She does her best to feed us all, but we do not feed her in return.
('98', 127, 6, 29, 274395) How can she sustain us, her children, if we do not serve her as dutiful children should serve a revered mother?
('98', 127, 6, 30, 274507) Year after year we plough, sow and reap harvests from the fields, but very rarely do we give any manure to the soil, and even what we give is usually half kachcha 2

('98', 128, 5, 6, 275005) 120. “DHAN” OF DUST
('98', 128, 6, 7, 275025) I could have given the heading “Dhan from Dust”.
('98', 128, 6, 8, 275074) But I have chosen “Dhan of Dust”.
('98', 128, 6, 9, 275108) The process of sifting the grains from dust means obtaining dhan from dust.
('98', 128, 6, 10, 275184) Similarly the industrious people of China collect gold dust by washing mud or sand.
('98', 128, 6, 11, 275268) This too I would call dhan from dust.
('98', 128, 6, 12, 275306) This is a transformation of the dust and much more so of the grains.
('98', 128, 6, 13, 275375) Normally we use the term dhan for foodgrain.
('98', 128, 6, 14, 275420) But when we use the word dhan for the grains of gold in dust, is it not a great transformation?
('98', 128, 6, 15, 275516) Here dhan means some useful object whose value can be determined.
('98', 128, 6, 16, 275582) But when we say “wealth of dust” it implies a chemical transformation of dust.
('98', 128, 6, 17, 275661) For instance, when we convert the dust, that is, earth into grains, we have converted the dust into wealth.
('98', 128, 6, 18, 275769) When we sow the seeds in the earth and water them properly, it produces grain.
('98', 128, 6, 19, 275848) I would call this creating dhan from dust.
('98', 128, 6, 20, 275891) Our language has not become precise because we have neglected it.
('98', 128, 6, 21, 275957) Let me now come to the main point.
('98', 128, 6, 22, 275992) I consider “compost” dhan of dust.
('98', 128, 6, 23, 276027) Compost means the gold like manure made from a proper mixture of such matter as cow dung, faeces, droppings of birds and animals, grass, chaff, refuse, urine, etc.
('98', 128, 6, 24, 276191) If we mix such manure with the earth in the field and then sow the seeds, it will yield at least double the crop and yet the soil will not lose its fertility.
('98', 128, 6, 25, 276350) Mirabehn is working hard in this direction.
('98', 128, 6, 26, 276394) She has set up an ashram at Rishikesh.
('98', 128, 6, 27, 276433) There she expects to carry on the work which she had begun in Delhi.
('98', 128, 6, 28, 276502) She has started issuing small pamphlets on this subject.
('98', 128, 6, 29, 276559) These pamphlets can be obtained from her.
('98', 128, 6, 30, 276601) Her pamphlet is published in Urdu.
('98', 128, 6, 31, 276636) She writes it in English as she does not have
('98', 128, 7, 32, 276682) 1 According to a “Note” in Harijan, 8 2 1948, her correct address was: Ashram Pashulok, Rishikesh, Dehradun, U. P.

('98', 129, 4, 6, 276993) 121. “URDU HARIJAN”
('98', 129, 5, 7, 277013) Readers know that two editions of Harijan in identical language are brought out every week—one in the Devanagari script and the other in the Urdu script.
('98', 129, 5, 8, 277167) One which is printed in the Urdu script is called the Urdu Harijan.
('98', 129, 5, 9, 277235) Shri Jivanji writes about its steadily dwindling circulation.
('98', 129, 6, 10, 277297) I have always been of the opinion that no newspaper should be published at a loss.
('98', 129, 6, 11, 277380) People should subscribe to the paper they want.
('98', 129, 6, 12, 277428) I do not regard a journal self supporting which meets its expenses out of advertisements.
('98', 129, 6, 13, 277518) I allowed the Urdu edition to continue at a loss so long only because Harijan on the whole with all its language editions did not incur any loss.
('98', 129, 6, 14, 277664) However there should be a limit to that also.
('98', 129, 6, 15, 277710) My views on Hindustani and the two scripts remain unchanged.
('98', 129, 6, 16, 277771) So for some time the Urdu edition will come out as usual.
('98', 129, 6, 17, 277829) In the mean time the readers of the Gujarati edition and others should decide whether they would like to have the Urdu edition.
('98', 129, 6, 18, 277957) If they want it they should help to enrol subscribers till the circulation reaches at least two thousand.
('98', 129, 6, 19, 278063) Along with this they should also give thought to another point.
('98', 129, 6, 20, 278127) It will become my duty to close down the Devanagari Harijan 2
('98', 129, 7, 21, 278189) also if people show an aversion to the Urdu script and the Urdu edition has to be stopped.
('98', 129, 7, 22, 278280) I do not consider it right to bring out Harijan exclusively in the Devanagari.
('98', 129, 7, 23, 278359) As a reformer it is my duty to bring out the paper either in both the scripts or in neither.
('98', 129, 7, 24, 278452) Much has been written on why the language is called “Hindustani” and not “Hindi” and why it should be written in both the Devanagari and Urdu scripts.
('98', 129, 7, 25, 278603) I cannot think of any new arguments.
('98', 129, 7, 26, 278640) My intention in writing this is to discuss how the Harijan

('98', 132, 2, 3, 281582) NEW DELHI, December 29, 1947
('98', 132, 3, 4, 281611) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Yesterday was the death anniversary of Hakim Ajmal Khan.
('98', 132, 3, 5, 281690) Hakim Ajmal Khan belonged to all—Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Parsis and Jews.
('98', 132, 3, 6, 281769) He was a devout Muslim.
('98', 132, 3, 7, 281793) But he served everyone with equal devotion.
('98', 132, 3, 8, 281837) The finest memorial to his labours was the famous Tibbia College and hospital at Delhi.
('98', 132, 3, 9, 281925) All classes of students studied unani, ayurvedic and allopathic systems of medicine there.
('98', 132, 3, 10, 282016) The communal poison, for which there was no place in this institution, has forced it to close down.
('98', 132, 3, 11, 282116) I think the sole reason for this is that its founder Hakim Ajmal Khan was a Muslim, however good and however respected.
('98', 132, 3, 12, 282236) If the memory of that great patriot cannot bury the communal strife let it at least give a new life to this college.
('98', 132, 3, 13, 282353) I mentioned earlier that it would be good to have our meetings in the open air under the canopy of the sky.
('98', 132, 3, 14, 282461) If the habit grows we will have to make suitable arrangements for the site, etc., accordingly.
('98', 132, 3, 15, 282556) In towns big and small we will have to have open space for the purpose.
('98', 132, 3, 16, 282628) We will have to change our habits.
('98', 132, 3, 17, 282663) We will have to learn to be quiet rather than noisy and we will have to learn to sit in an orderly way.
('98', 132, 3, 18, 282767) We must learn also to speak only when we must and at a pitch that is sufficient for the occasion, neither too high nor too low.
('98', 132, 3, 19, 282895) We should respect the right of our neighbour and not come in the way of others, individually or in groups.
('98', 132, 3, 20, 283002) We should not interfere with other people’s business.
('98', 132, 3, 21, 283056) This will require on many occasions extreme self restraint.
('98', 132, 3, 22, 283116) In such an order of things the dirt and noise we find in the busiest areas of Delhi will no longer be there and however large the crowds there will be no pushing and jostling and no confusion.
('98', 132, 3, 23, 283309) We must not think that we can never reach that goal.
('98', 132, 3, 24, 283362) Some group or other will have to take the initiative and work for this sincerely.
('98', 132, 3, 25, 283444) Just think how much saving it will mean in energy and expenditure.
('98', 132, 3, 26, 283511) I have been severely reprimanded for what I said concerning Kashmir and its Maharaja 2. It seems to me that those who upbraid me have not really read attentively what I said.

('98', 139, 6, 23, 294853) 138. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 139, 7, 24, 294883) NEW DELHI, December 30, 1947
('98', 139, 8, 25, 294912) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('98', 139, 9, 26, 294934) I told you yesterday in my written message and I also mentioned earlier that we should all know our respective places.
('98', 139, 9, 27, 295053) We must know when to speak and when to keep silent and how to conduct ourselves, so that even if millions are there there should be no disturbance and no feeling of crowding.
('98', 139, 9, 28, 295228) This is what happens with armies.
('98', 139, 9, 29, 295262) They maintain an external discipline.
('98', 139, 9, 30, 295300) What happens internally is another matter.
('98', 139, 9, 31, 295343) We have not had this kind of training.
('98', 139, 9, 32, 295382) I have often noticed that, when after the prayer I rise to go, people want to take a peep at me from all around and crowd round me.
('98', 139, 9, 33, 295514) Good manners demand that after the prayer meeting is over everyone should quietly remove himself.
('98', 139, 9, 34, 295612) Each one should ponder on whatever good things I may have said and go home.
('98', 140, 0, 1, 295688) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 141
('98', 140, 1, 2, 295735) I have a letter from Bahawalpur.
('98', 140, 1, 3, 295768) I once spoke about Bahawalpur to you.
('98', 140, 1, 4, 295806) 1 The people there liked what I said.
('98', 140, 1, 5, 295844) They want me to mention the matter again and repeat that all the Hindus and Sikhs who are still there and who want to leave the place should be allowed to do so.
('98', 140, 1, 6, 296006) All those who want to come have not been able to come.
('98', 140, 1, 7, 296061) There are still a large number of people there.
('98', 140, 1, 8, 296109) They want that no obstacle should be placed in their way and they should not be subjected to any assaults.
('98', 140, 1, 9, 296216) Whether my saying anything on the subject will have any effect God alone knows.
('98', 140, 1, 10, 296296) But one must make an effort whatever the effectiveness of one’s effort might be.
('98', 140, 1, 11, 296377) Of course the Nawab has said that Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs are equal in his eyes.
('98', 140, 1, 12, 296460) And he is equally interested in the welfare of all his subjects.
('98', 140, 1, 13, 296525) When he says so, who am I to question his motives?
('98', 140, 1, 14, 296576) Still I can plead with him and his officials that those Hindus and Sikhs who do not want to stay there should be allowed to leave.
('98', 140, 1, 15, 296707) It is his duty to put them on a train and have them safely escorted to the border.
('98', 140, 1, 16, 296790) But even if he cannot do so he can at any rate allow them to leave on their own, taking away such of their property as they can.
('98', 140, 1, 17, 296919) It will be a matter of thankfulness if he can do this much.
('98', 140, 1, 18, 296979) But I do not want to limit myself to only making a plea to the Nawab.
('98', 140, 1, 19, 297049) I want to tell Qaid e Azam Jinnah and his Government that today it has become impossible for a Hindu or any non Muslim to live peaceably in Sind.
('98', 140, 1, 20, 297195) Those Hindus who are called untouchables are particularly harassed there and they have no means of livelihood.
('98', 140, 1, 21, 297306) They at least should not be subjected to indignities.
('98', 140, 1, 22, 297360) Those who are not happy living there should be allowed to leave.
('98', 140, 1, 23, 297425) If their conditions of life are made easy even those who have left Sind will go back there, seeing that Sind has regained its former state.
('98', 140, 1, 24, 297565) But at present that is not the case.
('98', 140, 1, 25, 297602) Even their schools have been taken over for the use of refugees who have gone there from Kathiawar.
('98', 140, 1, 26, 297702) They say that the needs of the refugees are the first priority.

('98', 140, 1, 29, 297938) I think no one will like to be a slave.
('98', 140, 1, 30, 297978) This sort of thing is in no one’s interest.
('98', 140, 1, 31, 298022) I have many other things to say and only fifteen minutes to say them.

('98', 142, 4, 8, 301056) 139. TATYASAHEB KELKAR
('98', 142, 5, 9, 301079) Friends have more than once asked me why I have not noticed the death of so great a patriot as Tatyasaheb Kelkar 1, especially because he was a political opponent and more so because I am much misunderstood among a school of Maharashtrians.
('98', 142, 5, 10, 301320) These reasons made no appeal to me: the very reasons which according to my critics should have prompted my notice.
('98', 142, 5, 11, 301435) I conceive it to be very unseemly to notice pro forma such a serious event as death.
('98', 142, 5, 12, 301520) But I must do so now, though it is late, because of the importunity of one of my oldest friends— Haribhau Phatak.
('98', 142, 5, 13, 301634) I would at once admit that if it was usual for the Harijan to notice important deaths and births then Tatyasaheb’s death should be among the first to merit notice.
('98', 142, 5, 14, 301798) But industrious readers will have noticed that the Harijan has not followed any such practice.
('98', 142, 5, 15, 301893) Notice has depended upon my whim of the moment and leisure.
('98', 142, 5, 16, 301953) For some time past I have been unable to read newspapers regularly.
('98', 142, 5, 17, 302021) Whatever may be said to the contrary, Tatyasaheb, though a political opponent, I had always counted as a friend whose criticism was profitable.
('98', 142, 5, 18, 302165) I knew and honoured him as the late Lokamanya’s 2
('98', 142, 6, 19, 302215) valued follower.
('98', 142, 6, 20, 302232) It was, I fancy, in 1919 that I pleaded at an A. I. C. C. meeting for a constitution for the Congress 3 and said that if the

('98', 147, 3, 6, 310520) 148. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 147, 4, 7, 310550) NEW DELHI, December 31, 1947
('98', 147, 5, 8, 310579) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Here are a few questions.
('98', 147, 5, 9, 310627) Let me see how many of them I can deal with.
('98', 147, 5, 10, 310672) A friend writes to ask how, when Hindus and Sikhs cannot live peacefully in Sind, the Hindus from Punjab can be asked to go back.
('98', 147, 5, 11, 310802) Has there been some significant change of heart?
('98', 147, 5, 12, 310851) I think the Correspondent could not have asked the question if he had known the whole situation.
('98', 147, 5, 13, 310948) What I had told the Punjab Hindus was after a meeting I had with some Muslim friends.
('98', 147, 5, 14, 311034) 1 I cannot yet definitely advise the Punjab refugees to go back.
('98', 147, 5, 15, 311099) It is right that so long as Hindus and Sikhs cannot live happily in Sind I cannot have any hopes as regards the Punjab either.
('98', 147, 5, 16, 311226) At present the complaints I am receiving from all sides seem to be as to why Hindus and Sikhs from.
('98', 147, 5, 17, 311326) Other places in Pakistan are not being allowed to come.
('98', 147, 5, 18, 311382) A few men from Chitral and Swat came to see me.
('98', 147, 5, 19, 311430) They say there are still 251 Hindus in those places.
('98', 147, 5, 20, 311483) I said that this was not a very large number.
('98', 147, 5, 21, 311529) In Sind there are Hindus and Sikhs in much greater numbers and when they cannot come how can you expect the few in Swat and Chitral to be allowed to leave?
('98', 147, 5, 22, 311685) The Government is doing what it can and so long as all the Hindus and Sikhs stranded in Pakistan do not arrive here it will not rest.
('98', 147, 5, 23, 311819) I shall therefore not speak of the refugees returning to Pakistan till there is a change of heart.
('98', 147, 5, 24, 311918) I know that if there is a change of heart in one place the same thing will happen at other places.
('98', 147, 5, 25, 312017) If we have a change of heart here there will be a change of heart in Pakistan.
('98', 147, 5, 26, 312096) It will take some effort no doubt but there will be a change.
('98', 147, 5, 27, 312158) After all madness seized us only after it had
('98', 147, 6, 28, 312204) 1 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 11 12 1947.
('98', 148, 0, 1, 312251) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 149
('98', 148, 1, 2, 312298) seized people in Pakistan.
('98', 148, 1, 3, 312325) I shall not go into the various stages and degrees of madness.
('98', 148, 1, 4, 312388) If sanity does not return we shall lose both India and Pakistan.
('98', 148, 1, 5, 312453) There will be a war.
('98', 148, 1, 6, 312474) The present state cannot last.
('98', 148, 1, 7, 312505) People say that the required change in the situation has already taken place, that Hindus and Sikhs have come to India and Muslims from India have gone to Pakistan.
('98', 148, 1, 8, 312670) They point out that transfer of populations of such magnitude cannot be reversed.
('98', 148, 1, 9, 312752) I do not hold this view.
('98', 148, 1, 10, 312777) Even if I am the only one to say it I shall still say that so long as people do not go back to their homes there will be no peace in the two countries.
('98', 148, 1, 11, 312929) All the comforts you can provide to the Sikh and Hindu refugees are not going to heal the wounds they have suffered.
('98', 148, 1, 12, 313046) It will be a matter of perpetual distress to them that they have lost their hearths and homes and if there is a war in fifty years’ time or a hundred years’ time, they are going to remember this.
('98', 148, 1, 13, 313242) Such things are not forgotten.
('98', 148, 1, 14, 313273) A friend asks if the refugee camps cannot be made centres of training in handicrafts.
('98', 148, 1, 15, 313359) This is certainly possible if even a single refugee wants it.
('98', 148, 1, 16, 313421) It will not be necessary for me to bring any pressure on the Government to do this.
('98', 148, 1, 17, 313505) It will readily agree to do what will save them the enormous expenditure they incur at present in running these camps.
('98', 148, 1, 18, 313624) This will also enable the refugees to earn their livelihood without losing self respect.
('98', 148, 1, 19, 313713) I suggested that the friend should campaign for this and create an atmosphere where the refugees will themselves ask that they should be taught handicrafts.
('98', 148, 1, 20, 313870) This will raise India higher and arrest the rot that has set in in India.
('98', 148, 1, 21, 313944) A lady has just given me this note.
('98', 148, 1, 22, 313980) She is I think a Hindu from Pakistan.
('98', 148, 1, 23, 314018) She says she had gone out for a short period and when she returned she found the lock of her house broken and some Sikhs occupying the house.
('98', 148, 1, 24, 314160) She went to the police and had them arrested.
('98', 148, 1, 25, 314206) One of them escaped.
('98', 148, 1, 26, 314227) Now she wants to know what she should do— whether she should leave the house?
('98', 148, 1, 27, 314305) I would not advise her to leave.
('98', 148, 1, 28, 314338) I did not advise even those coming from Pakistan to leave their houses.
('98', 148, 1, 29, 314410) But what is my advice worth?
('98', 148, 1, 30, 314439) People will not be ready to lay down their lives on my saying so.
('98', 148, 1, 31, 314505) I shall advise the lady not to leave her house.
('98', 148, 1, 32, 314553) Why did the Sikh friends forcibly enter her house?
('98', 148, 1, 33, 314604) The refugees should declare that they will not force themselves on anyone, nor enter anyone’s house without permission.
('98', 148, 1, 34, 314724) They should live on what little money they get.
('98', 148, 1, 35, 314772) A lady has written to me a beautiful letter.
('98', 148, 1, 36, 314817) She does not give her name and address.
('98', 148, 1, 37, 314857) She says she listens to my speeches every day on the radio, but that the hymns and bhajans sung at the meeting are not relayed.
('98', 148, 1, 38, 314985) She suggests that if not every day at least once every third or
('98', 149, 0, 1, 315049) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 149, 1, 2, 315091) fourth day the prayer should be broadcast; that my speeches are only of mundane significance, while prayers are something spiritual.
('98', 149, 1, 3, 315224) My speeches are recorded by the radio people and then relayed.

('98', 149, 1, 31, 316782) Only then can we ensure the justice which we seek.
('98', 149, 1, 32, 316833) If we cannot confine ourselves to facts we are doomed.
