('98', 150, 3, 10, 318119) 150. LETTER TO KARL STRUVE1
('98', 150, 4, 11, 318147) BIRLA HOUSE, NEW DELHI, January 1, 1948
('98', 150, 5, 12, 318187) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter of 11th November 2 which I have just received.
('98', 150, 5, 13, 318275) I have not seen the report you refer to.
('98', 150, 5, 14, 318316) In any case, whatever I have said does not refer in any way to the failure of ahimsa, but it refers to my failure to recognize, until it was too late, that what I had mistaken for ahimsa was not ahimsa, but passive resistance of the weak, which can never be called ahimsa even in the remotest sense.
('98', 150, 5, 15, 318616) The internecine feud that is going on today in India is the direct outcome of the energy that was set free during the thirty years’ action of the weak.
('98', 150, 5, 16, 318768) Hence, the proper way to view the present outburst of violence throughout the world is to recognize that the technique of unconquerable non violence of the strong has not been discovered as yet.
('98', 150, 5, 17, 318963) Not an ounce of non violent strength is ever wasted.
('98', 150, 5, 18, 319016) I must not, therefore, flatter myself with the belief nor allow friends like you to entertain the belief that I have exhibited any heroic and demonstrable non violence in myself as yet.
('98', 150, 5, 19, 319202) All I can claim is that I am sailing in that direction without a moment’s stoppage.
('98', 150, 5, 20, 319286) This confession should
('98', 150, 6, 21, 319309) 1 This, along with the addressee’s letter, appeared in Harijan under the title “Ahimsa Never Fails”.

('98', 151, 0, 1, 319464) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 151, 1, 2, 319506) strengthen your belief in non violence and spur you and friends like you to action along the path of non violence.

('98', 152, 15, 26, 321780) NEW DELHI, January 1, 1948
('98', 152, 16, 27, 321807) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Today is New Year’s Day according to the English calendar.
('98', 152, 16, 28, 321888) I am happy to see such a large number of people gathered here.
('98', 152, 16, 29, 321951) I regret that it took no less than 7 minutes for us to make room for the women to sit.
('98', 152, 16, 30, 322038) Even one minute lost at such a meeting is hundreds of thousands of minutes lost to hundreds of thousands of people.
('98', 153, 0, 1, 322154) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 153, 1, 2, 322196) brothers should learn to offer first place to the sisters.
('98', 153, 1, 3, 322255) The country where women are not honoured is not really civilized.
('98', 153, 1, 4, 322321) According to Manu 1 men and women should both understand their own limits.
('98', 153, 1, 5, 322396) We should learn to behave with added restraint now that we are free.
('98', 153, 1, 6, 322465) I hope the audience attending the prayer meetings will be even larger in future.
('98', 153, 1, 7, 322546) But all those that come should come with prayer in their hearts, for prayer is the food for the heart.
('98', 153, 1, 8, 322649) We cannot get anywhere else such food as we get from God.
('98', 153, 1, 9, 322707) I also hope that the audience will maintain silence and will return to their homes in silence.
('98', 153, 1, 10, 322802) Recently there was a Harijan conference in U. P., at which it is reported, a minister preached to the Harijans that they should give up their unclean habits, unclean living and unclean clothes and abstain from alcohol.
('98', 153, 1, 11, 323021) A Harijan countered that the Government could burn up the unclean clothes just as it could have palm trees cut down and wine shops closed.
('98', 153, 1, 12, 323160) I admire the courage of the Harijan friend.
('98', 153, 1, 13, 323204) I for one make gur from palm.
('98', 153, 1, 14, 323234) I shall advise the Harijan brethren that the cure is in their own hands.
('98', 153, 1, 15, 323307) Even if liquor is sold in shops they should keep away from it as they would from poison.
('98', 153, 1, 16, 323396) In fact liquor is worse than poison.
('98', 153, 1, 17, 323433) Labourers drink in order to forget their domestic worries.
('98', 153, 1, 18, 323492) Poison can only kill the body.
('98', 153, 1, 19, 323523) Liquor can kill even the soul.
('98', 153, 1, 20, 323554) One loses the ability to control one’s action.
('98', 153, 1, 21, 323601) I would advise the Government to close down liquor shops and to replace them by eating houses where people could get pure and light food.
('98', 153, 1, 22, 323739) Here they should distribute books from which people could learn something and they should provide to them some harmless entertainment.
('98', 153, 1, 23, 323874) But there should be no place for cinema.
('98', 153, 1, 24, 323915) This will help people to give up alcohol.
('98', 153, 1, 25, 323957) I say this from my experience of many countries.

('98', 154, 5, 9, 324958) 157. WANTED ACCURACY
('98', 154, 6, 10, 324979) A correspondent from Malabar writes: 3
('98', 154, 7, 11, 325018) The confidence with which Shri Dev Prakash Nayyar has written on the “Intellectual Content of the Takli” in the Harijan of 21 12 47, takes one’s breath away.
('98', 154, 7, 12, 325176) He has made out that all knowledge is contained in the takli or can be derived from it or it is the quintessence of knowledge....
('98', 154, 7, 13, 325306) No doubt, the takli, charkha and spinning have a place in the proper scheme of education, especially, Nayee Talim, but to Say that the takli naturally takes you to mathematics, physics, economics, etc.
('98', 154, 7, 14, 325508) is but “sentimental nonsense.” The takli enthusiasts need not carry their arguments in favour of spinning to a ridiculous extent.
('98', 154, 7, 15, 325638) The cause of spinning cannot be advanced that way.
('98', 154, 7, 16, 325689) The correspondent evidently has not read as carefully as necessary Shri Dev Prakash Nayyar’s contribution on the takli As I read it, he has advanced no such claim as the correspondent imagines.
('98', 154, 7, 17, 325883) The author has not said that “all knowledge is contained in” or that “it is derived from” the takli, nor has he said that it is “the quintessence of knowledge”.
('98', 154, 7, 18, 326044) His thesis simply is that much knowledge that we derive from the books can be better given by competent teachers through crafts.
('98', 154, 7, 19, 326173) The fact that the correspondent who is a practised spinner of long standing is “shocked” at Shri Dev Prakash Nayyar’s claim and calls it “sentimental nonsense” proves that education does not reside in the takli, but it does in an educationist who, like Shri Dev Prakask Nayyar, having tested the possibilities of the takli is entitled to make the claim above mentioned.
('98', 154, 7, 20, 326543) I fear I must deprive the correspondent of the smug satisfaction that not even I have attributed to the innocent looking takli more than “economic and moral virtues”.
('98', 154, 7, 21, 326710) Even the modest claim, I am sorry,

('98', 155, 1, 4, 327092) Practical teachers along the line have found many more possibilities in handicrafts than I had mentioned.

('98', 158, 3, 14, 333128) It costs nothing.
('98', 158, 3, 15, 333146) It was given to me free of cost not because I am a Mahatma.
('98', 158, 3, 16, 333206) The fact is that when I was touring in Noakhali, 2 it was very hot and some people took pity on me and gave me this.
('98', 158, 3, 17, 333323) They put it on also when it rains.
('98', 158, 3, 18, 333358) Mostly people have to work in the fields, they cannot do so in the heat of the sun without putting this on.
('98', 158, 3, 19, 333466) Muslims live there in large numbers.
('98', 158, 3, 20, 333503) There are Hindus too, but mostly they carry on business.
('98', 158, 3, 21, 333560) Everyone has this kind of umbrella.
('98', 158, 3, 22, 333596) There was a Muslim friend there because after all every Muslim did not consider me his enemy and later they had all understood that I had not gone there to plunder them or to prepare a case against them, but I had gone there only to give such solace as I could to the Hindus.
('98', 158, 3, 23, 333872) So they gave me this umbrella.
('98', 158, 3, 24, 333903) I did not really need it much there because I did not do more than an hour of walking each day.
('98', 158, 3, 25, 333999) They also gave one to Nirmal Babu 3. When I left Noakhali Manu suggested that I should take along this umbrella because I would have to do a lot of walking in the sun and it would be a good covering for the head.
('98', 158, 3, 26, 334212) This can be made anywhere.

('98', 158, 3, 28, 334265) The other kind of umbrella needs a handle while this has no handle.
('98', 158, 3, 29, 334333) When it is windy we can tie the string attached to it round the face.

('98', 163, 9, 23, 343913) A man of peace can live happily even in a mud hut and has no thought of the morrow, for it is only God who knows what will happen on the morrow.

('98', 164, 1, 2, 344320) securing peace was not the same thing as securing a throne and that peace was not dependent on external conditions.

('98', 165, 1, 2, 346478) 170. QUESTION BOX1
('98', 165, 2, 3, 346497) Q. It does not matter whether the lingua franca be called Hindi or Hindustani; in any case the common language in actual use will remain Hindustani.
('98', 165, 2, 4, 346646) It cannot, however, be gainsaid that in advanced literature and science certain words will be necessary which can only be derived from Sanskrit.
('98', 165, 2, 5, 346791) Where is the harm in making this clear to the public?
('98', 165, 3, 6, 346845) A. The first part of the question would be correct provided the name adopted were accepted by all in the same light.
('98', 165, 3, 7, 346962) The controversy arises not over the name but what it is meant to convey.
('98', 165, 3, 8, 347035) In advanced literature and science we should not draw exclusively from Sanskrit.
('98', 165, 3, 9, 347116) A small committee can be appointed to prepare a dictionary of current words irrespective of their original source.
('98', 165, 4, 10, 347231) Q. With regard to the script, it would be burdensome to have to use two scripts in the conduct of the affairs of the nation.
('98', 165, 4, 11, 347356) Why not then adopt the Nagari script which is current in all provinces?
('98', 165, 4, 12, 347428) Does the two script proposal mean that the Central Government should use both the scripts in its correspondence and publications?
('98', 165, 4, 13, 347558) Would telegraph and other offices also have to use both the scripts?
('98', 165, 5, 14, 347627) I do not subscribe to the view often put forward that the two script proposal is meant to appease the Muslims.
('98', 165, 5, 15, 347738) Our concern should be to select the script which might be advantageous to the nation as a whole without wishing any injustice.
('98', 165, 5, 16, 347865) It would not be correct to hold that the adoption of the Nagari script would be harmful to Muslim interests.
('98', 165, 5, 17, 347974) As far as I can see, it would be necessary to adopt both the scripts, but only as a temporary measure— ultimately one script should be acceptable to all.
('98', 165, 5, 18, 348128) How can this be disputed?
('98', 165, 5, 19, 348154) A. With the adoption of the two scripts, the easier one will ultimately survive.
('98', 165, 5, 20, 348235) All that is wanted is that the Urdu script should not be boycotted, as such boycott would imply discrimination.
('98', 165, 5, 21, 348347) A controversy arose over such discrimination and this has now been accentuated.
('98', 165, 5, 22, 348427) With this background, we who believe in unity and are opposed to civil strife are bound to adopt both the scripts.
('98', 165, 5, 23, 348542) Again we cannot forget that many Hindus and Sikhs are ignorant of the Nagari script.
('98', 165, 5, 24, 348627) There is no question of all people having to learn both the scripts, but only of those liable to serve outside their province.
('98', 165, 5, 25, 348754) Nor is it suggested that all notices should be issued by the Central Government in both the scripts—but only those meant for all.
('98', 165, 6, 26, 348884) 1 A Hindi version of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 11 1 1948. The questions were sent by Rameshchandra of Shillong; vide “Letter to Rameshchandra”, 4/5 1 1948.
('98', 166, 0, 1, 349046) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 167
('98', 166, 1, 2, 349093) Having regard to the present communal antagonism, the boycott of the Urdu script would be regarded as an antidemocratic measure.
('98', 166, 1, 3, 349222) The question whether telegraph and other offices would also have to use both the scripts is a minor one.
('98', 166, 1, 4, 349327) When we get rid of the incubus of the English language and the Roman script, our minds will be clearer and we shall realize the futility of such controversies.
('98', 166, 1, 5, 349487) While we must always refrain from an improper course with the object of appeasing others, there is no harm in conciliating when the course itself is intrinsically proper.
('98', 166, 1, 6, 349658) If all accepted our script willingly, it would be so good, but even to achieve this end it is necessary to retain both the scripts at present.

('98', 177, 3, 17, 372075) 185. KHADI CAN REMOVE CLOTH SHORTAGE
('98', 177, 4, 18, 372112) A friend writes that khadi can help to remove the shortage of cloth in a matter of six months.
('98', 177, 4, 19, 372207) For this two conditions will be necessary, viz., (1) that the Central and Provincial Governments should adopt the policy of encouraging spinning and weaving in every village, and (2) that provincial and all India leaders should put forth greater efforts to popularize khadi.
('98', 177, 4, 20, 372482) In my opinion it should be worth while and it is the duty of the Congress to fulfil these conditions for the sake of remedying cloth shortage.
('98', 177, 4, 21, 372625) Our undoubted indifference in this respect shows that we have failed in our duty.
('98', 177, 4, 22, 372707) The price of cloth having risen so high, the present is the most opportune time to get over this indifference.
('98', 177, 4, 23, 372818) This can be done by the example and conduct as well as the wisdom of those who have unshakable faith in khadi.

('98', 178, 1, 2, 373345) 186. CERTIFIED AND UNCERTIFIED KHADI1
('98', 178, 2, 3, 373383) The same friend, who suggests that khadi can remove cloth shortage, writes that India having attained independence, there is little difference now between certified and uncertified khadi, mill cloth and foreign cloth.
('98', 178, 2, 4, 373601) Khadi may have significance for him who spins and weaves to clothe himself, but people are unable to do so or even to spin the minimum quota of yarn prescribed for the purchase of khadi from the bhandars.
('98', 178, 2, 5, 373806) No improvement is noticeable in the quality of pure khadi, while many useful varieties of uncertified khadi are available.
('98', 178, 2, 6, 373929) Moreover, it is difficult nowadays to give what can be termed a living wage in the khadi industry.
('98', 178, 2, 7, 374028) On these grounds the writer observes that the purchase of uncertified khadi should be permitted.
('98', 178, 2, 8, 374125) He proceeds to argue that having regard to the acute shortage of cloth all over the country and to the fact that the Union Government itself imports foreign cloth, there should be no objection to the purchase of such cloth either.
('98', 178, 2, 9, 374356) That such questions can be raised shows the change in the times.
('98', 178, 2, 10, 374421) My answer is that only “certified khadi” should be used.
('98', 178, 2, 11, 374478) Let me indicate the meaning of this term.
('98', 178, 2, 12, 374520) Even the Charkha Sangh’s definition is incomplete.
('98', 178, 2, 13, 374571) The term really implies that a reasonable wage is given to spinners and weavers and the price of khadi fixed with an eye on public good and not with a profit motive.
('98', 178, 2, 14, 374737) Certification of such khadi by the Charkha Sangh becomes necessary, as people have as a rule, to fall back upon the purchase of khadi in addition to self made (
('98', 178, 3, 15, 374898) <image: None, width: 32, height: 11, bpc: 1>
('98', 178, 4, 16, 374943) ) khadi.
('98', 178, 4, 17, 374952) Any other khadi is uncertified and open to objection and should not, therefore, be used.
('98', 178, 4, 18, 375041) It is open to the public to suggest improvements in the conditions presented for the certification of khadi, but it would be definitely wrong to abolish the distinction between certified and uncertified khadi.
('98', 178, 4, 19, 375251) Again, how can one shut one’s eyes to the distinction between khadi, mill cloth and foreign cloth, or justify the import of foreign cloth because foreign rule has ended?
('98', 178, 4, 20, 375421) We must remember that we opposed foreign rule because it involved the economic ruin of the country.
('98', 178, 4, 21, 375521) The first fruit of freedom should, therefore, be to put an end to this curse.
('98', 178, 4, 22, 375599) In fine it follows that pure khadi alone has place in swaraj: in it
('98', 178, 5, 23, 375667) 1 A Hindi version of this appeared in Harijan Sevak under the date line “New Delhi, 5 1 1948”.

('98', 179, 3, 5, 375910) 187. HARIJANS IN HOSTELS1
('98', 179, 4, 6, 375936) Apropos the recent legislation enacted by the Government of Bombay extending to the Harijans the right of admission to temples, wells, dharmashalas, schools, hostels, etc., Shri Parikshitlal writes that though this automatically covers undenominational hostels as well, school and college hostels have not in actual practice been thrown open to the Harijan students.
('98', 179, 4, 7, 376303) His experience has been that the school and college authorities have not adapted themselves to the spirit of the times to the extent the hostel students have.
('98', 179, 4, 8, 376462) As the academic year will soon be over and fresh admissions will be made shortly, he has advised the authorities to do the needful before the Harijan students are forced to assert their legal right in the matter and has also suggested to me to recommend the throwing open of the hostels in Bhavnagar and other Kathiawar States to the Harijan students.
('98', 179, 4, 9, 376814) I endorse his suggestion and would add that if the students in the hostels are sincere, they are sure to succeed in the matter.
('98', 179, 4, 10, 376942) In the present age the autocratic will of the managing committees cannot prevail, particularly when, as in this case, they are in the wrong and the students are in the right.
('98', 179, 4, 11, 377117) Be that as it may, the Harijan students should unquestionably be admitted to hostels with honour.

('98', 190, 1, 2, 395732) But what are the people to do?

('98', 196, 1, 2, 407221) 210. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 196, 2, 3, 407251) NEW DELHI, January 8, 1948
('98', 196, 3, 4, 407278) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('98', 196, 4, 5, 407300) A correspondent refers to what I had said about the Harijans and drinking.
('98', 196, 4, 6, 407375) 1 As a matter of fact it was not only Harijans I had mentioned but all others.
('98', 196, 4, 7, 407454) He asks if only Harijans should give up drinking, what about the soldiers and rich people?
('98', 196, 4, 8, 407545) It is a silly question.
('98', 196, 4, 9, 407569) If the rich do not give up drinking, does it mean that others too should not give it up?
('98', 196, 4, 10, 407658) Even if there is no prohibition drinking does not become a virtue.
('98', 196, 4, 11, 407725) Does it mean that if others sin we should also sin?
('98', 196, 4, 12, 407777) Since he has asked me I would tell him that all those who drink should give up the habit.
('98', 196, 4, 13, 407867) Since the Harijans and the labour class cannot be persuaded the law must persuade them.
('98', 196, 4, 14, 407955) They take to drink because they are deprived of other comforts of life.
('98', 196, 4, 15, 408027) They want to drown their poverty in drink.
('98', 196, 4, 16, 408070) But what reason can there be for the rich and the soldiers to drink?
('98', 196, 4, 17, 408139) It is not that all the soldiers drink.
('98', 196, 4, 18, 408178) Even among the English there are many who do not drink.
('98', 196, 4, 19, 408234) Everyone should give up drinking.
('98', 196, 4, 20, 408268) The law will apply to all.
('98', 196, 4, 21, 408295) It will not make any exception in favour of the rich.
('98', 196, 4, 22, 408349) I shall speak now of the students’ strike.
('98', 196, 4, 23, 408392) I understand that students who are Congress supporters will not join the strike.
('98', 196, 4, 24, 408473) It seems the strike was organized by the Communist students.
('98', 196, 4, 25, 408534) There are all types of students—Communist, Socialist and Congress supporters.
('98', 196, 4, 26, 408612) I am not concerned with that.
('98', 196, 4, 27, 408642) I am addressing them all.
('98', 196, 4, 28, 408668) If the Congress students are not taking part in the strike they deserve to be complimented.
('98', 196, 4, 29, 408760) I shall advise all the students not to go on strike.
('98', 196, 4, 30, 408813) It pains me that Communist students are taking this step.
('98', 196, 4, 31, 408871) Communists are clever people.
('98', 196, 4, 32, 408901) They too want to serve the country.
('98', 196, 4, 33, 408937) But this is not the way to serve the country.
('98', 196, 4, 34, 408983) And why should the students support any particular party?
('98', 196, 4, 35, 409041) The students form a party themselves.
('98', 196, 4, 36, 409079) Their job is to study not merely for themselves but for the service of the country.
('98', 196, 4, 37, 409163) So long as one is a student one is not a Communist, or a Socialist, or a Congressman.
('98', 196, 4, 38, 409249) One is merely a student devoted wholly to studies.
('98', 196, 4, 39, 409300) Strike for them will be fatal.
('98', 196, 4, 40, 409331) I have a question here.
('98', 196, 4, 41, 409355) It is a good question.
('98', 196, 4, 42, 409378) I am asked why I who have been advising everyone to give up evil things don’t offer

('98', 197, 1, 2, 409549) the same advice to Pakistan, why I do not go there and resort to satyagraha.
('98', 197, 1, 3, 409626) I have answered the question except for the satyagraha part.
('98', 197, 1, 4, 409687) How can I go to Pakistan so long as we are behaving here as they do in Pakistan?

('98', 197, 1, 19, 410445) The correspondent asks: “Since Hindus and Sikhs in such large numbers have been thrown out of Pakistan, where is the place for the Muslims to live?
('98', 197, 1, 20, 410593) And so long as the same number of Muslims do not leave India, where is the place for the refugees to occupy?” I think that the number of Muslims who have already left equals the number of Hindu and Sikh refugees from Pakistan.
('98', 197, 1, 21, 410820) It is madness to demand that the rest of them should also go because attempts are being made to drive out from Pakistan the Hindus and Sikhs still left there.
('98', 197, 1, 22, 410979) We still have large numbers of Muslims in India.
('98', 197, 1, 23, 411028) I am told that the meeting called by Maulana Azad in Lucknow was attended by 70,000 Muslims.
('98', 197, 1, 24, 411121) It was the largest number of Muslims who attended a meeting in recent times.
('98', 197, 1, 25, 411198) Must we kill all those Muslims or send them away to Pakistan, and why?
('98', 197, 1, 26, 411269) I shall never give such shameful advice.
('98', 197, 1, 27, 411310) There is no bravery in it.
('98', 197, 1, 28, 411337) A number of people from Bahawalpur came to see me today.
('98', 197, 1, 29, 411394) A few persons from Mirpur Kashmir also came.
('98', 197, 1, 30, 411439) They are obviously in great difficulty.
('98', 197, 1, 31, 411479) While they were still talking Panditji dropped in.
('98', 197, 1, 32, 411530) I asked him to hear what the visitors had to say.
('98', 197, 1, 33, 411580) The representatives of Mirpur had a talk with Panditji and I hope something will be done.
('98', 197, 1, 34, 411670) I do not say that all that they want will be done.
('98', 197, 1, 35, 411721) Although it is not yet a formal war, it is something very similar.
('98', 197, 1, 36, 411788) In the circumstances it will be difficult to find a way of bringing over all the people marooned there.
('98', 197, 1, 37, 411892) I am sure the Government will do what it can.
('98', 197, 1, 38, 411938) But if there are still some people left there who cannot be helped, there is nothing much we can do about it.
('98', 197, 1, 39, 412048) We do not have enough trains and buses.
('98', 197, 1, 40, 412088) The Kashmir road is not yet fit for transporting millions of people.
('98', 197, 1, 41, 412157) It is too narrow.
('98', 198, 0, 1, 412175) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 199
('98', 198, 1, 2, 412222) The Bahawalpur refugees told me that the other refugees could have their names registered for jobs and send in applications, but that all the applications of those coming from Bahawalpur were not being entertained.
('98', 198, 1, 3, 412437) They asked why there should be such discrimination.

('98', 202, 1, 2, 418947) 217. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 202, 2, 3, 418977) NEW DELHI, January 9, 1948
('98', 202, 3, 4, 419004) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('98', 202, 4, 5, 419026) I want to say something about a Hindu temple in Bahawalpur.
('98', 202, 4, 6, 419086) It is still there but is no more in the possession of the Hindus.
('98', 202, 4, 7, 419152) The chief priest of the temple came to see me today.
('98', 202, 4, 8, 419205) His name is Bhagwandas.
('98', 202, 4, 9, 419229) He saw with his own eyes how the temple was attacked and how the Hindus ran for their lives by the backdoor.
('98', 202, 4, 10, 419338) The chief priest also ran away with them.
('98', 202, 4, 11, 419380) He described to me how he was able to save some women.
('98', 202, 4, 12, 419435) He could not save them all but quite a number were rescued.
('98', 202, 4, 13, 419495) He wants me to find a way of bringing over the Hindus still stranded there.
('98', 202, 4, 14, 419571) I told him that I was doing all that a single individual could do.
('98', 202, 4, 15, 419638) The Government was trying to do something but it was not easy because one Government should not interfere in the affairs of another.
('98', 202, 4, 16, 419771) I have said it before and I say it again that what is required at the present juncture is patience.
('98', 202, 4, 17, 419871) We should not fear death.
('98', 202, 4, 18, 419897) We must fear dishonour and indignity.
('98', 202, 4, 19, 419935) To save one’s honour one must lay down one’s life.
('98', 202, 4, 20, 419986) If someone is asked to embrace Islam or be prepared to die, he must choose death.
('98', 202, 4, 21, 420068) Death is inevitable and cannot be avoided for ever.
('98', 202, 4, 22, 420120) This of course does not mean that we should not do what we can to save ourselves but our ultimate trust should be in God.
('98', 202, 4, 23, 420242) A refugee came to see me today.
('98', 202, 4, 24, 420274) He was not a beggar, nor a poor man.
('98', 202, 4, 25, 420311) He has known prosperity.
('98', 202, 4, 26, 420336) He lives in a bungalow nearby.
('98', 202, 4, 27, 420367) The bungalow belonged to a Muslim who ran away.
('98', 202, 4, 28, 420415) The refugee friend was a friend of that Muslim.
('98', 202, 4, 29, 420463) He comes from the place where the Muslim has gone to settle.
('98', 202, 4, 30, 420524) He told him to go and live in his bungalow.
('98', 202, 4, 31, 420568) Now he says he has received a notice from the Government asking him to vacate the bungalow which is required for public purposes.
('98', 202, 4, 32, 420698) I have no doubt that the Government would requisition the house.
('98', 202, 4, 33, 420763) There are many people, ambassadors and others coming from outside and the Government would want to provide them proper accommodation.
('98', 202, 4, 34, 420897) After all the Government cannot put up new houses by magic.
('98', 202, 4, 35, 420957) It is said that sages had this power in former times.
('98', 202, 4, 36, 421011) It is related in the Ramayana how the sage Bharadwaja had made a whole city appear from nowhere with the power of his mantra.
('98', 202, 4, 37, 421137) Today I know of no such mantra.
('98', 202, 4, 38, 421169) I therefore can understand it if the Government requisitions houses when it wants them but it should then
('98', 203, 0, 1, 421275) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 203, 1, 2, 421317) provide alternative accommodation to the people living there.
('98', 203, 1, 3, 421379) If the Government just pushes out the occupants, where are they to go?
('98', 203, 1, 4, 421450) I am sure the Government cannot act thus.
('98', 203, 1, 5, 421492) But if such a notice has been received I cannot really hold out any assurance of help.

('98', 203, 1, 21, 422494) There are so many notes and letters that I find it difficult to decide which one to take up.
('98', 203, 1, 22, 422587) One says that I am staying here in Birla House where poor people cannot enter; formerly when I was in Bhangi Colony poor people could approach me.

('98', 204, 4, 8, 424080) 218. LETTER TO VIJAYA M. PANCHOLI
('98', 204, 5, 9, 424114) January 9, 1948
('98', 204, 6, 10, 424130) VIJAYA, It is after a long time that you seem to have found occasion to write to me.
('98', 204, 6, 11, 424215) I often think of you.
('98', 204, 6, 12, 424237) The answer to your question is the verse which we sing every day at the morning prayer.
('98', 204, 6, 13, 424325) The prayer, in its entirety, is meant not only to be recited but to be acted upon.
('98', 204, 6, 14, 424408) This is what the verse means: “Our misfortunes are not real misfortunes, nor are our good fortunes so in fact.
('98', 204, 6, 15, 424519) Real misfortune is the forgetting of Vishnu, and the highest wealth consists in constantly thinking of Him and trying to see Him in one’s heart.” Think over this and shed your weakness.
('98', 204, 6, 16, 424705) Why need one who feels Rama in his heart, bemoan massacres or lose his reason because of them?
('98', 204, 6, 17, 424800) And, moreover, what about the inhuman conduct we were guilty of on our side?
('98', 204, 6, 18, 424877) Hence did Narasimha sing: “Let not thy mind be affected by suffering or happiness, for they were created with the body.” Think over this.
('98', 204, 6, 19, 425015) I don’t like your being weak.
('98', 204, 6, 20, 425045) You should go to Panchgani.
('98', 204, 6, 21, 425073) Accommodation is available there now.
('98', 204, 6, 22, 425111) Uruli also is a fine place.
('98', 204, 6, 23, 425139) You should find some time for rest.

('98', 204, 7, 25, 425214) I have written this letter in great hurry, having put off going to bed for a while.
('98', 204, 7, 26, 425298) Look after the children with great care.

('98', 205, 2, 3, 425573) January 10, 1948
('98', 205, 3, 4, 425590) SHARDA, Harjivan having passed away, your highest good lies in acknowledging your faults when they are pointed out by others.
('98', 205, 3, 5, 425716) One may only praise the departed for his good qualities.
('98', 205, 3, 6, 425773) How can Dada 1
('98', 205, 4, 7, 425788) realize that even when I was finding fault with you I was only admiring your good qualities?
('98', 205, 4, 8, 425881) However, irrespective of what I did or did not tell him let me tell you one thing, that I greatly appreciate your strength of character, and as for Harjivan he was simply devoted to you.
('98', 205, 4, 9, 426068) He believed that whatever brahmacharya he could observe he did with the help of your strength of character.
('98', 205, 4, 10, 426176) He did not look upon it as a great achievement on his part.
('98', 205, 4, 11, 426236) It was therefore you who succumbed to his entreaties.
('98', 205, 4, 12, 426290) Thus you fell and brought him down with you.
('98', 205, 4, 13, 426335) If you never had any respect for brahmacharya, raising a family would have been regarded as the normal thing for you as for anyone else.
('98', 205, 4, 14, 426472) Only he can fall who has risen high.
('98', 205, 4, 15, 426509) I write all this so that you can be strong in future and may not feel dejected.
('98', 205, 4, 16, 426589) You should now devote yourself cheerfully to your own work and your own dharma, and conduct yourself as Dada advises.

('98', 205, 8, 21, 426827) BHAI GANGADHARRAO,

('98', 208, 4, 10, 432857) 222. “URDU HARIJAN”
('98', 208, 5, 11, 432877) Two weeks ago I hinted in the Gujarati columns that the Harijan printed in the Urdu script was likely to be stopped as its sale was steadily dwindling.
('98', 208, 5, 12, 433029) Apart even from financial considerations, I saw no meaning in publishing it, if there was no demand for it.
('98', 208, 5, 13, 433137) The dwindle to me was a sign of resentment against its publication.
('98', 208, 5, 14, 433205) I would be foolish if I failed to profit by it.
('98', 208, 5, 15, 433253) My view remains unalterable especially at this critical juncture in our history.
('98', 208, 5, 16, 433334) It is wrong to ruffle Muslim or any other person’s feeling when there is no question of ethics.
('98', 208, 5, 17, 433430) Those who take the trouble of learning the Urdu script in addition to the Nagari, will surely lose nothing.
('98', 208, 5, 18, 433538) They will gain a knowledge of the Urdu script, which many of our countrymen know.
('98', 208, 5, 19, 433620) If it was not for cussedness, this proposition will be admitted without any argument.
('98', 208, 5, 20, 433706) The limitations of this script in terms of perfection are many.
('98', 208, 5, 21, 433770) But for elegance and grace it will equal any script in the world.
('98', 208, 5, 22, 433836) It will not die so long at least as Arabic and Persian live, though it has achieved a status all its own without outside aid.
('98', 208, 5, 23, 433962) With a little adaptation it can serve the purpose of shorthand.
('98', 208, 5, 24, 434026) As a national script, if it is set free from the bondage of orthodoxy, it is capable of improvement so as to enable one to transcribe Sanskrit verses without the slightest difficulty.
('98', 208, 5, 25, 434210) Lastly, those who in anger boycott the Urdu script, put a wanton affront upon the Muslims of the Union who, in the eyes of many Hindus, have become aliens in their own land.
('98', 208, 5, 26, 434384) This is copying the bad manners of Pakistan with a vengeance.

('98', 208, 5, 28, 434532) If they will enter the heart of what I have written, they will prevent the impending collapse of the Nagari and Urdu editions of the Harijan.
('98', 208, 5, 29, 434674) Will Muslim friends rise to the occasion and do two things—subscribe to the Urdu edition and diligently learn the Nagari script and enrich their intellectual capital?

('98', 209, 0, 1, 434890) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 209, 1, 2, 434932) 223. HOW DEMOCRACY WORKS
('98', 209, 2, 3, 434957) A valued correspondent has written to me two letters, one issuing a timely warning about the ill effects of hasty decontrol and the other about the possibility of an outbreak of Hindu Muslim riots.
('98', 209, 2, 4, 435155) I have dealt with both the letters in a letter which has become unexpectedly argumentative and gives my view of democracy which can only come out of non violent mass action.
('98', 209, 2, 5, 435329) I, therefore, reproduce the letter below without giving at the same time the letters to which it is in answer.
('98', 209, 2, 6, 435440) There is enough in the answer to enable the reader to know the purport of the two letters.
('98', 209, 2, 7, 435531) I have purposely refrained from giving the name of my correspondent and the scene of action, not because the letters are confidential, but because nothing is to be gained from disclosing either: You still write as if you had the slave mind, though the slavery of us all is abolished.
('98', 209, 2, 8, 435815) If decontrol has produced the effect you attribute to it, you should raise your voice, even though you may be alone in doing so and your voice may be feeble.
('98', 209, 2, 9, 435973) As a matter of fact you have many companions and your voice is by no means feeble unless intoxication of power has enfeebled it.
('98', 209, 2, 10, 436102) Personally, the bogey of the shooting up of prices by reason of decontrol does not frighten me.
('98', 209, 2, 11, 436198) If we have many sharks and we do not know how to combat them, we shall deserve to be eaten up by them.
('98', 209, 2, 12, 436301) Then we shall know how to carry ourselves in the teeth of adversity.
('98', 209, 2, 13, 436370) Real democracy people learn not from books, not from the government who are in name and in reality their servants.
('98', 209, 2, 14, 436485) Hard experience is the most efficient teacher in democracy.
('98', 209, 2, 15, 436545) The days of appeals to me are gone.
('98', 209, 2, 16, 436581) The cloak of non violence which we had put on during the British regime is no longer now necessary.
('98', 209, 2, 17, 436681) Therefore, violence faces us in its terrible nakedness.
('98', 209, 2, 18, 436737) Have you also succumbed or you too never had non violence?
('98', 209, 2, 19, 436796) This letter is not to warn you against writing to me and giving me your view of the picture, but it is intended to tell you why I would swear by decontrol even if mine was a solitary voice.
('98', 209, 2, 20, 436986) Your second letter about Hindu Muslim tension is more to the point than the first.
('98', 209, 2, 21, 437069) Here too you should raise your voice openly against any soft handling of the situation or smug satisfaction.
('98', 209, 2, 22, 437178) I shall do my part but I am painfully conscious of my limitations.
('98', 209, 2, 23, 437245) Formerly I could afford to be the monarch of all
('98', 210, 0, 1, 437294) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 211
('98', 210, 1, 2, 437341) I surveyed.
('98', 210, 1, 3, 437353) Today I have many fellow monarchs, if I may still count myself as such.
('98', 210, 1, 4, 437425) If I can, I am the least among them.
('98', 210, 1, 5, 437462) The first days of democracy are discordant notes which jar on the ear and give you many headaches.
('98', 210, 1, 6, 437561) If democracy is to live in spite of these killing notes, sweet concord has to rise out of this seemingly discordant necessary lesson.
('98', 210, 1, 7, 437695) How I wish that you would be one of the masters who would contribute to the production of concord out of discord!
('98', 210, 1, 8, 437809) You will not make the mistake of thinking that your duty is finished when you have apprised me of the situation in your part of the country.
('98', 210, 2, 9, 437950) NEW DELHI, January I 1, 1948 Harijan, 18 1 1948

('98', 214, 4, 8, 445518) 229. THE LATE TOTARAM SANADHYA
('98', 214, 5, 9, 445549) Totaramji has passed away at a ripe old age without requiring any nursing.
('98', 214, 5, 10, 445624) He was a jewel of the Sabarmati Ashram.
('98', 214, 5, 11, 445664) Though not a scholar, he had wisdom.

('98', 217, 5, 7, 449340) NEW DELHI, January 12, 1948
('98', 217, 6, 8, 449368) One fasts for health’s sake under laws governing health or fasts as a penance for a wrong done and felt as such.
('98', 217, 6, 9, 449481) In these fasts, the fasting one need not believe in ahimsa.
('98', 217, 6, 10, 449541) There is, however, a fast which a votary of non violence sometimes feels impelled to undertake by way of protest against some wrong done by society and this he does when he, as a votary of ahimsa, has no other remedy left.
('98', 217, 6, 11, 449764) Such an occasion has come my way.
('98', 217, 6, 12, 449798) When on September 9 I returned to Delhi from Calcutta, I was to proceed to West Punjab.
('98', 217, 6, 13, 449886) But that was not to be.
('98', 217, 6, 14, 449910) Gay Delhi looked a city of the dead.
('98', 217, 6, 15, 449947) As I alighted from the train I observed gloom on every face.
('98', 217, 6, 16, 450008) I saw even the Sardar, whom humour and the joy that humour gives never desert, was no exception this time.
('98', 217, 6, 17, 450115) The cause of it I did not know.
('98', 217, 6, 18, 450147) He was on the platform to receive me.
('98', 217, 6, 19, 450185) He lost no time in giving me the sad news of the disturbances that had taken place in the metropolis of the Union.
('98', 217, 6, 20, 450300) At once I saw that I had to be in Delhi and do or die.
('98', 217, 6, 21, 450355) There is apparent calm brought about by prompt military and police action.
('98', 217, 6, 22, 450430) But there is storm within the breast.
('98', 217, 6, 23, 450468) It may burst forth any day.
('98', 217, 6, 24, 450496) This I count as no fulfilment of the vow to “do” which alone can keep me from death, the incomparable friend.
('98', 217, 6, 25, 450606) I yearn for heart friendship between Hindus, Sikhs and Muslims.
('98', 217, 6, 26, 450670) It subsisted between them the other day.
('98', 217, 6, 27, 450711) Today it is non existent.

('98', 218, 1, 15, 451867) The period is indefinite and I may drink water with or without salts and sour limes.
('98', 218, 1, 16, 451952) It will end when and if I am satisfied that there is a reunion of hearts of all communities brought about without any outside pressure, but from an awakened sense of duty.
('98', 218, 1, 17, 452124) The reward will be the regaining of India’s dwindling prestige and her fast fading sovereignty over the heart of Asia and therethrough the world.

('98', 218, 1, 23, 452777) If I have made a mistake and discover it, I shall have no hesitation in proclaiming it from the house top and retracing my faulty step.
('98', 218, 1, 24, 452913) There is little chance of my making such a discovery.
('98', 218, 1, 25, 452967) If there is a clear indication, as I claim there is, of the Inner Voice, it will not be gainsaid.

('98', 228, 3, 4, 473741) 243. TO GUJARATIS1
('98', 228, 4, 5, 473760) I am dictating this from my bed early on Wednesday morning.
('98', 228, 4, 6, 473820) It is the second day of the fast though it is not yet twenty four hours since the fast commenced.
('98', 228, 4, 7, 473918) It is the last day for posting matter for this week’s Harijan.
('98', 228, 4, 8, 473981) So I think it proper to address a few words to the people of Gujarat.
('98', 228, 4, 9, 474051) I do not consider this an ordinary fast.
('98', 228, 4, 10, 474092) I have undertaken it after much reflection.
('98', 228, 4, 11, 474136) Yet it is not reflection that has impelled it; it is God who rules over reason.
('98', 228, 4, 12, 474216) It is addressed to no one or is addressed to all.
('98', 228, 4, 13, 474266) There is no anger of any kind behind it, nor the slightest tinge of impatience.
('98', 228, 4, 14, 474346) There is a time for everything.
('98', 228, 4, 15, 474378) Of what use would any efforts be after the opportunity has slipped?
('98', 228, 4, 16, 474446) What therefore remains to be considered is whether there is something that each Indian can do.
('98', 228, 4, 17, 474541) Gujaratis are Indians.
('98', 228, 4, 18, 474564) And since I write this in Gujarati it is addressed to all Indians who know Gujarati.
('98', 228, 4, 19, 474649) Delhi is the capital of India.
('98', 228, 4, 20, 474680) If we do not accept partition in our hearts, that is, if we do not consider Hindus and Muslims separate peoples, we shall have to admit that Delhi is no longer the capital of India as we have visualized it.
('98', 228, 4, 21, 474887) Delhi has always been the capital.
('98', 228, 4, 22, 474922) It is this city which was Indraprastha, which was Hastinapur.
('98', 228, 4, 23, 474984) We see the ruins standing today.
('98', 228, 4, 24, 475017) It is the heart of India.
('98', 228, 4, 25, 475043) It would be the limit of foolishness to regard it as belonging only to the Hindus or the Sikhs.
('98', 228, 4, 26, 475139) It may sound harsh but there is no exaggeration in it.
('98', 228, 4, 27, 475194) It is the literal truth.
('98', 228, 4, 28, 475219) All Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs, Parsis, Christians and Jews who people this country from Kanyakumari to Kashmir and from Karachi to Dibrugarh in Assam and who have lovingly and in a spirit of service adopted it as their dear motherland, have an equal right to it.
('98', 228, 4, 29, 475479) No one can say that it has place only for the majority and the minority should be dishonoured.
('98', 228, 4, 30, 475574) Whoever serves it with the purest devotion must have the first right over it.
('98', 228, 4, 31, 475652) Therefore, anyone who seeks to drive out the Muslims is Delhi’s enemy number one and therefore India’s enemy number one.
('98', 228, 4, 32, 475773) We are heading towards that catastrophe.
('98', 228, 5, 33, 475814) 1 A translation of this appeared in Harijan, 18 1 1948.
('98', 229, 0, 1, 475870) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 229, 1, 2, 475912) Every Indian must do his bit to ward it off.
('98', 229, 1, 3, 475957) What should we do then?
('98', 229, 1, 4, 475981) If we would see Panchayat Raj, i.
('98', 229, 1, 5, 476015) e., democracy established, we would regard the humblest and the lowliest Indian as being equally the ruler of India with the tallest in the land.
('98', 229, 1, 6, 476161) For this everyone should be pure.

('98', 229, 1, 9, 476268) He will observe no distinctions between caste and caste, between touchable and untouchable, but will consider everyone equal with himself.
('98', 229, 1, 10, 476407) He will bind others to himself with love.

('98', 231, 5, 6, 481410) 245. TALK WITH MUSLIMS
('98', 231, 6, 7, 481433) NEW DELHI, January 14, 1948 1
('98', 231, 7, 8, 481463) When the Delhi Maulanas came to see him in the course of the day Gandhiji greeted them with, “Are you now satisfied?” Then, turning to the one who had said to him three days ago that he should get the Union Government to send them to England, he remarked: I had no answer to give you then.
('98', 231, 7, 9, 481753) I can now face you.
('98', 231, 7, 10, 481773) Shall I ask the Government to arrange a passage for you to England?
('98', 231, 7, 11, 481841) I shall say to them: Here are the unfaithful Muslims who want to desert India.
('98', 231, 7, 12, 481920) Give them the facility they want.

('98', 232, 3, 6, 482843) However, from tomorrow or the day after I may not be in a condition to move about.

('98', 232, 3, 8, 482967) 1 I have placed myself not in the hands of the doctors but in the hands of God.
('98', 232, 3, 9, 483047) I have no such attachment for life that I must live under any circumstances.
('98', 232, 3, 10, 483124) Whether I die or live is wholly in the hands of God.

('98', 232, 3, 22, 483973) True, I have to conserve my energy for the future but God will see to that.

('98', 232, 4, 39, 485048) Jivraj Mehta and Sushila Nayyar issued a health bulletin that each day’s fast increased both immediate and future danger to Gandhiji’s life.

('98', 236, 1, 2, 492642) Q. You have undertaken the fast when there was no disturbance of any kind in any part of the Indian Dominion.

('98', 236, 2, 6, 493240) Q. You have stated that you could not give any reply to the Muslims who came to you with their tale of fear and insecurity and who have complained that Sardar Patel, who is in charge of the Home Affairs, is anti Muslim.

('98', 237, 1, 2, 495244) Lest my hearers should run away with the idea that my compliment carried the meaning that I could treat the Sardar as my “yes man”, as he was affectionately described, I balanced the compliment by adding the proviso that he was too masterful to be anybody’s “yes man”.
('98', 237, 1, 3, 495513) When he was my “yes man”, he permitted himself to be so named, because whatever I said instinctively appealed to him.
('98', 237, 1, 4, 495631) Great as he was in his own field and a very able administrator, he was humble enough to begin his political education under me because, as he explained to me, he could not take to the politics in vogue at the time I began my public career in India.
('98', 237, 1, 5, 495880) When power descended on him, he saw that he could no longer successfully apply the method of non violence which he used to wield with signal success.
('98', 237, 1, 6, 496030) I have made the discovery that what I and the people with me had termed non violence was not the genuine article but a weak copy known as passive resistance.
('98', 237, 1, 7, 496188) Naturally, passive resistance can avail nothing to a ruler.
('98', 237, 1, 8, 496248) Imagine a weak ruler being able to represent any people.
('98', 237, 1, 9, 496305) He would only degrade his masters who, for the time being, had placed themselves under his trust.
('98', 237, 1, 10, 496403) I know that the Sardar could never betray or degrade his trust.
('98', 237, 1, 11, 496467) I wonder if with a knowledge of this background to my statement, anybody would dare call my fast a condemnation of the policy of the Home Ministry.
('98', 237, 1, 12, 496615) If there is any such person, I can only tell him that he would degrade and hurt himself, never the Sardar or me.
('98', 237, 1, 13, 496728) Have I not before now said emphatically that no outside power can really degrade a man?
('98', 237, 1, 14, 496816) Only he can degrade himself.
('98', 237, 1, 15, 496845) Though I know that this sentence is irrelevant here, it is such a truth that it bears repetition on all occasions.
('98', 237, 1, 16, 496960) My fast, as I have stated in plain language, is undoubtedly on behalf of the Muslim minority in the Union and, therefore, it is necessarily against the Hindus and Sikhs of the Union and the Muslims of Pakistan.
('98', 237, 1, 17, 497171) It is also on behalf of the minorities in Pakistan as in the case of the Muslim minority in the Union.
('98', 237, 1, 18, 497274) This is a clumsy compression of the idea I have already explained.
('98', 237, 1, 19, 497341) I cannot expect the fast taken by a very imperfect and weak mortal, as I truly confess I am, to have the potency to make its proteges proof against all danger.
('98', 237, 1, 20, 497501) The fast is a process of self purification for all.
('98', 237, 1, 21, 497553) It would be wrong to make any insinuation against the purity of the step.

('98', 239, 2, 3, 499730) BIRLA HOUSE, NEW DELHI, January 16, 1948
('98', 239, 3, 4, 499771) MIRA, I got your letter yesterday.

('98', 239, 3, 6, 499883) Whether it will ultimately prove so or not is neither your concern nor mine.

('98', 239, 3, 8, 500021) The fast was commenced as usual with a service, part of which was singing of “When I survey’’ 1. It was well sung by Sushila.
('98', 239, 3, 9, 500147) There were some good friends at the service.
('98', 239, 3, 10, 500192) The company was impromptu.
('98', 239, 3, 11, 500219) No one was invited.
('98', 239, 3, 12, 500239) I am dictating this immediately after the 3.30 a.

('98', 239, 3, 14, 500379) Don’t be shocked.
('98', 239, 3, 15, 500397) The food consists of 8 ozs.
('98', 239, 3, 16, 500425) of hot water sipped with difficulty.
('98', 239, 3, 17, 500462) You sip it as poison, well knowing that in result it is nectar.
('98', 239, 3, 18, 500526) It revives me whenever I take it.
('98', 239, 3, 19, 500560) Strange to say, this time I am able to take about 8 meals of this poison tasting but nectar like meal.
('98', 239, 3, 20, 500663) Yet I claim to be fasting and credulous people accept it.
('98', 239, 3, 21, 500721) What a strange world!
('98', 239, 3, 22, 500743) I shall watch and see how you can keep two typists constantly at their typewriters.
('98', 239, 3, 23, 500827) If it is only self deception and the typists a fraud on you, you will succumb and fall ill in the midst of attractive surroundings of your own choice.
('98', 239, 3, 24, 500978) One man claims that oil cakes are easier to make, cheaper in the end, and yet as effective as compost which requires a fair amount of technical skill for a kisan.
('98', 239, 3, 25, 501141) Your description of Goswami’s Goshala is tragic, if true.
('98', 239, 3, 26, 501199) It is enough to make one despair of the cow, the mother of prosperity, receiving her due in a country accused of cow worship.
('98', 239, 3, 27, 501325) There is no swaraj in such a land.
('98', 239, 3, 28, 501360) Your describing the Ashram as “Pashulok” is a magnificent idea.

('98', 241, 3, 4, 503689) PREMA, I got both your letters yesterday.
('98', 241, 3, 5, 503731) I had received the tilgur 1 on the Sankranti 2 day itself.
('98', 241, 3, 6, 503790) I saw that little bag on my desk.
('98', 241, 3, 7, 503824) The card pinned to it was on the other side.
('98', 241, 3, 8, 503869) I looked at it and read your name.
('98', 241, 3, 9, 503904) I remembered that it was the Sankranti day and understood.
('98', 241, 3, 10, 503963) I then got the parcel opened by Abha and asked her to distribute one piece as from you and the other one as from me among all those present, since, because of the fast, I myself could not partake of it.
('98', 241, 3, 11, 504166) Immediately the tilgur grains were distributed among all present.
('98', 241, 3, 12, 504232) I read your poem describing the significance of the tilgur, and was pleased.
('98', 241, 3, 13, 504309) I would never slight a religious celebration which was used to strengthen pure sentiments.
('98', 241, 3, 14, 504400) But celebrations which involve conspicuous enjoyments displease me.
('98', 241, 3, 15, 504468) Shankarrao Deo told me yesterday that you had written to him earnestly requesting him to inquire about my health daily and write to you.
('98', 241, 3, 16, 504605) If he has to do this, please consider that he will not be able to attend to his duty.
('98', 241, 3, 17, 504691) He has to go and visit different localities; should he neglect that duty in order to inquire after an old man?
('98', 241, 3, 18, 504802) Why need you also come running here to see how I am?
('98', 241, 3, 19, 504855) Please remember that there are a great many people here engaged in service of one kind or another.
('98', 241, 3, 20, 504954) If I let all of them come and see me, my fast would have to be indefinitely prolonged.
('98', 241, 3, 21, 505041) For they would then labour under the delusion that they were doing their all in looking after me and so neglect their real duty.
('98', 241, 3, 22, 505170) If you still feel that you must come, you are free to do so.
('98', 241, 3, 23, 505231) Both your letters are like beautiful poems.
('98', 241, 3, 24, 505275) I did not know that you had such great command over the language.
('98', 241, 3, 25, 505341) About the Socialists, I believe that they are self sacrificing, studious and courageous men.

('98', 241, 3, 27, 505475) If it is enough to know what appears in the newspapers about them, then that much I know, though not in great detail.

('98', 271, 3, 5, 568466) (2) provide information about our activities so far;

('98', 285, 1, 2, 595976) 287. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 285, 2, 3, 596006) NEW DELHI , January 22, 1948
('98', 285, 3, 4, 596035) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, By the grace of God, I am as you see slowly recovering my strength.
('98', 285, 3, 5, 596125) 1 I hope very soon I shall be as strong as ever.
('98', 285, 3, 6, 596174) But it is in the hands of God.
('98', 285, 3, 7, 596205) A friend writes saying that Jawaharlal may spare a room or two in his large house for the refugees, and other ministers, army officers and Government executives may also similarly spare some accommodation in their houses, but then, he asks, how many refugees can we house in this way?
('98', 285, 3, 8, 596490) There are many who give verbal assurance but only a few act on them.
('98', 285, 3, 9, 596559) I agree that only a few thousand refugees can be housed in this way.
('98', 285, 3, 10, 596628) But that is not important.
('98', 285, 3, 11, 596655) What is important is that leading men and officers will have set an example.
('98', 285, 3, 12, 596732) In England if the King makes the smallest sacrifice, like giving up a glass of wine, the gesture is greatly appreciated.
('98', 285, 3, 13, 596853) Every civilized country appreciates such gestures.
('98', 285, 3, 14, 596904) It also creates a good impression among the refugees who feel that people are doing the best for them and they too should try and face difficulties bravely.
('98', 285, 3, 15, 597061) But if this leads to people rushing to Delhi in the belief that they will be better looked after here it will spoil things.
('98', 285, 3, 16, 597185) Another difficulty has been placed before me.
('98', 285, 3, 17, 597231) People say that formerly the Congress could collect even a lakh of rupees only with the greatest difficulty.
('98', 285, 3, 18, 597340) Today it can disburse crores of rupees.
('98', 285, 3, 19, 597380) This is the power which it had been fighting for.
('98', 285, 3, 20, 597430) But they are following in the footsteps of the British Government in the matter of spending lavishly.
('98', 285, 3, 21, 597532) Some say that since we are now running the Government we must spend lavishly and live in style, otherwise our prestige outside India will suffer.
('98', 285, 3, 22, 597678) But if we want to compete with the British in the lavishness they show in maintaining their dignity, we shall have to be as well off as they are.
('98', 285, 3, 23, 597824) But our per capita income is nowhere near that of England.
('98', 285, 3, 24, 597883) We are an extremely poor country.
('98', 285, 3, 25, 597917) If, therefore, we compete with others in the matter of spending we shall be destroyed.
('98', 285, 4, 26, 598004) 1 For the first time after his fast, Gandhiji was able to walk up to the prayer ground.
('98', 286, 0, 1, 598092) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 287
('98', 286, 1, 2, 598139) hope our representatives abroad will realize this.
('98', 286, 1, 3, 598190) They should not try to compete with America in throwing dinners, banquets and parties.
('98', 286, 1, 4, 598277) That even our self sacrificing Congressmen should fall into such erroneous ways is something that should make us sit up and think.
('98', 286, 1, 5, 598408) People also object to ministers getting higher salaries than other people.
('98', 286, 1, 6, 598483) If Sardar Patel is paid Rs. 1,500 a month, then they say they should at least be paid Rs. 500. This is not the way of living in India.
('98', 286, 1, 7, 598618) When we are all trying to purify ourselves why should we think along such lines?
('98', 286, 1, 8, 598699) We do not judge people by the money they have.
('98', 286, 1, 9, 598746) I have read out to you the wire describing the plight of certain Muslims in Gwalior.
('98', 286, 1, 10, 598831) 1 A worker from there came to me saying that he had good news.
('98', 286, 1, 11, 598894) He says that the Maharaja of Gwalior has handed over all power to the people.
('98', 286, 1, 12, 598972) 2 But if the Praja Mandal people show discrimination and drive out Muslims, how can I be happy over it?
('98', 286, 1, 13, 599076) I shall be happy if you tell me that there will be no discrimination and that no ill will would be shown against anyone, be he a Hindu or Muslim or Parsi or Christian.
('98', 286, 1, 14, 599244) Then I shall congratulate you and bless you.
('98', 286, 1, 15, 599289) The Maharaja has become the servant of the people.
('98', 286, 1, 16, 599340) In this yajna of self purification everyone, including the ruler and the ruled, should participate.
('98', 286, 1, 17, 599440) Only then shall we be able to stand before the world.
('98', 286, 1, 18, 599494) If we want to carry the world on the right path and save it there is no other way before us.
('98', 286, 2, 19, 599587) [From Hindi]
('98', 286, 3, 20, 599600) Courtesy: All India Radio.
('98', 286, 3, 21, 599627) Also Prarthana Pravachan—II, pp.
('98', 286, 4, 22, 599660) 288. WORTHY OF REFLECTION3
('98', 286, 5, 23, 599687) A young man 4 writes 5:
('98', 286, 6, 24, 599711) Today at noon I learnt that you had commenced fasting.
('98', 286, 6, 25, 599766) I resisted the temptation of writing to you during the fast.
('98', 286, 6, 26, 599827) But I can do so no longer.
('98', 286, 6, 27, 599854) 1. It is idle to think that a fast of five or seven days on your part can establish heart unity between the Hindus and Muslims.
('98', 286, 6, 28, 599982) What your fast will do will be to make the Hindus suppress their anger .
('98', 286, 6, 29, 600055) And I think it
('98', 286, 7, 30, 600070) 1 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 20 1 1948. 2 The Maharaja of Gwalior had announced his decision to form an interim government having the support of the majority party in the legislature.
('98', 286, 7, 31, 600260) 3 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 1 2 1948. 4 Kanti Gandhi; vide “Letter to Kanti Gandhi”, 23 1 1948. 5 Only excerpts from the letter are reproduced here.
('98', 287, 0, 1, 600440) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 287, 1, 2, 600482) should be enough to induce you to end your fast.
('98', 287, 1, 3, 600531) 2. By your penance you have gained a unique place in the hearts and affection of the people.
('98', 287, 1, 4, 600624) .They will, therefore, suppress their anger and hatred in order to save your life.
('98', 287, 1, 5, 600707) But this pent up anger is sure to burst out at the first opportunity.
('98', 287, 1, 6, 600777) 3. If anger and hatred are to be purged out of the hearts of the people, the Government ought to teach them to base their lives on constructive work.
('98', 287, 1, 7, 600927) .In America, they are tending more and more to revert to natural manures.
('98', 287, 1, 8, 601001) We seem to be going in for the production of chemical fertilizers.
('98', 287, 1, 9, 601068) 4. I can say from my experience that the Indian Muslims are not so innocent as they might appear....a large majority of them are simply biding their time and waiting for an opportunity to play the fifth columnists when Pakistan invades India.
('98', 287, 1, 10, 601311) 5. In view of the foregoing, I feel that your fast was not meant to achieve anything more than making the Hindus restrain their passions.
('98', 287, 1, 11, 601449) 6. I hold that the Hindu Muslim trouble can be resolved only in two ways.
('98', 287, 1, 12, 601523) First, by the Hindus completely cleansing their hearts.
('98', 287, 1, 13, 601579) That expectation may be said to have been belied long ago.
('98', 287, 1, 14, 601638) As you have observed, the Congress struggle has so far been based on the passive resistance of the weak.
('98', 287, 1, 15, 601743) Therefore, now that power has come to it, it will rush towards himsa with redoubled speed.
('98', 287, 1, 16, 601834) .The other way is for the Indian Government to handle the situation with firmness.
('98', 287, 1, 17, 601917) This, it seems to me, it has failed to do so far and to that extent— thanks to your influence—the interest of the country has suffered.
('98', 287, 1, 18, 602053) The foregoing letter deserves careful attention.
('98', 287, 1, 19, 602102) Contrary to what the correspondent holds, instances can be adduced of instantaneous change of heart.
('98', 287, 1, 20, 602203) It would have been more apt to say that such heart change is transitory.
('98', 287, 1, 21, 602276) Now that my fast is over, it remains to be seen what result it produces.
('98', 287, 1, 22, 602349) I say this not to deprecate or detract from what the writer of the foregoing letter has said.
('98', 287, 1, 23, 602443) Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs—all may learn something from it.
('98', 287, 1, 24, 602499) The ideal of communal unity is not a new one.
('98', 287, 1, 25, 602545) It has always been before the country as one of the pillars of national independence.
('98', 287, 1, 26, 602631) Without it independence cannot last.
('98', 287, 1, 27, 602668) This has been regarded as more or less axiomatic.
('98', 287, 1, 28, 602718) the transition period, which I hope is now over, reflected our distemper.
('98', 287, 1, 29, 602792) We may, therefore, expect that the unity that has been established in Delhi will prove enduring.
('98', 288, 0, 1, 602889) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 289
('98', 288, 1, 2, 602936) That the edifice of unity can rest on constructive work alone is a maxim which everybody should remember.
('98', 288, 1, 3, 603042) The question is how to realize it.
('98', 288, 1, 4, 603077) It is up to every worker who believes in it to live it in his life and to bring it home to his neighbours.
('98', 288, 1, 5, 603184) By explaining the scientific basis of the constructive programme, it can be made interesting.
('98', 288, 1, 6, 603278) Our daily experience shows that this programme cannot be advanced by mechanical or unintelligent work.
('98', 288, 1, 7, 603381) That tractors and chemical fertilizers will spell our ruin, I have not a shadow of a doubt.
('98', 288, 1, 8, 603473) I do not regard all the Muslims of India to be innocent.
('98', 288, 1, 9, 603530) What is obvious is that after the birth of Pakistan the Muslims in the Indian Union have been placed in a very difficult situation and it is up to the majority community to mete out exact justice to them.
('98', 288, 1, 10, 603735) It would spell the ruin of both the Hindu religion and the majority community if the latter, in the intoxication of power, entertains the belief that it can crush the minority community and establish a purely Hindu Raj.
('98', 288, 1, 11, 603955) I consider the present occasion to be particularly auspicious for purging out the dross from the hearts of both the communities by a strenuous effort at self purification.
('98', 288, 1, 12, 604127) The meaning of the fifth paragraph is not quite clear.
('98', 288, 1, 13, 604182) In any case, my fast being for the purification of all, I expected and still expect all—be they Hindu, Muslim or others—to turn the searchlight inward and to cast out all hidden impurity.
('98', 288, 1, 14, 604370) In the sixth paragraph I find only dry logic.
('98', 288, 1, 15, 604416) It ignores the heart.
('98', 288, 1, 16, 604438) No one has a right to say that what could not be achieved during the struggle for independence is unachievable at all times.
('98', 288, 1, 17, 604563) On the contrary, today there is a real opportunity to demonstrate the supremacy of ahimsa.
('98', 288, 1, 18, 604654) True, our people have been sucked into the whirlpool of universal militarization.
('98', 288, 1, 19, 604736) If even a few can keep out of it, it will be their privilege to set an example of ahimsa of the brave and be reckoned as the first servants of India.
('98', 288, 1, 20, 604886) This cannot be demonstrated by intellect.
('98', 288, 1, 21, 604928) Therefore, till it can be realized through experience, it must be accepted on faith.
('98', 288, 1, 22, 605013) The Swaraj Government is bound to proceed with firmness and courage.
('98', 288, 1, 23, 605082) A government which is weak or which allows itself to be led into courses which its reason does not approve of, is not fit to rule.
('98', 288, 1, 24, 605213) It ought to step aside and make way for a better one.
('98', 288, 1, 25, 605267) To say or to believe that Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and Sardar Patel have weakened under my influence is to betray gross ignorance of their character.
('98', 289, 0, 1, 605416) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 289, 1, 2, 605458) And if my influence has really the enervating effect imputed to it by my correspondent, it is a thing for me to be ashamed of and for the country to deplore as detrimental to its very existence.
('98', 289, 1, 3, 605653) NEW DELHI , January 23, 1948
('98', 289, 2, 4, 605682) Harijan, 1 2 1948
('98', 289, 3, 5, 605700) 289. LETTER TO MANU GANDHI
('98', 289, 4, 6, 605727) BIRLA HOUSE, NEW DELHI , After prayer, 6 a.

('98', 289, 5, 8, 605792) MANUDI, I have been looking into your diary for quite a few days.
('98', 289, 5, 9, 605858) I am very pleased.
('98', 289, 5, 10, 605877) You have passed the test.
('98', 289, 5, 11, 605903) You have shown great devotion in serving me.
('98', 289, 5, 12, 605948) Whether in the family or outside I have not met a girl of your purity.
('98', 289, 5, 13, 606019) That is why I became a mother to no one but you.
('98', 289, 5, 14, 606068) Why is it that though your diary shows your mental anguish you have not expressed it to me?
('98', 289, 5, 15, 606160) Why should you be concerned about .
('98', 289, 5, 16, 606196) 1 or anyone else?
('98', 289, 5, 17, 606214) That girl has been deceiving me but in reality those who seek to deceive me are themselves deceived.
('98', 289, 5, 18, 606315) The service you have rendered in this great yajna is of inestimable value to me.
('98', 289, 5, 19, 606396) Your only offence is that you have let your body be ruined in the process, not so much from physical work as from your native reticence.
('98', 289, 5, 20, 606533) Who knows but that there may be another bomb explosion and with Ramanama on my lips I may be taken away from you?
('98', 289, 5, 21, 606647) If that happens you will have won a total victory, only I shall not be there to watch it.
('98', 289, 5, 22, 606737) But these scribbled words will remain and so will you.
('98', 289, 5, 23, 606792) As for me, I shall think I have won a victory only when you transform yourself from an old woman of seventy which you look like today, into a blooming maiden of seventeen.
('98', 289, 5, 24, 606964) You see how God is helping us.
('98', 289, 5, 25, 606995) Everyone is appearing in his true colours.
('98', 289, 5, 26, 607038) In the Congress too there is so much confusion.
('98', 289, 5, 27, 607086) Today I have written you a long letter.
('98', 289, 5, 28, 607126) Please send a copy to Jaisukhlal.

('98', 292, 4, 6, 611157) 293. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('98', 292, 5, 7, 611187) NEW DELHI , January 23, 1948
('98', 292, 6, 8, 611216) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I have many things to say today.
('98', 292, 6, 9, 611271) I shall try to deal with as many as I can.
('98', 292, 6, 10, 611314) Today is Subhas Babu’s birthday.
('98', 292, 6, 11, 611347) I have told you I cannot remember anyone’s Birthday or death anniversary.
('98', 292, 6, 12, 611421) Someone reminded me of Subhas Babu’s birthday.
('98', 292, 6, 13, 611468) Subhas Babu was a votary of violence while I am a devotee of ahimsa.
('98', 292, 6, 14, 611537) But what does it matter?
('98', 292, 6, 15, 611562) I know that the most important thing is that we should learn from other people’s virtues.
('98', 292, 6, 16, 611652) As Tulsidas says:
('98', 292, 7, 17, 611670) The Lord has created this world full of lifeless and living things and virtues and vices.
('98', 292, 7, 18, 611760) The wise like the swan take the milk of virtue and leave out the waste of water.
('98', 292, 7, 19, 611841) We should be like the swan and take the milk of virtue.
('98', 292, 7, 20, 611897) Man has virtues as well as vices.
('98', 292, 7, 21, 611931) We should emulate him in his virtues and forget his deficiencies.
('98', 292, 7, 22, 611997) Subhas was a great patriot.
('98', 292, 7, 23, 612025) He laid down his life for the country.
('98', 292, 7, 24, 612064) He was not by nature a fighter but he became commander of an army and took up arms against a great empire.
('98', 292, 7, 25, 612171) The soldiers of that army included Hindus, Muslims, Parsis and Christians.
('98', 292, 7, 26, 612246) He never considered himself only a Bengali.
('98', 292, 7, 27, 612290) He had no use for parochialism or caste distinctions.
('98', 292, 7, 28, 612344) In his eyes all were Indians and servants of India.
('98', 292, 7, 29, 612396) He treated all alike.
('98', 292, 7, 30, 612418) It never occurred to him that since he was the commander he deserved more and others less.

('98', 294, 4, 25, 616845) 294. HIS MAJESTY’S OPPOSITION
('98', 294, 5, 26, 616875) Great Britain prides itself on possessing the “Mother of Parliaments”.
('98', 294, 5, 27, 616946) The method prevailing there is to maintain at Government cost “His Majesty’s Opposition” to keep the Ministers within bounds by directing the flood light of public criticism on the steps taken or proposed to be taken by the Government....
('98', 294, 5, 28, 617185) Our country has taken up the reins of government.
('98', 294, 5, 29, 617235) If we desire to pursue non violence, what shall be the form of our government?
('98', 294, 5, 30, 617314) Our Government also will need a corrective force to perform the functions of an “Opposition”....
('98', 294, 5, 31, 617411) What we should aim at is not to replace the ministers, but to hold up models that they should follow.
('98', 294, 5, 32, 617513) The constructive workers should direct them into proper channels by the beaconlight of their example.
('98', 294, 5, 33, 617615) This is a great responsibility that would devolve upon the constructive workers in a
('98', 295, 0, 1, 617700) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 295, 1, 2, 617742) non violent economy.
('98', 295, 1, 3, 617763) A well organized body of constructive workers will be needed to provide this directive force.
('98', 295, 1, 4, 617857) Their service to the people will be their sanction and the merit of their work will be their charter.
('98', 295, 1, 5, 617959) The ministers will draw their inspiration from such a body which will advise and guide the secular government.
('98', 295, 1, 6, 618070) To be able to discharge this function the constructive workers forming such a body will have to be drawn from men of renunciation, whose one aim and ambition is the service of the people.
('98', 295, 1, 7, 618258) In a political structure of this nature the body of constructive workers will form the bulwark of safety for the people against exploitation.
('98', 295, 1, 8, 618400) A government run on this basis will give the needed emphasis to the affairs of the people and ensure their welfare, bringing in swaraj to the masses.
('98', 295, 1, 9, 618550) This is very attractive.
('98', 295, 1, 10, 618575) 1 But it has to be confessed that we have not the requisite number of selfless workers capable of giving a good account of themselves.

('98', 300, 8, 18, 628296) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, People say that we have achieved heart unity.
('98', 300, 8, 19, 628364) I question both Muslims and Hindus and they all say that they have realized the futility of going on fighting with each other.
('98', 300, 8, 20, 628491) I will not ask how many Muslims there are at this meeting.

('98', 300, 8, 27, 628954) Even the stone lattice work was demolished.
('98', 300, 8, 28, 628998) Now it has been repaired somewhat and the Urs will take place as usual.
('98', 300, 8, 29, 629070) I do not know how many Muslims will go there but I know that formerly a large number of them visited the Urs and so did a large number of Hindus.
('98', 300, 9, 30, 629216) 1 A religious fair held annually at the shrine of Khwaja Syed Kutub ud Din Bakhtiar
('98', 301, 0, 1, 629300) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 301, 1, 2, 629342) that this time too Hindus will go there with peaceful intent and reverent hearts.
('98', 301, 1, 3, 629424) Let them not mock or malign the Muslims who will be going to the fair.
('98', 301, 1, 4, 629495) The police of course will be there but these should be as few as possible, you should all act as policemen yourselves and make sure that everything functions smoothly.
('98', 301, 1, 5, 629663) At any rate you have earned a good name.

('98', 301, 1, 8, 629905) All of them say that we have achieved here something very great, that they had been fearing that with the British having left the country we Indians being stupid and inexperienced in the ways of governing would destroy ourselves in a civil war.

('98', 301, 1, 15, 630703) Whenever there is a meeting of the Congress Working Committee at which I am present I give you some idea of what is transacted there.
('98', 301, 1, 16, 630837) Today there was a second meeting of the Congress Working Committee and many matters were discussed there.
('98', 301, 1, 17, 630943) You may not be interested in everything that was taken up for discussion but one thing I may tell you.
('98', 301, 1, 18, 631046) The Congress had decided some twenty years ago that there should be as many provinces in the country as there are major languages.
('98', 301, 1, 19, 631177) The Congress had also said that as soon as power came into its hands such linguistic provinces would be formed.
('98', 301, 1, 20, 631289) For that matter we have nine or ten provinces even today—all under a central authority.
('98', 301, 1, 21, 631377) If new provinces are formed and they are all placed under the authority of Delhi there is no harm in it.
('98', 301, 1, 22, 631482) But it will be very bad if they all want to be free and refuse to accept central authority.
('98', 301, 1, 23, 631574) It should not be that Bombay then will have nothing to do with Maharashtra and Maharashtra with Karnataka and Karnataka with Andhra.
('98', 301, 1, 24, 631707) Let all live as brothers.
('98', 301, 1, 25, 631733) Moreover if linguistic provinces are formed it will also give a fillip to the regional languages.
('98', 301, 1, 26, 631831) It would be absurd to make Hindustani the medium of instruction in all the regions and it is still more absurd to use English for this purpose.
