('98', 302, 1, 2, 632063) 301. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING1
('98', 302, 2, 3, 632094) NEW DELHI , January 26, 1948
('98', 302, 3, 4, 632123) This day, 26th January, is Independence Day.
('98', 302, 3, 5, 632168) This observance was quite appropriate when we were fighting for independence we had not seen nor handled.
('98', 302, 3, 6, 632274) Now we have handled it and we seem to be disillusioned.
('98', 302, 3, 7, 632330) At least I am, even if you are not.
('98', 302, 3, 8, 632366) What are we celebrating today?
('98', 302, 3, 9, 632397) Surely not our disillusionment.
('98', 302, 3, 10, 632429) We are entitled to celebrate the hope that the worst is over and that we are on the road to showing the lowliest of the villager that it means his freedom from serfdom and that he is no longer a serf born to serve the cities and towns of India but that he is destined to exploit the city dwellers for the advertisement of the finished fruits of well thought out labours, that he is the salt of the Indian earth and that it means also equality of all classes and creeds, never the domination and superiority of the major community over a minor, however insignificant it may be in numbers or influence.
('98', 302, 3, 11, 633030) Let us not defer the hope and make the heart sick.
('98', 302, 3, 12, 633081) Yet, what are the strikes and a variety of lawlessnesses but a deferring of the hope?
('98', 302, 3, 13, 633167) These are symptoms of our sickness and weakness.
('98', 302, 3, 14, 633216) Let labour realize its dignity and strength.
('98', 302, 3, 15, 633261) Capital has neither dignity nor strength compared to labour.
('98', 302, 3, 16, 633322) These the man in the street also has.
('98', 302, 3, 17, 633360) In a well ordered democratic society there is no room, no occasion, for lawlessness or strikes.
('98', 302, 3, 18, 633456) In such a society there are ample lawful means for vindicating justice.
('98', 302, 3, 19, 633528) Violence veiled or unveiled must be taboo.
('98', 302, 3, 20, 633571) Strikes in Kanpur, coal mines or elsewhere mean material loss to the whole society not excluding the strikers themselves.
('98', 302, 3, 21, 633693) I need not be reminded that this declamation does not lie well in the mouth of one like me who has been responsible for so many successful strikes.
('98', 302, 3, 22, 633841) If there be such critics they ought not to forget that then there was neither independence nor the kind of legislation we now have.
('98', 302, 3, 23, 633973) I wonder if we can remain free from the fever of power politics or the bid for power which afflicts the political world, the East and the West.
('98', 302, 3, 24, 634117) Before leaving this topic of the day, let us permit ourselves to hope that though geographically and politically India is divided into two, at heart we shall ever be friends and brothers helping and respecting one another and be one for the outside world.
('98', 302, 4, 25, 634373) 1 It being Gandhiji’s silence day, Pyarelal translated the written speech into Hindustani and read it out after the prayers.
('98', 303, 0, 1, 634498) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 303, 1, 2, 634540) Decontrol of cloth 1 has been welcomed in all quarters.
('98', 303, 1, 3, 634596) There never was a scarcity of cloth.
('98', 303, 1, 4, 634633) How can it be when there is enough cotton and enough hands in the land for spinning and weaving?
('98', 303, 1, 5, 634730) Equally welcome is the removal of control on firewood and coal.
('98', 303, 1, 6, 634794) It is remarkable that there is now a glut in the market of gur, the poor man’s supply for caloric deficiency.
('98', 303, 1, 7, 634904) There would be no remedy for glut nor for reaching places outside the boundary of production unless there is quick locomotion.
('98', 303, 1, 8, 635031) Let a correspondent in the know speak on this subject:
('98', 303, 2, 9, 635086) Needless to say that efficiency of the rail and road transport is the chief factor for the success of the decontrol policy.
('98', 303, 2, 10, 635210) If there is no improvement in the railway transport there is a danger of countrywide famine and the entire collapse of the decontrols.
('98', 303, 2, 11, 635345) The present working of the railway transport is a living danger to these decontrols and controls alike.
('98', 303, 2, 12, 635449) The terrible contrast of different prices prevalent in different parts of India for the same commodity is chiefly due to this transport bottleneck.
('98', 303, 2, 13, 635597) If gur is sold at Rs. 8 per maund at Rohtak and at Rs. 50 in Bombay, we must say there is something wrong with the working of the railways.
('98', 303, 2, 14, 635737) Thousands of wagons in the length and breadth of the country are not kept moving.
('98', 303, 2, 15, 635819) Wagons are not even unloaded for months and months together.
('98', 303, 2, 16, 635880) Corruption is rampant in a most virulent form in the booking of these wagons, in the garb of ‘scarcity of wagons and coal’ and ‘priority for different commodities’.
('98', 303, 2, 17, 636045) For the booking of one wagonload one has to spend hundreds of rupees and spend days together in the railway yards.
('98', 303, 2, 18, 636160) Even the best efforts of the worthy Transport Minister 2 have cut no ice in so far as the supply of these wagons and their constant moving is concerned.
('98', 303, 2, 19, 636313) The entire rail and road transport requires a complete overhauling by the Transport Minister to make the decontrols a thorough success.
('98', 303, 2, 20, 636449) Then only decontrols shall prove a blessing to the poor for the benefit of whom they are being pursued.
('98', 303, 2, 21, 636553) Millions of villagers, farmers and labourers are hit owing to the defective system in this rail and road transport as their produce seldom reaches the market.
('98', 303, 2, 22, 636712) As stated in my previous letter, the rationing of petrol ought to be removed and monopoly and permit system of the road transport may be abolished altogether.
('98', 303, 2, 23, 636871) This monopoly system is benefiting a few transport companies only but has rendered the lives of millions and millions of our countrymen difficult.
('98', 303, 2, 24, 637018) Ninety five per cent of the success in decontrols solely depends upon
('98', 303, 3, 25, 637088) 1 The Government had decided to decontrol cloth from January 19. 2 John Matthai
('98', 304, 0, 1, 637168) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 305
('98', 304, 1, 2, 637215) the efficient working of the railways and vehicles, i.
('98', 304, 1, 3, 637270) e., in keeping the wagons moving, and abolishing the rationing of petrol and the permit and monopoly system of the lorries.
('98', 304, 1, 4, 637394) This shall bring from the remotest corners of the country lakhs of tons of foodstuffs and all other produce profusely to the entire markets of the land.
('98', 304, 1, 5, 637547) The subject of corruption referred to by the correspondent is not new.
('98', 304, 1, 6, 637618) Only it has become much worse than before.
('98', 304, 1, 7, 637661) Restraint from without has practically gone.
('98', 304, 1, 8, 637706) Corruption will go when the large number of persons given to the unworthy practice realize that the nation does not exist for them but that they do for the nation.
('98', 304, 1, 9, 637870) It requires a high code of morals, extreme vigilance on the part of those who are free from the corrupt practice and who have influence over corrupt servants.

('98', 304, 3, 13, 638241) 302. CONGRESS POSITION
('98', 304, 4, 14, 638264) Indian National Congress which is the oldest national political organization and which has after many battles fought her non violent way to freedom cannot be allowed to die.
('98', 304, 4, 15, 638438) It can only die with the nation.
('98', 304, 4, 16, 638471) A living organism ever grows or it dies.
('98', 304, 4, 17, 638512) The Congress has won political freedom, but it has yet to win economic freedom, social and moral freedom.
('98', 304, 4, 18, 638618) These freedoms are harder than the political, if only because they are constructive, less exciting and not spectacular.
('98', 304, 4, 19, 638738) All embracing constructive work evokes the energy of all the units of the millions.
('98', 304, 4, 20, 638822) The Congress has got the preliminary and necessary part of her freedom.
('98', 304, 4, 21, 638894) The hardest has yet to come.
('98', 304, 4, 22, 638923) In its difficult ascent to democracy, it has inevitably created rotten boroughs leading to corruption and creation of institutions popular and democratic only in name.
('98', 304, 4, 23, 639091) How to get out of the weedy and unwieldy growth?
('98', 304, 4, 24, 639140) The Congress must do away with its special register of members, at no time exceeding one crore, not even then easily identifiable.
('98', 304, 4, 25, 639271) It had an unknown register of millions who could never be wanted.
('98', 304, 4, 26, 639337) Its register should now be co extensive with all the men and women on the voters’ rolls in the country.
('98', 304, 4, 27, 639441) The Congress business should be to see that no faked name gets in and no legitimate name is left out.
('98', 305, 0, 1, 639543) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 305, 1, 2, 639585) its own register it will have a body of servants of the nation who would be workers doing the work allotted to them from time to time.
('98', 305, 1, 3, 639720) Unfortunately for the country they will be drawn chiefly for the time being from the city dwellers, most of whom would be required to work for and in the villages of India.
('98', 305, 1, 4, 639893) The ranks must be filled in increasing numbers from the villagers.
('98', 305, 1, 5, 639960) These servants will be expected to operate upon and serve the voters registered according to law, in their own surroundings.
('98', 305, 1, 6, 640085) Many persons and parties will woo them.
('98', 305, 1, 7, 640125) The very best will win.
('98', 305, 1, 8, 640149) Thus and in no other way can the Congress regain its fast ebbing unique position in the country.
('98', 305, 1, 9, 640246) But yesterday the Congress was unwittingly the servant of the nation, it was Khudai khidmatgar—God’s servant.
('98', 305, 1, 10, 640356) Let it now proclaim to itself and the world that it is only God’s servant—nothing more, nothing less.
('98', 305, 1, 11, 640458) If it engages in the ungainly skirmish for power, it will find one fine morning that it is no more.

('98', 306, 1, 7, 642165) Now that the Bombay Government have passed a law to that effect there seems to be no occasion for satyagraha.
('98', 306, 1, 8, 642275) If the law is in conformity with public opinion it should command respect.
('98', 306, 1, 9, 642350) If it is against public opinion, its enforcement will be rather slow.
('98', 306, 1, 10, 642420) In a democracy a law cannot be enforced through coercion.
('98', 306, 1, 11, 642478) It always calls for discerning circumsp ection.
('98', 306, 1, 12, 642526) It will succeed if a reformer takes recourse to it with clear understanding.
('98', 306, 1, 13, 642603) If he is impatient the law will prove a failure.
('98', 306, 1, 14, 642652) Trustees are not the owners of the temples.

('98', 306, 1, 21, 643104) It was enough that I looked a Hindu.
('98', 306, 1, 22, 643141) So where Hindus go Harijans can also go.
('98', 306, 1, 23, 643182) Harijans are not a separate community.
('98', 306, 1, 24, 643221) Enlightened public opinion and the law which embodies that opinion say that they are one of the varnas, be they four or eighteen, comprising Hindu society.
('98', 306, 1, 25, 643377) Therefore the contrary view cannot prevail.
('98', 306, 1, 26, 643421) It is the devotees who make of God a living entity.
('98', 306, 1, 27, 643473) If they are good, the God is good.

('98', 309, 4, 20, 648376) 307. INTERVIEW TO KINGSLEY MARTIN2
('98', 309, 5, 21, 648411) NEW DELHI, January 27, 1948
('98', 309, 6, 22, 648439) Gandhiji explained how the freedom movement had not been a non violent movement in the highest sense of the term.
('98', 309, 6, 23, 648553) If it had been the non violence of the strong no butchery such as had taken place recently could have come about.
('98', 309, 6, 24, 648667) He discovered this while he was on his pilgrimage in Noakhali and ever since this discovery he had been impressing the fact on everyone.
('98', 309, 6, 25, 648804) He felt that non violence during the struggle for independence was an expedient, i.
('98', 309, 6, 26, 648888) e., resistance to the white man was undertaken in a non violent manner simply because we had no military strength with which to offer battle.
('98', 309, 7, 27, 649030) Gandhiji went on to relate how he had resisted a certain millionaire in South Africa who had introduced him at a public meeting as a mere passive resister and weak
('98', 309, 8, 28, 649194) 1 Non Muslims waiting for evacuation in a camp at Parachinar were attacked by tribesmen on the night of January 22. According to the local authorities, 130 were killed, 50 wounded and 50 abducted.
('98', 309, 8, 29, 649391) 2 A British press correspondent.
('98', 309, 8, 30, 649424) Notes of this interview taken by Amrit Kaur were approved by Gandhiji.
('98', 310, 0, 1, 649495) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 311
('98', 310, 1, 2, 649542) because as an Indian there he was landless and without any rights.
('98', 310, 1, 3, 649609) 1 Gandhiji objected to this description and said that real passive resistance had been miscalled a weapon of the weak.
('98', 310, 1, 4, 649728) After all Jesus Christ had been called the Prince of passive resisters.
('98', 310, 1, 5, 649800) Could he, in any sense of the term, be called a weak man?
('98', 310, 1, 6, 649858) People forget that soul force, the only weapon of the truly non violent man, was a weapon of the strong.
('98', 310, 2, 7, 649963) In reply to the correspondent’s suggestion that many people looked upon non violence as a good opposition weapon in politics and that they could not understand how it could, for example, be used as a positive weapon in Kashmir today or against a man like Hitler who just killed everybody and stamped out opposition in that manner, Gandhiji laughingly replied that he was not in charge of the Government and therefore could not guide their policies; nor did he think that the members of the present Government believed in non violence.
('98', 310, 2, 8, 650498) He recalled how Maulana Saheb had said, “When we gain power we shall not be able to hold it non violently.” Gandhiji said that he had laughed to himself at that time and related the moral of Tolstoy’s story of Ivan the Fool which had always remained with him.
('98', 310, 2, 9, 650758) Hindu scriptures, Gandhiji said, had scores of such stories but he quoted Ivan the Fool because the interviewer might have read the book.
('98', 310, 2, 10, 650896) Ivan remained non violent even when he became king.
('98', 310, 2, 11, 650948) Gandhiji pointed out how the truly non violent man could never hold power himself.
('98', 310, 2, 12, 651031) He derived power from the people whom he served.
('98', 310, 2, 13, 651080) For such a man or such a government, a non violent army would be a perfect possibility.
('98', 310, 2, 14, 651168) The voters then would themselves say, ‘We do not want any military for our defence.’ A non violent army would fight against all injustice or attack but with clean weapons.
('98', 310, 2, 15, 651340) Non violence did not signify that man must not fight against the enemy and by enemy was meant the evil which men did, not human beings themselves.
('98', 310, 2, 16, 651487) He went on to say that if he were the leader of Kashmir like Sheikh Abdullah, he would have such an army but Sheikh Abdullah quite honestly and humbly thought otherwise.
('98', 310, 3, 17, 651657) On the correspondent suggesting a solution of the Kashmir issue on the basis of separation, e.
('98', 310, 3, 18, 651752) g., a predominantly pro Pakistan area like Poonch going to Pakistan and the Kashmir Valley remaining in India Gandhiji had no difficulty in giving a firm answer in the negative.
('98', 310, 3, 19, 651930) He held firmly that India or any part of India could not be divided in this manner.
('98', 310, 3, 20, 652014) It was an evil that must not be allowed to continue.
('98', 310, 4, 21, 652067) 1 According to “A Correction” sent by H. S. L. Polak which appeared in Harijan, 5 9 1948, the reference was obviously to William Hosken who though a well to do businessman, was not a millionaire.

('98', 310, 4, 24, 652543) They are weak and have no arms.

('98', 311, 1, 2, 652697) Take, for example, Hyderabad; will you separate the town of Hyderabad from the rest of the State?
('98', 311, 1, 3, 652795) Such pockets exist all over India and separation would then become an endless process spelling the ruination of India.
('98', 311, 2, 4, 652914) The interviewer pleaded that the position of Hyderabad was not wholly analogous.
('98', 311, 2, 5, 652995) Any state on a border area was surely different.
('98', 311, 2, 6, 653044) But Gandhiji maintained that it was not possible for states even on the border to be either cut up or separated or .

('98', 311, 2, 11, 653537) It had been a big bite even for Britain.

('98', 311, 4, 21, 654388) there are no Gandhis in Palestine, in Russia or in the U. S. A. !”, to which Gandhiji laughingly replied: So much the worse for them.
('98', 311, 5, 22, 654522) In reply to a query as to why Poonch going over to Pakistan was not practicable and that a war between India and the Frontier would be unending, Gandhiji replied that it would be a very bad example to others.

('98', 311, 5, 25, 654968) Gandhiji quoted the example of Kathiawar.
('98', 311, 5, 26, 655010) Pakistan wanted to vivisect Kathiawar by getting Junagadh to accede to that Dominion.
('98', 311, 5, 27, 655096) Vivisection of Kathiawar which was indivisible was quite unthinkable.

('98', 312, 2, 4, 655558) He himself was working for a heart union between Hindus and Muslims not only in India but in Pakistan also and would continue his efforts in that direction.

('98', 312, 3, 6, 655734) 308. A DISCUSSION1
('98', 312, 4, 7, 655753) January [27], 2 1948
('98', 312, 5, 8, 655774) Mr. Diwakar and myself 3met Mahatmaji to consult him on some of the important points relating to the changes in the Congress Constitution.
('98', 312, 5, 9, 655913) The following is a summary of the talk we had with him:
('98', 312, 6, 10, 655969) On the question of general membership, on being asked whether the membership of the Congress should be open to all who subscribed to its creed or whether it should be further restricted to those who also agreed with the fundamentals of its socio economic programme, Mahatmaji was of opinion that there need be no necessity for enrolment of members even on the present basis.
('98', 312, 6, 11, 656344) Instead, he suggested that the constituencies should be so limited in area that all adults residing in that locality could participate in the elections to the primary committees, irrespective of the fact whether they formally subscribed to the creed and programme of the Congress or not.
('98', 312, 6, 12, 656632) The reason he advanced in favour of this was, firstly, that the constituency being small every adult in it would be able to exercise his or her judgment in favour of a candidate about whose conduct and work he or she could properly judge.
('98', 312, 6, 13, 656871) The Congress should henceforward be an organization of sevaks who possessed missionary zeal to be able to effect a radical change in the society ensuring justice, tolerance and economic equality.
('98', 312, 6, 14, 657067) Only through such a change in the social outlook could the state be reformed and restrained.
('98', 312, 7, 15, 657160) Secondly, and consequently he wants to avoid the present system of election with its pocket or rotten boroughs and the corruption incidental to it.
('98', 312, 8, 16, 657308) 1 According to the introductory note issued with the “Draft Constitution of Congress” the Constitution Committee met Gandhiji in the morning after the Working Committee meeting held on January 26 and “had the privilege of discussing many important points”.
('98', 312, 8, 17, 657565) Gandhiji was requested to prepare a draft embodying his proposals which he undertook to hand over on January 30. Vide “Draft Constitution of Congress”, 29 1 1948. 2 ibid 3 Presumably Acharya Jugal Kishore, one of the General Secretaries of the Congress and a member of the Constitution Committee
('98', 313, 0, 1, 657861) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 313, 1, 2, 657903) Regarding the qualifications of those who are to be eligible to stand as candidates for election to the various Congress Committees he would require everyone to subscribe not only to the creed but also to the fundamentals of the socio economic programme and also to put in some kind of constructive work such as plying the charkha for a stated period or any other manual work besides doing some kind of public work.
('98', 313, 2, 3, 658319) On the question whether the Congress, now that the political power had been transferred to the representatives of Indians, had any role other than that of carrying out the parliamentary activities, Mahatmaji was very emphatic that even for carrying out parliamentary activities the Congress had to carry on constructive activities in the country to maintain contact with the people and to educate them to understand Congress policies and programmes.
('98', 313, 2, 4, 658769) But apart from this kind of activities the Congress had also to rebuild a new society based upon truth and non violence—a society not so much dependent on the existence of a strong and centralized government as on the intelligent co operation of the people organized on a voluntary basis and inspired by the ideals of justice, tolerance and truthfulness.
('98', 313, 2, 5, 659124) He was of opinion that unless the Congress took up this role, the Congress would gradually lose its moral influence and was likely to degenerate into a political party hankering only after power and position.
('98', 313, 2, 6, 659333) Viewed in this context, the Congress must reorganize itself on the basis proposed by him and become eventually a strong and efficient instrument of public service and of public will.
('98', 313, 2, 7, 659516) His suggestion regarding the question of jurisdiction of the Congress was that it should not function in the Pakistan area.
('98', 313, 2, 8, 659640) He said that formerly he was of opinion that it could function in that area but in the changed circumstances brought about by the communal frenzy it would not be proper to function there directly.
('98', 313, 2, 9, 659837) In the case of East Bengal his suggestion was that the Congress could function there if the Government of East Bengal had no objection.
('98', 313, 2, 10, 659973) Regarding States, he was of opinion that the States Peoples’ Conference should continue to function but they should have representatives on the A. I. C. C. and Provincial Congress Committees.

('98', 316, 4, 22, 666989) NEW DELHI, January 27/28, 1948
('98', 316, 5, 23, 667020) Gandhiji’s objection to the use of force was not that force could as well be used to support unrighteous wars; it was fundamental.
('98', 316, 5, 24, 667151) I do not know what is intrinsically good.
('98', 316, 5, 25, 667193) Hence I do not go by results.
('98', 316, 5, 26, 667223) It is enough if I take care of the means.
('98', 316, 6, 27, 667265) For instance, as a nature curist, he did not believe in the use of sulpha drugs.
('98', 316, 6, 28, 667346) Suppose he got typhoid.
('98', 316, 6, 29, 667370) Should he abandon his belief and try to get cured by taking sulpha drugs?
('98', 316, 6, 30, 667444) I do not know whether it is good for me or humanity to be
('98', 316, 7, 31, 667502) 1 Vincent Sheean, an American author, accompanied Gandhiji on his evening walk on January 27. The interview continued the next day.

('98', 317, 1, 2, 667676) cured by the use of sulpha drugs; so I refuse to use sulpha drugs .
('98', 317, 2, 3, 667744) If evil does seem sometimes to result from good, the inference would be that the means employed were probably wrong.
('98', 317, 2, 4, 667861) Good action to produce good results must be supported by means that are pure.
('98', 317, 3, 5, 667939) If those who believe in the idea of non violence keep away from government, government will continue to be carried on by the use of force.
('98', 317, 3, 6, 668078) How is then the transformation of the existing system of government to be brought about?
('98', 317, 4, 7, 668167) Gandhiji admitted that ordinarily government was impossible without the use of force.

('98', 317, 5, 10, 668409) No, he (the man of non violence) can send those to the Government who represent his will.
('98', 317, 5, 11, 668499) If he goes there himself, he exposes himself to the corrupting influence of power.

('98', 317, 5, 14, 668707) I cannot recall myself.

('98', 317, 7, 24, 669680) For instance, we steal in so many ways—not to steal in any shape or form needs some mental poise, contemplation.

('98', 318, 3, 27, 671478) But he did not agree that the Gita was either in intention or in the sum total an argument in defence of a righteous war.
('98', 318, 3, 28, 671600) Though the argument of the Gita was presented in a setting of physical warfare, the “righteous war” referred to in it was the eternal duel between right and wrong that is going on within us.
('98', 318, 3, 29, 671791) There was at least one authority that supported his interpretation.
('98', 318, 3, 30, 671859) The thesis of the Gita was neither violence nor non violence but the gospel of selfless action—the duty of performing right action by right means only, in a spirit of detachment, leaving the fruits of action to the care of God.
('98', 318, 4, 31, 672087) Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. II, pp.

('98', 322, 1, 2, 676976) 317. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING1
('98', 322, 2, 3, 677007) NEW DELHI, January 28, 1948
('98', 322, 3, 4, 677035) Gandhiji said he had received a complaint from some friends in Bahawalpur that they had asked for an appointment with him but failed to get it.
('98', 322, 3, 5, 677179) Gandhiji knew they were in distress and he would manage to find time for them if that would comfort them.
('98', 322, 3, 6, 677285) He, however, desired to assure them that everything possible was being done.
('98', 322, 3, 7, 677362) Dr. Sushila Nayyar and Mr. Leslie Cross went to Bahawalpur and the Nawab has promised to help them in every way.
('98', 322, 3, 8, 677475) In the Union Capital, by the grace of God, there is again peace among the three communities.
('98', 322, 3, 9, 677568) This will certainly improve the situation all over India.
('98', 322, 3, 10, 677626) You know in South Africa our people are fighting for their rights.
('98', 322, 3, 11, 677693) Here in India there are no laws depriving the people of the right of owning land or living wherever they please.
('98', 322, 3, 12, 677806) It is true we have reduced Harijans to some such condition but for the rest of society that is not so.
('98', 322, 3, 13, 677909) But I have seen with my own eyes that that is so in South Africa.
('98', 322, 3, 14, 677975) The Indians therefore are having to put up a struggle to safeguard their rights and in defence of the honour of India.
('98', 322, 3, 15, 678094) They can resort to various means in their struggle but they claim to be satyagrahis and their struggle has taken the form of satyagraha.
('98', 322, 3, 16, 678231) They keep on sending cables.
('98', 322, 3, 17, 678260) They cannot even move from one province to another without a permit.
('98', 322, 3, 18, 678329) South Africa is like a continent.
('98', 322, 3, 19, 678363) It is a very large country.
('98', 322, 3, 20, 678391) Indians wishing to go to the Transvaal from Natal can do so only if they have a permit.
('98', 322, 3, 21, 678479) They say it is as much their country as anyone else’s and ask why there should be such restrictions imposed on their movements.
('98', 322, 3, 22, 678607) Many have succeeded in moving to the Transvaal and the Government this time have been decent.
('98', 322, 3, 23, 678701) They have not been arrested so far.
('98', 322, 3, 24, 678737) They first went to Volksrust which is the first city after crossing the border.
('98', 322, 3, 25, 678817) There were policemen present in strength but they only looked on and did not arrest them.
('98', 322, 3, 26, 678907) There they found a motor vehicle and proceeded in it further on.
('98', 322, 3, 27, 678972) Then a meeting was held there at which they were given a warm welcome.
('98', 322, 3, 28, 679043) I thought I should give you this information.
('98', 322, 3, 29, 679089) Those Indians have performed an act of great courage.
('98', 322, 3, 30, 679143) Indians in South Africa are few in number but, if they all become true satyagrahis, their victory is certain and no obstacle can stop them.
('98', 322, 3, 31, 679283) But this has yet to be achieved.
('98', 322, 3, 32, 679316) There are, as
('98', 322, 4, 33, 679330) 1 The Hindi version in Prarthana Pravachan has been collated with the report in The Hindustan Times.

('98', 323, 1, 2, 679473) here, many kinds of people.

('98', 327, 10, 20, 688545) NEW DELHI, January 29, 1948
('98', 327, 11, 21, 688573) Margaret Bourke White discussed with Gandhiji the doctrine of trusteeship.
('98', 327, 11, 22, 688648) Bapu had once said that the rich should be trustees for the poor.
('98', 327, 11, 23, 688714) How did he define a trustee?
('98', 327, 12, 24, 688743) 1 This and the following item are reproduced from P. B. Chandwani’s article “The Master at Work”.
('98', 327, 12, 25, 688841) Margaret Bourke White, American photographer and Life magazine correspondent, introduced herself as the “Torturer”, a title Gandhiji had conferred on her earlier in Bengal.
('98', 328, 0, 1, 689014) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 329
('98', 328, 1, 2, 689061) A trustee is one who discharges the obligations of his trust faithfully and in the best interests of his wards.
('98', 328, 2, 3, 689173) Did he know of any industrialist who lived up to that ideal?
('98', 328, 2, 4, 689234) No, though some are striving in that direction, my host, G. D. Birla, for instance.
('98', 328, 2, 5, 689318) I hope he is not deceiving me.
('98', 328, 2, 6, 689349) If I saw him do so, I would not live under his roof.
('98', 328, 3, 7, 689402) Did he still cherish the wish and hope to live the full span of life?
('98', 328, 3, 8, 689472) He had lost that wish, Gandhiji said, in view of the prevailing darkness.
('98', 328, 3, 9, 689546) He was, however, groping for light.
('98', 328, 3, 10, 689582) If things took a turn for the better and the people responded to his call and co operated to usher in a new era of peace and amity, he would again wish—indeed, he would be “commanded” to wish to live the full span.
('98', 328, 3, 11, 689797) “Would you advise America to give up the manufacture of atom bombs?” she finally asked.
('98', 328, 3, 12, 689885) Most certainly.
('98', 328, 3, 13, 689901) As things are, the war ended disastrously and the victors are vanquished by jealousy and lust for power.
('98', 328, 3, 14, 690006) Already a third war is being canvassed, which may prove even more disastrous.
('98', 328, 3, 15, 690084) Ahimsa is a mightier weapon by far than the atom bomb.
('98', 328, 3, 16, 690139) Even if the people of Hiroshima could have died in their thousands with prayer and goodwill in their hearts, the situation would have been transfor med as if by a miracle.

('98', 331, 1, 2, 696270) I keep receiving complaints about the refugees.

('98', 332, 4, 14, 699544) 327. DRAFT CONSTITUTION OF CONGRESS2
('98', 332, 5, 15, 699581) NEW DELHI, January29, 1948
('98', 332, 6, 16, 699608) Though split into two, India having attained political independence through means devised by the Indian National Congress, the Congress in its present shape and form, i.
('98', 332, 6, 17, 699778) e., as a propaganda vehicle and parliamentary machine, has outlived its use.
('98', 332, 6, 18, 699855) India has still to attain social, moral and economic independence in terms of its seven hundred thousand villages as distinguished from its cities and towns.
('98', 332, 6, 19, 700013) The struggle for the ascendency of civil over military power is bound to take place in India’s progress towards its democratic goal.
('98', 332, 6, 20, 700146) It must be kept out of unhealthy competition with political parties and communal bodies.
('98', 332, 6, 21, 700235) For these and other similar reasons, the A. I. C. C. resolves to disband the existing Congress organization and flower into a Lok Sevak Sangh under the following rules with power to alter them as occasion may demand.
('98', 332, 7, 22, 700452) 1 Which commenced on November 6, 1913. 2 Acharya Jugal Kishore, General Secretary of A. I. C. C., released this draft to the Press on February 7, with the note: “As something has already appeared in the Press .
('98', 332, 7, 23, 700663) regarding the proposals which Mahatmaji had made concerning changes in the Congress constitution I am releasing the full draft as was handed to me on the fateful forenoon of 30th January.
('98', 332, 7, 24, 700851) .” This appeared in Harijan under the title “His Last Will and Testament”.

('98', 333, 1, 2, 701131) Every panchayat of five adult men or women being villagers or village minded shall form a unit.
('98', 333, 1, 3, 701227) Two such contiguous panchayats shall form a working party under a leader elected from among themselves.
('98', 333, 1, 4, 701331) When there are one hundred such panchayats, the fifty first grade leaders shall elect from among themselves a second grade leader and so on, the first grade leaders meanwhile working under the second grade leader.
('98', 333, 1, 5, 701545) Parallel groups of two 1 hundred panchayats shall continue to be formed till they cover the whole of India, each succeeding group of panchayats electing a second grade leader after the manner of the first.
('98', 333, 1, 6, 701751) All second grade leaders shall serve jointly for the whole of India and severally for their respective areas.
('98', 333, 1, 7, 701861) The second grade leaders may elect, when.
('98', 333, 1, 8, 701903) ever they deem necessary, from among themselves a chief who will, during pleasure, regulate and command all the groups.
('98', 333, 1, 9, 702023) (As the final formation of provinces or districts is still in a state of flux, no attempt has been made to divide this group of servants into provincial or district councils and jurisdiction over the whole of India has been vested in the group or groups that may have been formed at any given time.

('98', 339, 3, 5, 713259) Outwardly he seemed light and happy but his heart was smitten with grief at the wave of insanity which was sweeping over the land.
('98', 339, 3, 6, 713390) Either this must end or he must perish.

('98', 339, 4, 8, 713519) Chuckling with laughter he observed that nothing would be better in one sense: he would develop into a double Mahatma and attract larger crowds.
('98', 339, 4, 9, 713664) But what he wanted was not vainglory or ease but such comfort and strength as he could extract out of the prevailing darkness and misery.

('98', 340, 4, 5, 715615) NEW DELHI, January 30, 1948
('98', 340, 5, 6, 715643) “Bapu, your watch must be feeling very neglected.

('98', 340, 6, 11, 715865) The last remark he uttered as he cleared the steps leading to the prayer ground was: It is your fault that I am ten minutes late.
('98', 340, 6, 12, 715995) It is the duty of nurses to carry on their work even if God himself should be present there.
('98', 340, 6, 13, 716088) If it is time to give medicine to a patient and one feels hesitant about it, the poor patient will die.
('98', 340, 6, 14, 716192) So it is with prayers.
('98', 340, 6, 15, 716215) It irks me if I am late for prayers even by a minute.

('98', 341, 0, 1, 718018) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 341, 1, 2, 718060) 338. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('98', 341, 2, 3, 718088) Q.1. Is it possible to recite Ramanama from the heart even while talking to someone, doing arduous mental work or when mentally perturbed?
('98', 341, 2, 4, 718227) If people do so even under such conditions, how do they manage it?
('98', 341, 3, 5, 718294) A. Experience tells us that whatever the situation a person may be in, even if he may be asleep, if he has formed the habit, and if Ramanama fills his heart, recitation of Ramanama will continue as long as the heart beats.
('98', 341, 3, 6, 718517) Otherwise, it may said that he utters Ramanama only with his lips, or if occasionally it enters the heart, it certainly does not reign in the heart.
('98', 341, 3, 7, 718666) When Ramanama rules the heart, it is needless to ask how the recitation is carried on.
('98', 341, 3, 8, 718753) For, when the Name has found a place in the heart, recitation is superfluous.
('98', 341, 3, 9, 718831) It would be correct to say that those whose hearts are thus permeated by Ramanama are few.
('98', 341, 3, 10, 718922) I have no doubt that Ramanama does indeed possess the power attributed to it.
('98', 341, 3, 11, 719000) Not everyone can have Ramanama inscribed in his heart by merely wishing it.
('98', 341, 3, 12, 719076) It requires a tireless effort and also patience.
('98', 341, 3, 13, 719125) How can one find the philosopher’s stone without patience?
('98', 341, 3, 14, 719184) Ramanama is superior to it.
('98', 341, 4, 15, 719212) Q.2. Is it from a certain mental weakness that one sees so many layers of the mind, or is it necessary for the mind to pass through all these stages before reaching a state of steadiness?
('98', 341, 4, 16, 719400) Why is it that even in the waking state dreamlike visions come and go?
('98', 341, 4, 17, 719471) How is it that phantoms of things never experienced in life appear in the mind or echo in the heart?
('98', 341, 5, 18, 719572) A. Before arriving at steadiness of mind almost everyone has to pass through stages enumerated in the question.
('98', 341, 5, 19, 719684) That is to say, those who have in the former life striven without achieving success will not need to pass through agony in the present birth.
('98', 341, 5, 20, 719826) When the mind is calm but one still has dream like experiences, it only means that though the mind appears calm on the surface, it is not in fact calm.
('98', 341, 5, 21, 719978) That there are visions of things not related to experience, means, in my view, that apart from memory, there are many other things involved.
('98', 341, 6, 22, 720119) 1 In this section of undated items, letters and notes from Gandhiji to individuals have been put together in the alphabetical order of surnames, as it has not been possible to establish conclusive evidence of the period to which they belong.
('98', 341, 6, 23, 720361) However, an occasional inference as regards the date of an item is ventured in a footnote to the title.
('98', 342, 0, 1, 720465) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 343
('98', 342, 1, 2, 720512) Q. 3. When work of service makes demands of one, sometimes it is not possible to pursue devotional activity.
('98', 342, 1, 3, 720621) Is this harmful?
('98', 342, 1, 4, 720638) What should be considered more important – service or recitation of God's name?
('98', 342, 2, 5, 720718) A. Whether it is the demands of work or even sterner demands, the recitation of the Ramanama may never be stopped.
('98', 342, 2, 6, 720833) Its outward expression may be modified depending on the circumstances.
('98', 342, 2, 7, 720904) Even if one does not count the beads, can Ramanama which is inscribed in the heart, be abandoned?
('98', 342, 2, 8, 721002) M. K. GANDHI
('98', 342, 3, 9, 721015) From a copy of the Hindi: Pyarelal Papers.
('98', 342, 3, 10, 721058) Courtesy: Pyarelal
('98', 342, 4, 11, 721077) 339. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('98', 342, 5, 12, 721105) 1. There is life and there is death.
('98', 342, 5, 13, 721142) Freedom from all bondage is moksha.
('98', 342, 5, 14, 721178) 2. He who consders himself in bondage is a bound person.
('98', 342, 5, 15, 721235) It is attachment.
('98', 342, 5, 16, 721253) He is bound by the bonds of attachment.
('98', 342, 5, 17, 721293) Knowingly or unknowingly, he seeks freedom from it.
('98', 342, 5, 18, 721345) 3. Freedom that needs replenishing is not freedom.
('98', 342, 5, 19, 721396) He who is free is the best.
('98', 342, 5, 20, 721424) 4. There is not the slightest external difference between a bound and a free man.
('98', 342, 5, 21, 721506) A free man recognizes himself.
('98', 342, 5, 22, 721537) Even while doing, he does not do, for he never yearns for reward.
('98', 342, 5, 23, 721603) He does his deeds by force of the previous sanskaras 2. 5. No activity is possible for the one who is free.
('98', 342, 5, 24, 721711) For him there is nothing that remains to be attained.
('98', 342, 5, 25, 721765) 6. Rama, Krishna, etc., who are settled in my imagination are free souls to my mind.
('98', 342, 5, 26, 721850) My emancipated Rama and Krishna have nothing at all to do with the Rama and Krishna of history.
('98', 342, 5, 27, 721946) This is a matter of imagina tion.
('98', 342, 5, 28, 721980) In truth, only the emancipated can recognize the emancipated.
('98', 342, 5, 29, 722042) I have not become emancipated myself.
('98', 342, 5, 30, 722080) 7. Apart from non vegetarianism, I have written about the historical Buddha.
('98', 342, 5, 31, 722157) But that would be like proud words from an under serving person.
('98', 342, 5, 32, 722222) I see no harm in regarding the Buddha as a perfect,
('98', 342, 6, 33, 722274) 1 Posed by Maganbhai Shankerbhai Patel 2 This is followed by a quotation in Sanskrit, which is not clear in the source,
('98', 343, 0, 1, 722394) 344 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 343, 1, 2, 722436) and hence, an emancipated being.
('98', 343, 1, 3, 722469) 8. I started accepting the existence of God when I accepted the existence of soul.
('98', 343, 1, 4, 722552) Prior to that my condition was similar to that of an atheist if not exactly of an atheist.
('98', 343, 1, 5, 722643) During my search for Truth I discovered the soul.
('98', 343, 1, 6, 722693) If there is nothing like soul, then a truthful action may even be a sin.
('98', 343, 1, 7, 722766) But I got firmly convinced that truthful action is meritorious action at all times and thus I disocvered the soul.
('98', 343, 1, 8, 722881) 9. God’s form is incomprehensible.
('98', 343, 1, 9, 722916) Reason can somehow grasp it.
('98', 343, 1, 10, 722945) It is clear from experience.
('98', 343, 1, 11, 722974) I have the experience as far as faith goes.
('98', 343, 1, 12, 723018) But that experience is not such that all perversities of (my) mind can be said to have vanished.
('98', 343, 1, 13, 723115) 10. Faith means belief in something which we cannot prove to others or in something that others cannot prove (to us).
('98', 343, 1, 14, 723233) I have faith in both these senses.
('98', 343, 1, 15, 723268) Once we fully believe that faith can do everything, we have no place anywhere, or being in it, our place is everywhere.
('98', 343, 1, 16, 723388) It is absolutely true that I wanted to live.
('98', 343, 1, 17, 723433) It was out of pride that I had a yearning that my body still had a function to perform.
('98', 343, 1, 18, 723521) It is still there.
('98', 343, 1, 19, 723540) Even while knowing that every disease lies there, it is not destroyed.
('98', 343, 1, 20, 723611) My physical senses are pulling me perforce and do not let me give up my ego.
('98', 343, 1, 21, 723688) 11. The greatest endeavour is endeavour for moksha.
('98', 343, 1, 22, 723740) Moksha means elimination of ego.
('98', 343, 1, 23, 723773) I prevail into everybody.
('98', 343, 1, 24, 723799) The first step is the intense experience that I am unhappy when others are unhappy and I am happy when others are happy.
('98', 343, 1, 25, 723920) When that happens, the ego can hardly persist.
('98', 343, 1, 26, 723967) In the midst of disturbances, I find and experience peace.
('98', 343, 1, 27, 724026) How can there be peace when there is misery everywhere?
('98', 343, 1, 28, 724082) But if that misery has to be eliminated, I have got to be calm, and therefore, I remain calm.
('98', 343, 1, 29, 724176) If I do something grievously wrong for the sake of swaraj, Swami Ramatirtha’s 1 description of it as a night would be correct.
('98', 343, 1, 30, 724303) Swami Vivekananads's view is also correct that our rise with the help of the world implies the welfare of the world.
('98', 343, 1, 31, 724420) 12. Fate means the acts one has committed.
('98', 343, 1, 32, 724463) Clearly, I am reaping the reward for what I did yesterday.
('98', 343, 1, 33, 724522) 13. Truth, non violence and the keen observance of brahmacharya, etc.
('98', 343, 1, 34, 724592) are a means to attain moksha.
('98', 343, 1, 35, 724622) 14. Moksha means elimination of all action, that is, elimination
('98', 343, 2, 36, 724687) 1 (1873 1906): Hindu religious thinker, philosopher and poet
('98', 344, 0, 1, 724748) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 345
('98', 344, 1, 2, 724795) of ego.
('98', 344, 1, 3, 724803) But that elimination is possible only by burning away the desire for reward.
('98', 344, 1, 4, 724880) Action is connected with the body and it will go on.
('98', 344, 1, 5, 724933) We must be its witness.
('98', 344, 1, 6, 724957) That is why I would always read, always spin.
('98', 344, 1, 7, 725003) And yet I can believe that I am not reading: I am not spinning.
('98', 344, 1, 8, 725067) This can be experienced.
('98', 344, 1, 9, 725092) It cannot be explained.
('98', 344, 1, 10, 725116) 15. And I do not see place for anyone in the Ashram who wishes to merely indulge in meditation without any concrete physical activity.

('98', 348, 7, 19, 733156) The concept of renunciation seems to have been born only out of such ideas.
('98', 348, 7, 20, 733232) But what we know as renunciation would prove to be incomplete from the rational point of view.
('98', 348, 7, 21, 733327) Hence, the ultimate course would be resorting to fast.
('98', 348, 7, 22, 733382) But man cannot do it, and even if he does make an attempt, his mind is likely to imagine all kinds of things.
('98', 348, 7, 23, 733492) It seems to me that the origin of the Gita lies in such a line of thought.
('98', 348, 7, 24, 733567) And the Gita shows us on the one hand the ideal of life, and on the other, shows us how to conduct ourselves in life while pursuing that ideal.
('98', 348, 7, 25, 733711) In one sentence it is like this: Keeping the ideal in view, properly discharge whatever duty one may be called upon to do and crave for no reward.
('98', 348, 7, 26, 733858) It is by following this line that the problems arising at the Ashram get solved.
('98', 348, 7, 27, 733939) If a thief came to the Ashram, we would let him stay.
('98', 348, 7, 28, 733993) But we humbly admit our inability to do so, and
('98', 349, 0, 1, 734041) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 349, 1, 2, 734083) solve the situation in a manner that would behove us.
('98', 349, 1, 3, 734137) We have not discovered a purely non violent way of dealing with the cattle, animals, birds and the insects that come and destroy our harvests.
('98', 349, 1, 4, 734280) Hence, we practise certain violence, considering it unavoidable in recognition of our own weakness.
('98', 349, 1, 5, 734380) Otherwise, I know that driving away the cattle by shouting or hitting them with a stick, creating fright in the heart of a bird by throwing a pebble at it, destroying the insects by crushing them under the plough or by any other method, driving away snakes and such creatures or even permitting killing them, are all against the principle of non violence.
('98', 349, 1, 6, 734736) But since the Ashram or the inmates of the Ashram have not reached the stage of perfection, these things are being done even though they are inconsistent with the principle of non violence.
('98', 349, 1, 7, 734926) For that way alone is it possible to discover a path to moksha.
('98', 349, 1, 8, 734990) I have no doubt that sitting back after stopping all activity is even worse than doing such things which are against the principle of non violence.
('98', 349, 1, 9, 735138) That is exactly why the author of the Gita has said that just as behind every fire there is the fault of smoke, human beings are also afflicted with some fault or the other.

('98', 372, 4, 18, 772283) The statistics you send me do not impress me.

('98', 395, 2, 3, 803161) Y[ERAVDA] P[RISON]
('98', 395, 3, 4, 803180) BHAGWANJI, You have asked me why the work of the removal of untouch ability is proceeding at a slow pace.
('98', 395, 3, 5, 803286) The reason is clear.
('98', 395, 3, 6, 803307) What is not found elsewhere is found here.
('98', 395, 3, 7, 803350) Understanding and explaining the point that irreligion has taken the place of religion is bound to take time.
('98', 395, 3, 8, 803460) Moreover, it requires immense powers of penance to show that what is known as religion is irreligion.
('98', 395, 3, 9, 803562) Those who would show it unmistakably should be the embodiments of religion themselves.
('98', 395, 3, 10, 803649) None of us is that.
('98', 395, 3, 11, 803669) We are possessed with attachments and jealousies.
('98', 395, 3, 12, 803719) We are given to physicial passions.
('98', 395, 3, 13, 803755) We do not love evil men, we have no courage, no restraint.
('98', 395, 3, 14, 803814) Hence, who would take us seriously?
('98', 395, 3, 15, 803850) This requires less of intellectual power.
('98', 395, 3, 16, 803892) What is needed is spiritual strength.
('98', 395, 3, 17, 803930) If you consider other constructive works, you will clearly see the distinction I have made.
('98', 395, 3, 18, 804022) Have patience and inculcate the qualities indicated above.
('98', 395, 4, 19, 804081) Blessings from BAPU

('98', 400, 1, 2, 809868) 474. LETTER TO SHANTA S. PATEL1
('98', 400, 2, 3, 809900) To be sent to Shanta (Shankarbhai’s) without reading
('98', 400, 3, 4, 809953) SHANTA, Received your letter.
('98', 400, 3, 5, 809983) There is no harm at all in going round with any man, particularly a married man, if you regard him as your brother.
('98', 400, 3, 6, 810099) But in view of bitter experiences, and because such company is rare in our country, people condemn such a practice.
('98', 400, 3, 7, 810215) Where one has the permission from parents, there is no need to bother about public criticism.
('98', 400, 3, 8, 810309) But where a man or a woman becomes habituated to the company of the opposite sex, it is necessary to be cautious in spite of the initial innocent relationship.
('98', 400, 3, 9, 810469) It is another matter if such a relationship is naturally built up.
('98', 400, 3, 10, 810536) But it happens rarely.
('98', 400, 3, 11, 810559) The common and wonderful rule is that a woman should seek a woman’s company and a man should seek a man’s company.
('98', 400, 3, 12, 810674) Who can negate the distance that nature has created between man and woman?
('98', 400, 3, 13, 810749) Be sure that it is futile to marry out of a desire for friendship and after doing that not to have sexual relations.
('98', 400, 3, 14, 810866) It is quite possible that a man and a woman may avoid sexual relations after getting married with the desire to have such relations.
('98', 400, 3, 15, 810999) We can see that happening in the Ashram.
('98', 400, 3, 16, 811040) But where there is no desire at all for such indulgence, where is the need for marriage?
('98', 400, 3, 17, 811129) Does not marriage mean a desire to be something more than brother and sister?
('98', 400, 3, 18, 811207) That very thing is wrong.
('98', 400, 3, 19, 811233) But if you want to have a sexual relationship, do not deceive your mind.
('98', 400, 3, 20, 811306) There is nothing wrong in it.
('98', 400, 3, 21, 811336) Tell me.
('98', 400, 3, 22, 811345) Tell Shankarbhai.
('98', 400, 3, 23, 811363) Try to exercise restraint during the quarrel.
('98', 400, 3, 24, 811409) Write to me frankly.

('98', 403, 3, 4, 814101) PYARELAL, I am writing this is pencil.

('98', 403, 3, 6, 814166) I had intended to write sooner, but I have had to endure a lot of pain during the day.
('98', 403, 3, 7, 814253) For Sushila I have taken mother’s place.
('98', 403, 3, 8, 814294) As a mother becomes distraught when the daughter is out of her sight, so is it with me.

('98', 403, 3, 16, 814702) I would consider my efforts in vain if she were observing punctuality, which I am inculcating in her with so much care, only to please me.

('98', 403, 3, 18, 815008) Your way is of course different.

('98', 403, 3, 25, 815380) But I think you are going too far in making even Sushila keep late hours.

('98', 403, 3, 28, 815580) I would even like it.
('98', 403, 3, 29, 815602) She can give up the night massage and work for you at night till 9.30. I see many minutes and hours of her time being wasted.
('98', 403, 3, 30, 815728) But how far can I control her?
('98', 403, 3, 31, 815759) With that thought in mind I do not interfere.

('98', 403, 3, 33, 815878) I shall abide by your wish.
('98', 403, 3, 34, 815906) If you approve of what I am doing and if she follows it with interest and knowledge, I shall need all help from you.

('98', 403, 3, 36, 816123) After dinner, everybody should go to sleep.
('98', 403, 3, 37, 816167) And you should not work at night.
('98', 403, 3, 38, 816201) I shall be content with what you can give during the day.

('98', 408, 2, 3, 821724) Saturday
('98', 408, 3, 4, 821733) ANASUYABEHN, I have your letter.
('98', 408, 3, 5, 821766) It is possible that Vallabhbhai is at fault in his dealings with the workers.
('98', 408, 3, 6, 821844) But you cannot say for that reason there is authoritarianism in Gujarat.
('98', 408, 3, 7, 821917) I can, however, understand your anger arising from anguish.
('98', 408, 3, 8, 821977) I hear praise for Vallabhbhai in news wherever I get it from.
('98', 408, 3, 9, 822039) Sitting here I feel the same way about his work.
('98', 408, 3, 10, 822088) Man is full of faults.
('98', 408, 3, 11, 822111) Vallabhbhai may have made mistakes.
('98', 408, 3, 12, 822147) We must try and understand them.
('98', 408, 3, 13, 822180) And our dharma consists in drawing his attention if we can, to these mistakes so that he may rectify his faults.
('98', 408, 3, 14, 822293) If he does not mend himself, we should not get angry but remian patient.
('98', 408, 3, 15, 822366) So much for your general criticism.
('98', 408, 3, 16, 822402) Now about the workers.
('98', 408, 3, 17, 822425) Did you or Shankerlal meet Vallabh bhai in person?
('98', 408, 3, 18, 822476) If so, did you speak your mind freely to him?
('98', 408, 3, 19, 822522) You should not fight shy of being snubbed.
('98', 408, 3, 20, 822565) We should quarrel with Vallabhbhai if justice has to be got done.
('98', 408, 3, 21, 822631) Friendship consists in that and so does training for public life.
('98', 408, 3, 22, 822697) In public institutions, those whom we consider our opponents are sometimes really that, but often they are friends.
('98', 408, 3, 23, 822813) We should regard both kinds as equals and seek justice from them.
('98', 408, 3, 24, 822879) In the immediate present, I do not expect much from the the owners.
('98', 408, 3, 25, 822947) Our views are so divergent that they cannot be easily reconciled.
('98', 408, 3, 26, 823013) We should be content to take from them as much as we can or fight them.
('98', 408, 3, 27, 823085) What I like best is that the workers should build their own chawls.
('98', 408, 3, 28, 823153) But is that possible at present?
('98', 408, 3, 29, 823186) However, I feel that even if a small number of workers come forward to do so, we should encourage it.
('98', 408, 3, 30, 823288) If you are hesitant to write to Vallabhbhai about what you should get from him, let me know and I shall do so readily.

('98', 419, 16, 22, 838386) 521. NOTES FOR SURENDRANATH 1
('98', 419, 17, 23, 838416) 9. The instinctive qualities attributed to the soul are the gunas of the individual.
('98', 419, 17, 24, 838501) He who possesses the quality of maximum calm is sattvika or righteous.
('98', 419, 17, 25, 838572) He who possesses the quality of maximum disquiet is rajasi or passionate.
('98', 419, 17, 26, 838646) And he who lacks in both these qualities and is also wanting in awareness or knowledge is tamasi, which signifies darkness and ignorance.
('98', 419, 17, 27, 838784) 10. Every wise person must possess the same qualities.
('98', 419, 17, 28, 838839) He may appear to be impractical, but in reality, he is not so.
('98', 419, 17, 29, 838902) 11. Ba is still so stupid that she does not understand even common duty.
('98', 419, 17, 30, 838975) It pained me.
('98', 419, 17, 31, 838989) There was only pity behind it.
('98', 419, 17, 32, 839020) 12. The body can certainly reach the state of absolute brahmacharya and absolute truth.
('98', 419, 17, 33, 839108) There can be no freedom from unavoidable violence like breathing.
('98', 419, 17, 34, 839174) 13. That a passionless, perfect man should commit a blunder is a contradiction in terms like a son being born to a barren woman.
('98', 419, 18, 35, 839303) 1 Reproduced as serialized in the source

('98', 420, 1, 2, 839391) possible that man would become free in spite of wearing foreign clothes.
('98', 420, 1, 3, 839464) But let us not attain freedom by wearing foreign clothes.
('98', 420, 1, 4, 839522) 14. A one sided statement that the Buddha did not attain emancipation only because he ate non vegetarian food cannot be true.
('98', 420, 1, 5, 839648) 15. A person who has controlled the senses ultimately becomes incapable of sensual pleasures.
('98', 420, 1, 6, 839742) But that is the capacity of the strong.

('98', 420, 1, 8, 839873) It is the calm resulting from a sense of duty.
('98', 420, 1, 9, 839920) Hence, a saintly man experiences calm in the midst of disquiet.

('98', 430, 5, 12, 856299) The wrong is all the greater because they have turned it into a virtue of which they are proud.

('98', 436, 6, 12, 863865) APPENDIX
('98', 436, 7, 13, 863874) EXTRACT FROM A WRITING OF THOMAS CARLYLE 3
('98', 436, 8, 14, 863917) It is only with renunciation that life, properly speaking, can be said to begin.
('98', 436, 8, 15, 863998) What is this that thou hast been fretting and fuming on account of?
('98', 436, 8, 16, 864066) Say in a word: Is it not because thou art not happy?
('98', 436, 8, 17, 864119) Because thee (who art a sweet gentleman) is not sufficiently honoured, nourished, soft bedded and lovingly cared for?
('98', 436, 8, 18, 864237) Foolish soul!
('98', 436, 8, 19, 864251) What Act of Legislature was there thou shouldst be happy?
('98', 436, 8, 20, 864309) A little while ago thou hadst no right to be at all.
('98', 436, 8, 21, 864362) What if thou weren’t born and predestined not to be happy, but to be unhappy?
('98', 436, 8, 22, 864440) Art thou nothing other than a vulture that flying through the universe seeking after somewhat to eat and shrieking dolefully because carrion enough is not given thee?
('98', 436, 8, 23, 864607) Man can do without anything and instead find blessedness.
('98', 436, 8, 24, 864665) Was it not to preach forth the same Higher [Truth] that sages and martyrs have spoken and suffered, bearing testimony through life and through death of the God like that is in man and how in the God like only he has strength and freedom?
('98', 436, 8, 25, 864903) Oh, thank thy destiny for afflictions.
('98', 436, 8, 26, 864942) Thankfully bear what yet remain.
('98', 436, 8, 27, 864975) Thou hadst need of them.
('98', 436, 8, 28, 865000) The self in thee needed to be annihilated.
('98', 436, 8, 29, 865043) By benignant fever paroxysms is life rooting out the deep seated chronic disease and triumphs over death.
('98', 436, 9, 30, 865149) From the original: Gandhi Kallenbach Correspondence.
('98', 436, 9, 31, 865202) Courtesy: National Archives of India

('98', 437, 7, 10, 865878) 573. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('98', 437, 8, 11, 865912) Thursday night
('98', 437, 9, 12, 865927) DEAR MR. KALLENBACH, The Upper House was delighted to receive a note from the Lower House, but the Upper House strongly resents and protests against the insult implied in the titles used by the Lower House in addressing the Upper House.
('98', 437, 9, 13, 866164) If the Lower House persists in such disrespectful and inappropriate language, all the liberty granted by the Constitution to the Lower House will be withdrawn and the Lower House will be called upon to return to Phoenix at once and before Tuesday in order to give a good account to the Lower House’s doings.
('98', 437, 9, 14, 866472) ‘Master me no Master’ says the Upper House.
('98', 437, 9, 15, 866516) Whether the Upper House can fairly enjoy the privilege of the friendship of the Lower is a question to be jointly determined after due deliberation by both the Houses.
('98', 437, 9, 16, 866684) In the meanwhile, the Upper House must undergo a period of probation before claiming the high title of a true friend.
('98', 437, 9, 17, 866802) The time table is good, but how can you think of remaining there the whole of the other week when the progress is spelt retrogression!
('98', 437, 9, 18, 866937) From good to medium and from medium to bad is a startling thing.
('98', 437, 9, 19, 867002) I really, therefore, think that it will be as well to pass next week at Phoenix.
('98', 437, 9, 20, 867083) There is not much chance of my going there during the week.
('98', 437, 9, 21, 867143) There is much to do and see at Phoenix and if necessary you can pay a visit to Durban in the meanwhile, returning
('98', 438, 0, 1, 867257) VOL. 98: 6 DECEMBER, 1947 30 JANUARY, 1948 439
('98', 438, 1, 2, 867304) here for the night.
('98', 438, 1, 3, 867324) However, if you think that Durban is giving you mental peace and progress, by all means stay there.
('98', 438, 1, 4, 867424) You need not fear t he food here now because it is most like what we have at Orchards.
('98', 438, 2, 5, 867511) Yours sincerely, M.K. GANDHI [PS.] What about Dickson’s advice?
('98', 438, 3, 6, 867575) From the original: Gandhi Kallenbach Correspondence.

('98', 439, 0, 1, 868721) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 439, 1, 2, 868763) If you were here I could certainly profit by your knowledge of gardening.
('98', 439, 1, 3, 868837) I am discussing with the press people as to the gardening and the proposal is that all but Kababhai should give 4 hours togardening every day.
('98', 439, 1, 4, 868980) If we can but carry out the programme, what a glorious thing it would be!
('98', 439, 1, 5, 869054) We propose to do joint cultivation on Cordes’ ground as it is fenced and put in there fruit trees which would give a return enough to support at least a few.
('98', 439, 1, 6, 869212) There are two Kaffir boys working at the press.
('98', 439, 1, 7, 869260) I am suggesting that we should use them mostly for field work.
('98', 439, 1, 8, 869323) Reverting to the food question, I see that I could easily live on the products of Phoenix, barring oil.
('98', 439, 1, 9, 869427) All fruit just now is very dear.
('98', 439, 1, 10, 869460) Otherwise I should live on 8 d.
('98', 439, 1, 11, 869492) per day and not 1/3 as now.
('98', 439, 1, 12, 869520) per day would be exactly £1 per month.
('98', 439, 1, 13, 869559) I often substitute lemons by raw mangoes which are soaked in olive oil.
('98', 439, 1, 14, 869631) Mangoes are home grown ≈ not so lemons just now.
('98', 439, 1, 15, 869680) I am writing this amid many interruptions.
('98', 439, 1, 16, 869723) So I shall close with love.
('98', 439, 1, 17, 869751) Will you please read this to Mr. Kotwal and others so that they may understand the progress of my experiment.
('98', 439, 2, 18, 869861) Yours sincerely, UPPER HOUSE

('98', 440, 3, 16, 870959) The Registrar’s office is here today.
('98', 440, 3, 17, 870997) I had a long chat with General Smuts last week on his invitation.

('98', 448, 1, 2, 882919) 592. LETTER TO PRABHUDAS GANDHI
('98', 448, 2, 3, 882951) Phagun Sud 11, Tuesday
('98', 448, 3, 4, 882974) PRABHUDAS,1 I have your letter.
('98', 448, 3, 5, 883006) If you do not find it strenuous, make it a rule to write at least once a week.
('98', 448, 3, 6, 883085) You have asked four questions but all of them seem to originate from one issue and that has arisen either due to misunderstanding or loss of memory.
('98', 448, 3, 7, 883234) I have not commented on your reading Tulsidas, Akho, etc., but you had expressed a desire to learn geology also, and that I had criticized a little.
('98', 448, 3, 8, 883383) I regard it as superficial knowledge.
('98', 448, 3, 9, 883421) It is not that this desire is base.
('98', 448, 3, 10, 883457) The only thing is that even if a person strives to imbibe such knowledge, he will gain very little.
('98', 448, 3, 11, 883557) My intention was only to say that one should be satisfied with what he easily gets.
('98', 448, 3, 12, 883641) Reading from Tulsidas cannot be considered pursuit of superficial knowledge.
('98', 448, 3, 13, 883718) It is only an external means of gaining knowledge of the self.
('98', 448, 3, 14, 883781) But study of geology, etc., is superficial knowledge.
('98', 448, 3, 15, 883835) It is a different thing if it helps someone in acquiring knowledge of the self.
('98', 448, 3, 16, 883915) I did not want to go so deep into the subject, nor did I want you to do that.
('98', 448, 3, 17, 883993) In youth, everyone feels like gaining knowledge of such science.
('98', 448, 3, 18, 884058) That’s justified too.
('98', 448, 3, 19, 884080) The intention of my criticism was to reduce the intensity of such desire.
('98', 448, 3, 20, 884154) However, I will not have any objection if you can easily find a person who has a thorough knowledge of geology and from whom you can easily learn.
('98', 448, 3, 21, 884301) I will not consider such knowledge useless.
('98', 448, 3, 22, 884345) One who has given his heart to God will use even that knowledge in praise of Him.
('98', 448, 3, 23, 884427) Now, I hope I do not have to clarify the difference between true knowledge and superficial knowledge.
('98', 448, 3, 24, 884529) Should I assume from your letter that there is a slight improvement in your health?
('98', 448, 4, 25, 884613) Blessings from BAPU

('98', 448, 6, 27, 884672) 593. LETTER TO PRABHUDAS GANDHI BOMBAY, Saturday
('98', 448, 7, 28, 884721) PRABHUDAS, I have read your letter to Chi.
('98', 448, 7, 29, 884764) There is a difference between thoughts and fancies.
('98', 448, 7, 30, 884816) Man falls through fancies and becomes a prey to worrying, thoughts mature him.
('98', 448, 7, 31, 884895) In the sentence, ‘This man
('98', 448, 8, 32, 884922) 1 The letter is in a different hand but the subscription is by Gandhiji.
('98', 449, 0, 1, 884995) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('98', 449, 1, 2, 885037) is ever thinking’, ‘thinking’ means ‘worrying’.
('98', 449, 1, 3, 885085) You should give that up.
('98', 449, 1, 4, 885110) But it is essential that we use our judgement and discriminate between our good and bad tendencies.
('98', 449, 1, 5, 885210) By thinking systematically in this matter, we become mature.
('98', 449, 1, 6, 885271) You should not worry or indulge in fancies while plying the spinning wheel.
('98', 449, 1, 7, 885347) If impure thoughts forcibly invade your mind, you should, with equal energy, force yourself to think differently.
('98', 449, 1, 8, 885461) He who is devoted to his work, has no time to indulge in useless thoughts.
('98', 449, 1, 9, 885536) Always remember that there is One Witness to all our thoughts.
('98', 449, 1, 10, 885599) How can we entertain impure thoughts in the presence of that Witness?
('98', 449, 1, 11, 885669) Take this to be the meaning of the verse, ‘It ceases when the Supreme is seen’.
('98', 449, 1, 12, 885749) Who, after seeing the Supreme, can take pleasure in the objects of the senses?
('98', 449, 1, 13, 885828) We do not know the atman.
('98', 449, 1, 14, 885854) That is why we commit sins everyday.
('98', 449, 1, 15, 885891) If we but know that He sees our thoughts also, then, just as we are ashamed to commit any sin in the presence of our dearest friend, we would, if we are definitely convinced that our atman always stands there as a witness, be ashamed of thinking impure thoughts or doing impure things.
('98', 449, 1, 16, 886177) How, then, can hypocrisy remain in us?
('98', 449, 1, 17, 886216) Lakshmidas and Velanbehn are generous.
('98', 449, 1, 18, 886255) They will certainly forgive you.
('98', 449, 1, 19, 886288) But it is your atman’s forgiveness that you really need.
('98', 449, 1, 20, 886345) Once you have become pure, you will as a matter of course be forgiven.
('98', 449, 1, 21, 886416) It is not in the nature of the atman to be impure.
('98', 449, 1, 22, 886467) So, if the impurity has left you, it has left you for good.
('98', 449, 1, 23, 886527) When even the worst of sinners becomes clean, he can stand on a footing of equality with one who has committed no sin at any time.
('98', 449, 1, 24, 886658) There is no distinction of high and low in the state of moksha 1. When that one indescribable state is attained, it is the same for all.
('98', 449, 1, 25, 886795) All of us commit sins.
('98', 449, 1, 26, 886818) But manliness lies in seeing and recognizing them and then destroying them.
('98', 449, 1, 27, 886894) You committed sins.
('98', 449, 1, 28, 886914) But you need not feel frightened for that reason.
